announcements.title: India Promotes Ayurveda Health at Arctic Meeting in Reykjavik
announcements.content: During the 2025 Arctic Circle Assembly in Reykjavík, Iceland, members of the Indian delegation, including Prof. (Vaidya) Rabinarayan Acharya, Director General of the Central Council for Research in Ayurvedic Sciences (CCRAS), and Dr. Srinivas Rao Chinta, Joint Advisor for Homoeopathy at the Ministry of Ayush, spoke at a session called "The Role and Importance of the Global South in the Arctic." Prof. Acharya talked about India’s active role in the Arctic through its Arctic Policy. He highlighted how traditional medicine can help solve global health problems and mentioned how Ayush can support health and resilience even in harsh places like the Arctic. The session was organized by India and had many respected speakers, such as Rear Admiral T.V.N. Prasanna, Polar Coordinator for India; Manish Tiwari, Scientist F at the National Centre for Polar and Ocean Research (NCPOR); and Wassim Said, member of the Emirates Polar Program Steering Committee in the UAE. Prof. Acharya shared a future plan to strengthen cooperation between traditional knowledge and Arctic research. He suggested starting joint clinical trials in Arctic areas, creating a research consortium within the Arctic policy framework, and building skills for cross‑cultural delivery of Ayush and monitoring its safety. He also stressed the importance of publishing strong scientific evidence to link traditional and modern medicine and pushed for embedding Ayush awareness in India’s Arctic diplomatic efforts. The presence of the Ministry of Ayush delegation shows India’s commitment to bring Ayush knowledge, innovation, and diplomacy into global talks on sustainability and health. This move reaffirms India’s role as a responsible partner promoting holistic health, scientific cooperation, and people‑to‑people ties under its Arctic Policy. *** SR/GS/SG
announcements.original_title: Ayush Diplomacy Reaches the Arctic: India Champions Integrative Health Collaboration at Reykjavík Assembly
announcements.summary:
India spoke at the Arctic Circle Assembly in Reykjavík.
The delegation said that Ayurveda and traditional medicine can help keep people healthy even in cold places, and they want to work with Arctic researchers to test and share these ideas.

announcements.title: Ayush and ICMR to hold national seminar on liver health with Ayurveda
announcements.content: The Ministry of Ayush is continuing its promise to base traditional medicine on evidence. It is working with the Central Council for Research in Ayurvedic Sciences (CCRAS) and its Central Ayurveda Research Institute (CARI) in Bhubaneswar, together with the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) and its Regional Medical Research Centre (RMRC) in Bhubaneswar, to hold a two‑day National Seminar on "Hepatobiliary Wellness through Ayurveda: Bridging Traditional Wisdom with Contemporary Science" from 25 to 26 October 2025 in Bhubaneswar. The seminar’s theme is "Yakrut Suraksha, Jiveeta Raksha" (Protect the Liver, Preserve Life) and marks a major step toward creating research‑supported ways to care for liver and bile health. It brings together Ayurveda and modern biomedical science. Prof. Rabinarayan Acharya, Director General of CCRAS, said, "Ayurveda offers a complete framework for liver health, focusing on prevention, balance and sustainable care. By doing joint research we are scientifically confirming Ayurveda principles and products, so we better understand how they work and how useful they are in real life. These efforts give Ayurveda global trust and open new evidence‑based options that can change how we treat the liver and improve public health." Dr. Sanghamitra Pati, Additional Director General of ICMR and Director of RMRC Bhubaneswar, added, "Liver problems are complex and need cross‑disciplinary research and new ideas. Working together with Ayurveda and modern medicine creates new ways to understand disease, develop safer treatments and improve patient care. By blending old wisdom with rigorous science, we can build health models that are preventive, personalised and worldwide relevant." The two‑day seminar will cover five main topics and support joint research on liver and bile health. Day 1 will look at overall preventive and therapeutic approaches, including Ayurveda diet, daily routine, seasonal routine, Panchakarma and cleansing therapies, plus scientific tests and disease‑specific plans for NAFLD, Hepatitis and Liver Cirrhosis. Day 2 will focus on evidence‑based integration, showing experiments on the safety, effectiveness and workings of Ayurveda products, and plans to match Ayurveda with modern hospital practices, such as the Gut‑Liver Axis. The event will feature 58 scientific talks—22 oral and 36 posters—showing clinical results and future applications. A special session on "Ethnomedicine in Hepatobiliary Disorders" will highlight 20 tribal healers from Odisha, showing the Ministry’s effort to keep local medical knowledge alive. This partnership of CCRAS and ICMR shows the Ministry of Ayush’s focus on strict science, teamwork across fields and practical outcomes. By linking Ayurveda’s complete knowledge with modern research, the seminar hopes to open new paths for combined approaches to liver health and strengthen India’s global leadership in traditional medicine research. The Ministry has been working hard through CCRAS and others to scientifically prove Ayurveda for liver conditions like MASLD and hepatitis. Pre‑clinical studies on Picrorhiza kurroa (Kutaki) and Ayush‑PTK products have shown strong liver protection, while a joint study with CSIR‑CDRI in Lucknow is testing key Ayurvedic medicines against drug‑induced liver damage from ATT. A multi‑centre trial on Arogyavardhini Vati and Pippalyasava has shown good results for MASLD. A double‑blind trial is also studying the liver‑protecting effect of Ayush‑PTK in tuberculosis patients on ATT, showing CCRAS’s dedication to evidence‑based Ayurveda. The National Seminar will boost science dialogue in this area. Leading experts from modern and traditional medicine, including Prof. (Dr.) Ashutosh Biswas, Executive Director & CEO of AIIMS Bhubaneswar; Prof. Subrat Kumar Acharya, Pro‑Chancellor of KIIMS Bhubaneswar and Executive Director of Fortis Escorts, New Delhi; and Dr. Sarada Ota, Assistant Director in charge of CARI Bhubaneswar, will be present. Other distinguished scientists, doctors and teachers such as Prof. Manas Ranjan Sahoo, Dr. N. Srikanth, Dr. Ashok B. K., Dr. Rajesh Kumavat and many others will join, creating a multi‑disciplinary platform to advance liver research and integrated care through Ayurveda.

announcements.title: Agriculture Minister pushes quick start of Pulses Mission and PM Farm Plan
announcements.content: Shri Shivraj Singh Chouhan, the Union Minister for Agriculture, Farmers Welfare and Rural Development, met with senior ministry officials about the ‘Self‑Reliance in Pulses Mission’ and the ‘Pradhan Mantri Dhan‑Dhaanya Krishi Yojana’. He gave instructions for both schemes to be carried out within set deadlines. To speed up the ‘Pradhan Mantri Dhan‑Dhaanya Krishi Yojana’, he will soon hold a meeting with ministers from 11 ministries. The meeting also confirmed that the ‘Self‑Reliance in Pulses Mission’ will be run through district‑level clusters, and states are asked to help form these clusters. He also told officials to make sure the ‘Pradhan Mantri Dhan‑Dhaanya Krishi Yojana’ is effectively implemented at the village level. He said that quick action at the ground level will help farmers directly. The ‘Pradhan Mantri Dhan‑Dhaanya Krishi Yojana’, launched by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, is designed to boost farming in 100 aspirational districts by linking 36 sub‑schemes from 11 ministries. Therefore, Shri Chouhan asked officials to arrange a meeting with the ministers and secretaries of those 11 ministries, plus NITI Aayog staff, so that farmers get the most benefit. He also ordered a meeting with the main officers of the states involved in the ‘Self‑Reliance in Pulses Mission’ to ensure it runs smoothly and on time. On 11 October 2025, Prime Minister Modi launched both the ‘Pradhan Mantri Dhan‑Dhaanya Krishi Yojana’ and the ‘Self‑Reliance in Pulses Mission’ at a major event in Pusa, New Delhi. The Union Cabinet approved the ‘Pradhan Mantri Dhan‑Dhaanya Krishi Yojana’ on 16 July 2025. The scheme will run for six years, starting FY 2025–26, with an annual budget of ₹24,000 crore. The ‘Self‑Reliance in Pulses Mission’ will also run for six years with a budget of ₹11,440 crore. It aims to raise the area under pulses from 275 lakh hectares to 310 lakh hectares, increase production from 242 lakh tonnes to 350 lakh tonnes, and raise productivity to 1,130 kg per hectare by 2030–31. Along with better productivity, the mission is expected to create many jobs. ***** RC/AR
announcements.original_title: Union Agriculture Minister Shri Shivraj Singh directs for timely implementation of ‘Self-Reliance in Pulses Mission’ and ‘Pradhan Mantri Dhan-Dhaanya Krishi Yojana’
announcements.summary:
Shri Shivraj Singh Chouhan told officials to speed up the Self‑Reliance in Pulses Mission and the Pradhan Mantri Dhan‑Dhaanya Krishi Yojana, meeting ministers from 11 ministries and using district clusters to help farmers quickly.
The schemes will run for six years from FY 2025‑26, with budgets of ₹24,000 crore and ₹11,440 crore, aiming to boost pulse areas and production.

announcements.title: DA&FW work till 17 Oct 2025
announcements.content:
Special Campaign 5.0 was launched by DARPG to reduce backlog in government offices. The campaign has two phases: the Preparatory Phase from 16 th - 30 th September 2025, and the Main Phase from 2 nd - 31 st October 2025. The main focus is disposal of E-waste. The department has carried out thorough cleanliness drives at its headquarters and at all subordinate or attached offices, PSU, etc. across the country. Dedicated effort has been made to meet these targets during the Implementation Phase from 2 nd to 31 st October, 2025. All offices and officers are encouraged to dispose of E-waste properly as per government guidelines and to find new uses for the E-waste they generate. All Subordinate/Attached Offices under DA&FW are enthusiastically participating. Farm Machinery Training and Testing Institutes have made several models of equipment used by farmers from E-waste. A workshop on Public Grievances and Special Campaign 5.0 was organised by the department on 9.10.2025 with help from the Department of Administrative Reforms and Public Grievances; it was addressed by the Secretary of DA&FW and the Secretary of DARPG. Other senior officers, nodal officers for Public Grievances and the campaign, attended. Officers from the department and attached and subordinate offices under DA&FW were sensitised on the NextGen CPGRAMS portal and Special Campaign 5.0. Booklets on work allocation and submission channels in DA&FW were jointly unveiled by the secretaries. During the workshop, models of drones, tractors, cultivators etc. made from E-waste by officers and staff of various Farm Machinery Training and Testing Institutes under DA&FW were showcased. The Secretary of DARPG appreciated the officers’ efforts. The department has a strong grievance‑redressal system for farmers. The Krishi Rakshak Portal was presented in the workshop, and a 3D physical model of it was also displayed. By the middle of Special Campaign 5.0 (up to 17.10.2025), four PIB notes and more than 150 tweets had been posted by the department and its attached/subordinate/field offices on social media platforms such as Twitter, LinkedIn, Instagram, Facebook, etc. Progress and achievements of the department up to the mid‑campaign are as follows:
1. Number of cleanliness campaign sites: Target 1105, Achievement 500

3. Pending Public Grievances: Target 171442, Achievement 90150
4. Pending PG Appeals: Target 1500, Achievement 859

7. Space freed (area in sq. ft.): 5917 sq. ft.
8. Revenue generated (amount in Rupees): Rs. 12,73,071/-

announcements.title: FAO marks 80 years of partnership with India
announcements.content: Dr. Devesh Chaturvedi, Secretary of the Ministry of Agriculture & Farmers Welfare, spoke at World Food Day 2025, which also marked the 80th anniversary of the FAO. He thanked the FAO for its expertise and its long partnership with the Ministry, helping India become self‑sufficient in food grains, grow more varieties of crops, and make farmers stronger through new ideas and eco‑friendly ways. He said that the future must focus on nutrition‑aware farming, so everyone has healthy, varied, safe and affordable food. He noted that from being food‑poor when India first became independent, the country has now become a food‑surplus nation that feeds 1.4 billion people and plays a big part in worldwide food security. He said this change came from bold policies, science, and strong global teamwork led by the Ministry and FAO. India, a founding FAO member since 1945, shows that hunger can be cut down when farming, supply, and policy work together. He pointed out that even though India owns less than 4% of the world’s farmland and water, it has become food‑self‑sufficient and kept prices steady using public stocks and the Minimum Support Price (MSP). These systems give cheap food to more than 800 million people under the National Food Security Act, showing India’s rights‑based food security. He added that India’s farming success comes from its 146 million small farms, which keep rural life alive. Specific help such as tough seeds, cheap loans, crop insurance, and climate‑smart methods has raised yields, resilience, and farmers’ income. He reaffirmed India’s pledge to sustainability and climate change, noting projects like micro‑irrigation, integrated and natural farming, organic farming, and digital tools like AgriStack that give farmers tech and live data. The event also launched FAO’s coffee‑table book, "Sowing Hope, Harvesting Success", which tells FAO’s 80‑year journey and key moments in farming and related fields with India. Mr. Shombi Sharp, UN Resident Coordinator in India, and Mr. Takayuki Hagiwara, FAO Representative in India, attended. Mr. Sharp said the FAO story in India is also India’s rise as a global farming leader. Mr. Hagiwara confirmed FAO’s promise to help India reach Viksit Bharat by 2047. In line with this year’s World Food Day theme, "Hand in Hand for Better Food and a Better Future", the celebration brought together senior Indian government staff, UN and Rome‑based agencies, partners, and farmers from all over the country. He concluded that worldwide food problems need worldwide solutions based on local facts, and urged stronger international teamwork, open sharing of knowledge, and joint action to meet the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). He sent warm greetings on World Food Day and wished everyone a happy, prosperous Diwali. ****** RC/AR
announcements.original_title: FAO Celebrates 80 Years of Partnership with India on World Food Day 2025
announcements.summary:
At World Food Day 2025, Dr. Devesh Chaturvedi thanked FAO on its 80th anniversary and said India now feeds 1.4 billion people.
He urged global teamwork to keep food safe, affordable and nutritious, and wished everyone a happy Diwali.

announcements.title: Union Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan visited Dumri Khurd village in Gorakhpur today
announcements.content: Union Minister for Agriculture & Farmers’ Welfare, and Rural Development, Shri Shivraj Singh Chouhan today talked with rural villagers at a ‘Gram Chaupal’ held in Dumri Khurd village in Gorakhpur, Uttar Pradesh. Many locals, farmers, SHG members, and Panchayat representatives were there. Shri Shivraj talked about the joint work of the Central and Uttar Pradesh Governments to help farmers. He said the government is continually working to raise production, supply better seeds, and cut costs. The Minister also promised compensation under the Pradhan Mantri Fasal Bima Yojana for crop losses. While talking to the farmers, he asked for their feedback on main crops, costs, and the need for local food shops. Shri Chouhan also explained the plan to boost lentil and gram production under the Central Government’s ‘Self‑Reliance in Pulses Mission’ and asked farmers for suggestions. He noted that this year the Central Government has raised the Minimum Support Price (MSP) for Rabi crops, which will help farmers a lot. He shared the specific increases in MSP for wheat, gram, lentil, and mustard. Shri Shivraj said that under Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi, GST on agricultural machinery has been lowered from 12% and 18% to 5%, giving direct money help to farmers. The Minister also urged farmers to take up animal husbandry, fisheries, beekeeping, and horticulture in addition to farming. He mentioned government schemes for animal vaccination. Many farmers, SHG members, and Panchayat representatives were present at the ‘Gram Chaupal’, where they voiced their concerns and gave suggestions to the Union Minister. At the end, Shri Chouhan asked everyone to cooperate and take part in rural development and farm prosperity. ******** RC/S/AR/AK
announcements.original_title: Union Minister Shri Shivraj Singh Chouhan held a ‘Gram Chaupal’ in village Dumri Khurd of Gorakhpur today
announcements.summary:
Shri Shivraj Singh Chouhan talked to farmers in Dumri Khurd, saying the government will raise seed supply and cut costs.
He also announced higher MSP for wheat, gram, lentil and mustard, 5% GST on farm machines, and encouraged work in animal care, fisheries, beekeeping, and horticulture.

announcements.title: Coal Ministry pushes clean, efficient, sustainable practices
announcements.content: As part of the ongoing Special Campaign 5.0, the Ministry of Coal and its Public Sector Undertakings (PSUs) are actively carrying out a set of activities that were identified in the campaign’s preparation stage. These actions encourage the use of best practices to improve cleanliness, operational efficiency, and sustainability in the coal sector. During the implementation phase from 2nd to 31st October 2025, great progress was made: 802 sites were cleaned, covering 40,86,545sq. ft., which moves us toward the overall goal of 82,51,511 sq. ft. Against the target of 8,678 MT of scrap, 4,763 MT was disposed of, generating Rs. 20 crores in revenue. Before (CCL) After (CCL) 73,756 physical and 18,719 electronic files were reviewed, and 15,089 files were removed/closed. Before (SCCL) After (SCCL) Some of the best practices in this Campaign are: 1. Bio Toilets Under SC 5.0 – 33 Bio-Toilets were opened in Western Coalfields Limited (WCL) mines in Nagpur, improving hygiene and supporting eco‑friendly sanitation for workers. 2. Turning the Scrap Room into a “Learning Hub” (NLCIL) – During Special Campaign 5.0, an unused scrap room at TPS II Expansion, NLCIL, became a Learning Lab, a lively space for sharing knowledge. The lab encourages continuous learning and boosts employee development across TPS II Expansion. This shows NLCIL's commitment to building a progressive, empowered, and resilient workforce, where flexibility and growth are key to excellence. Before After 3. Environmental Friendly Practices – A greenhouse was built at Rajeev Gandhi ITI, Barsingsar, NLCIL, providing a controlled setting for non‑native plant species. This shows the Ministry’s focus on innovative and sustainable environmental practices. Before After 4. 'E-Waste to Art' workshop & exhibition for children – an inclusivity activity – WCL held an 'E-Waste to Art' workshop at its headquarters for employees' children, led by famous Nagpur artist Shri Anand Dhopte. Children turned discarded electronic items into sculptures such as an Indian Army tank, an airplane, and a robot, showing innovation, recycling, and sustainability awareness. The workshop gave a fun, educational, and inclusive experience for children and parents. By using new ideas, improving cleanliness, and encouraging learning and creativity, these actions set new standards in the coal sector and support the Ministry’s vision of a modern, responsible, and forward‑looking industry. **** Shuhaib T / Durgesh Kumar
announcements.original_title: Ministry of Coal Drives Cleanliness, Efficiency, and Sustainability Under Special Campaign 5.0
announcements.summary: The Ministry of Coal's Special Campaign 5.0 cleaned 802 sites from 2nd to 31st October 2025, covering 40,86,545sq. ft. and reached 4,763 MT of scrap disposal, earning Rs. 20 crores. It also opened 33 Bio-Toilets, turned a scrap room into a Learning Hub, built a greenhouse, and held an 'E-Waste to Art' workshop to boost hygiene, learning, and sustainability.

announcements.title: NCL runs 'Waste to Art' and clean-up campaign 5.0
announcements.content: On the Prime Minister’s call, with guidance from the Ministry of Coal, the Coal India company Northern Coalfields Limited (NCL) in Singrauli is taking part in Special Campaign 5.0. The focus is on keeping places clean, managing records, getting rid of scrap, and doing green work in all its areas. Following the “Waste to Beauty” idea, a large statue of the National Bird Peacock and Barasingha is being put up. The statue is made from iron scrap that comes from mining. It shows NCL’s promise to protect the environment and to be creative. NCL has also set up five bio‑toilets in its projects to give workers and nearby people clean and green toilets. These bio‑toilets leave a small environmental impact and help the Swachh Bharat Mission. For the local community, a “Waste to Art” contest was held at Kendriya Vidyalaya, Singrauli, on 17th October. Students showed ideas for reusing and recycling scrap, which encouraged more people to join green waste practices. NCL’s Special Campaign 5.0 keeps raising awareness and taking action through clean‑up drives, public events, and better record keeping in all areas. The company wants to set new standards in cleanliness, admin efficiency, and environmental care, in line with the Government’s aim of a cleaner and greener India. NCL has set a big goal in the campaign: clean 75 places, keep 85,000 square feet of area sanitary, dispose of 2,500 metric tonnes of scrap, check 350 physical files, and review 9,000 e‑files. **** Shuhaib T / Durgesh Kumar

announcements.title: Coal India and IIT Madras Build a Sustainable Energy Center
announcements.content: Coal India Limited (CIL) signed an agreement (MoU) with IIT Madras on Wednesday to set up the "Centre for Sustainable Energy" at IIT Madras. The agreement was signed by Shri Achyut Ghatak, Director (Technical), CIL, and Shri V. Kamakoti, Director, IIT Madras, in front of Shri P.M. Prasad, Chairman, CIL, and other senior staff from both CIL and IIT Madras. The center will be a hub for advanced research and training in clean energy. With CIL’s funding and its goal of diversifying, the center will focus on turning coal mines into useful resources, making low‑carbon tech, and seeing coal as a useful material in India’s clean energy future. This partnership shows a shared commitment to leading India’s energy transition through homegrown research, innovation, and technology to reach the nation’s net‑zero goals by 2070. Speaking at the event, Shri P.M. Prasad, Chairman, CIL, said that Coal India is shifting from being the country’s power supplier to becoming a key driver of India’s clean energy transition. "This agreement is a historic step in Coal India’s move toward sustainable growth. With this partnership with IIT Madras, Coal India wants to create homegrown solutions that keep energy safe, reduce carbon, and bring social progress," he added. Shri V. Kamakoti, Director, IIT Madras, said that industry‑academia partnerships have been a cornerstone of IIT Madras’s path to leading India’s shift to a low‑carbon economy. "The partnership with Coal India shows the institute’s commitment to this cause. Together, we want to create solutions that can grow and make a difference that support India’s sustainable energy future," he emphasized. The center will also help grow talent through Ph.D., postdoctoral, and internship programs, training the next generation of researchers and engineers to lead India’s green energy change.
announcements.original_title: Coal India & IIT Madras Join Hands to Establish Centre for Sustainable Energy
announcements.summary:
Coal India Limited (CIL) and IIT Madras are opening a new centre for clean energy research.
It will turn coal into useful resources, train scientists, and help India reach net-zero by 2070.

announcements.title: Three coal blocks sold in commercial auctions
announcements.content: The Ministry of Coal has issued Vesting Orders for three coal blocks from commercial auctions on October 23, 2025. The Coal Mine Development and Production Agreements (CMDPA) for these blocks were signed on August 21, 2025. The blocks with vesting orders are Rajgamar Dipside (Deavnara), Tangardihi North, and Mahuagarhi. Two blocks have been partly explored, while one block has been fully explored and has a peak capacity of ~1.00 MTPA. The combined geological reserves of these three blocks are ~1,484.41 MT. These blocks are expected to bring in an annual revenue of ~Rs. 189.77 crores and attract a capital investment of ~Rs. 150 crores. They will create jobs for ~1352 people, both directly and indirectly. In addition, vesting/allocation orders for 130 coal blocks have been issued under commercial auctions, with a total PRC of ~267.244 MTPA. This is expected to generate an annual revenue of ~Rs. 37,700 crores and provide jobs for ~3,61,301 people, both directly and indirectly. **** Shuhaib T
announcements.original_title: Vesting Orders Issued for 3 Coal Blocks Under Commercial Auctions
announcements.summary:
The Ministry of Coal announced that vesting orders were issued for three coal blocks—Rajgamar Dipside (Deavnara), Tangardihi North and Mahuagarhi—on October 23, 2025, after CMDPA signing on August 21, 2025.

announcements.content: Under Special Campaign 5.0, the Ministry of Coal and its PSUs are working to keep places clean, run better, and build a sustainable coal industry. From 2nd to 31st October 2025, many things were done. A total of 1,205 sites have been cleaned, covering 68,04,087 sq. ft., moving steadily toward the overall target of 82,51,511 sq. ft. The scrap target was 8,678 MT, and 5,813 MT of scrap was disposed of, generating a revenue of Rs. 22.87 crores. Before (NLCIL) After (NLCIL) 1,11,248 physical and 30,331 electronic files have been reviewed and 74,123 files were weeded out/closed. Before (CCL) After (CCL) Some of the best practices shown during Special Campaign 5.0 are: The historic "Tally Bungalow" at Bankola Area, Eastern Coalfields Limited, has been restored and turned into a Yoga and Recreation Centre. Built during the British era, the 80-year-old structure has been renovated carefully to preserve its architectural heritage. A Tamil awareness song with Hindi subtitles, composed by the Mine 1A team of NLCIL, creatively highlights the campaign’s key activities and objectives. Watch- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rAUrED9GBC4. Northern Coalfields Limited introduced a first-of-its-kind Vocational Training Portal on 30.09.25 with a comprehensive, end-to-end digital vocational training management and one-stop platform for seamless training, evaluation & certification of contractors’ employees. Till now 350 registrations have been completed. An unused space at Jayant Area, previously cluttered with scrap, has been transformed into a Music Room "JHANKAAR". This creative initiative encourages cultural expression and promotes holistic well-being among employees and their families and stands as a best practice at NCL. The newly developed Music Room serves as a platform where individuals from children to women, from budding learners to seasoned artists can explore, learn and express their love for music. Equipped with various musical instruments, this space fosters creativity, community bonding and a sense of joy among employees and their families. 5. Poetry & Speech Competition in MoC On 22.10.2025, the Ministry of Coal organized a Poetry and Speech Competition on the themes of "Swachhata" and "Swachh Bharat Mission". Eight winners were felicitated for their inspiring contributions as participants shared innovative ideas for advancing the Clean India movement. 6. Cyber Security Quiz Competition Ministry of Coal organized a Cyber Security Quiz Competition on 10.10.2025. The event witnessed enthusiastic employee participation, promoting awareness on safe and responsible digital conduct. The Ministry of Coal remains committed to the spirit of Special Campaign 5.0, ensuring sustained cleanliness, efficiency, and innovation in all its operations. The collective efforts of the Ministry and its PSUs reflect a strong resolve to align with the vision of Swachh Bharat promoting a cleaner, efficient, and future-ready coal sector. **** Shuhaib T

announcements.title: Network Planning Group reviews major infrastructure projects at 100th meeting
announcements.content:
The 100th meeting of the Network Planning Group (NPG) was held today to review road, transport and highway projects. The meeting focused on making transport easier and more efficient, following the PM GatiShakti National Master Plan (PMGS NMP).

NPG looked at 05 projects: 02 road/highway projects from MoRTH, 02 rail projects from MoR, and 01 metro rail project from MoHUA. The projects were checked for how well they follow PM GatiShakti rules: integrated multimodal infrastructure, last‑mile connection to economic and social hubs, and a ‘Whole of Government’ approach. These projects should improve logistics, cut travel time, and bring big social and economic benefits to the surrounding areas.

**Rail Projects**
- **Quadrupling Hosapete–Ballari (Karnataka)** – MoR wants a 65 km quadruple track. The corridor is very busy with iron ore, coal, steel and cement. The new track will ease congestion and add capacity for more freight and passengers.
- **Doubling Gondia–Jabalpur (Madhya Pradesh & Maharashtra)** – MoR plans a 230.5 km double track. The line passes through five districts and serves key farming, mining and industrial zones. It will reduce bottlenecks and speed up movement of goods like coal, steel and cement.

**Road Projects**
- **Widening NH‑921 Mahwa–Mandawar (Rajasthan)** – MoRTH proposes a 50.246 km upgrade from 4 lanes to a wider highway. It will link Rajasthan, Delhi NCR and Haryana, cut travel time, lower congestion and improve safety. It will also create jobs and help local communities.
- **Six‑lane elevated road Anisabad–Deedarganj (Bihar)** – MoRTH plans 13.37 km of six lanes, a grade road and a service road. Features include 4 light‑vehicle underpasses, 91 redesigned intersections, and 8 grade separators. The project will ease traffic, improve safety and support future growth.

**Metro Project**
- **Jaipur Metro Phase 2 (Prahladpura–Todi Mod, Rajasthan)** – MoHUA proposes a 42.8 km north‑south line with 36 stations (34 elevated, 2 underground). It connects important sites and links to the east‑west line at Chandpole. The line will reduce traffic, lower pollution and support nearby towns.

The meeting was chaired by Shri Pankaj Kumar, Joint Secretary, Logistics, DPIIT.

announcements.title: Government extends PLI application deadline to Nov 10, 2025
announcements.content: The Department for Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade (DPIIT) has extended the deadline for Round 4 of the Production Linked Incentive (PLI) Scheme for White Goods (Air Conditioners and LED Lights) to 10th November 2025. The original deadline for Round 4 was 15th September 2025 to 14th October 2025. It was extended because many companies responded and more investment is expected. This shows growing confidence and momentum in India’s domestic production of key parts for ACs and LED Lights under the PLI‑WG Scheme. Earlier rounds of the Scheme already attracted big investment commitments, boosting manufacturing capacity and jobs across the supply chain. The PLI Scheme for White Goods was launched in April 2021 with a total cost of ₹6,238 crore. It is designed to increase local manufacturing, encourage parts made in India, and make India more competitive globally in the air conditioner and LED lighting markets. Eligible applicants can submit proposals online via the PLI portal at https://pliwg.dpiit.gov.in in the “White Goods” section by 10th November 2025. *** Abhishek Dayal/ Abhijith Narayanan/

announcements.title: India trades strongly, partners with non-competitor countries
announcements.content: Union Minister of Commerce and Industry, Shri Piyush Goyal, said that India has changed a lot in recent years and now talks in trade deals from a strong position. He spoke at the 105th Annual General Meeting of ASSOCHAM in New Delhi. He said that India now works mainly with countries that are not competitors, so trade deals are fair and help both sides. This strategy protects our local industries, boosts exports, and opens chances for investment and technology sharing. It also avoids deals that would mainly help the other side. He mentioned that India’s foreign exchange reserves are still strong, about USD 700 billion, showing a healthy economy. He said that people, businesses, and industry in India now show new energy and confidence that we did not see a few years ago. The world now sees India as an important trade partner. He said that the days when India negotiated from a weak position are over. India’s passport now has respect and value worldwide. Shri Goyal said that while the world faces tough times, India keeps growing fast. He mentioned the IMF projection that raised India’s growth forecast from 6.4% to 6.6% and that retail inflation in September was the lowest in eight years at 1.54%. He said that India no longer signs unfair free trade agreements. The economy is ready for present and future challenges, guided by a clear vision and a nation‑first approach. He recalled the five principles (Panch Pran) the Prime Minister spoke about on 15 August 2022, which set the path to make India a developed country by 2047. He explained that the free trade agreements with Mauritius, Australia, the UAE, and the European Free Trade Association are a new chapter in India’s trade. These deals are balanced, keeping India’s priorities and long‑term goals first. These countries do not compete with India in key manufacturing sectors, so Indian businesses get better market access without unfair competition. The agreements open opportunities for exporters, bring high‑income markets, encourage investment, and allow advanced technology flows. They aim to promote industry collaboration, improve supply‑chain resilience, and help India become a global manufacturing hub. They also have strong rules for innovation, research, and skill development so Indian firms stay competitive. The government has protected India’s interests in these deals, especially in sensitive sectors. Through these trade pacts, India strengthens its position and promotes fair and sustainable growth. The government works to make India attractive for business by easing rules, simplifying processes, and reducing red tape. Shri Goyal said India is committed to sustainability, having already built 250 GW of renewable energy, 50% of the national grid. By 2030 India will reach 500 GW of clean energy, making it a top place for data centres and green investments. He highlighted that services are India’s core strength and expects service exports to soon exceed merchandise exports. The service sector creates jobs, drives the economy, and boosts demand for goods and services. The government is working with start‑ups that recycle waste for rare earths like loam and aldo, and plans to set up processing plants in India, a field currently concentrated in few places. He urged stakeholders to keep checking and strengthening their supply chains. Recent disruptions show the need for secure, diverse, self‑reliant networks. India must examine every link—from raw material to production and distribution—to cut dependence on a few areas and reduce risks. The government encourages industry to map supply chains and find ways to build domestic capacity. With public‑private cooperation, India can create strong value chains that meet domestic demand and serve the global trade system. This fits the “Aatmanirbhar Bharat” vision of self‑reliance and deeper integration into global value chains. Shri Goyal has spoken with many Export Promotion Councils and industry groups, urging them to strengthen supply chains with innovation, local manufacturing, and efficient logistics. He said India should build flexibility in trade systems to respond to future challenges. He said the MSME sector faces challenges and that groups like ASSOCHAM can help solve them. He praised ASSOCHAM for engaging start‑ups, MSMEs, and industries and being a key partner in policy dialogue, trade facilitation, and international cooperation. With resolve, teamwork, and commitment, India can keep overcoming challenges and move toward being a developed, self‑reliant nation by 2047.
announcements.original_title: India Engages in Trade from a Position of Strength, Focusing on Non-Competitor Nations for Balanced and Beneficial Partnerships: Union Minister of Commerce and Industry Shri Piyush Goyal
announcements.summary:
Shri Piyush Goyal said India now talks from a strong position, making fair trade deals that help local industries and boost exports.
India has strong reserves, low inflation, fast growth, and plans to build 250 GW of renewable energy, reaching 500 GW by 2030.

announcements.title: Commerce Minister Piyush Goyal to Visit Germany to Boost Trade Ties
announcements.content: Union Minister of Commerce & Industry, Shri Piyush Goyal, will visit Berlin (Germany) on 23 rd October 2025. The visit is an important step to strengthen India's ties with Germany and is especially meaningful because 2025 is the 25th anniversary of the India–Germany Strategic Partnership, showing how strong and long‑lasting our relationship is. Minister Goyal will meet senior government officials, business leaders, and trade groups in both countries. He will hold high‑level talks with Ms. Katherina Reiche, German Federal Minister for Economic Affairs & Energy, and Dr. Levin Holle, Economic and Financial Policy Advisor at the Federal Chancellery and Germany’s G7 & G20 Sherpa. The talks will focus on making the India‑Germany trade relationship stronger and finding new ways to increase trade and investment. He will also meet Mr. Xavier Bettel, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs and Trade of Luxembourg, to talk about boosting trade between the two countries, Luxembourg’s forthcoming State Visit to India, current regional events, and major global issues. As part of his trip, Shri Goyal will speak at the third Berlin Global Dialogue (BGD), an annual summit that brings together leaders from business, government, and academia to discuss issues that shape the global economy. He will take part in a panel session titled “Leaders' Dialogue: Growing Together – Trade and Alliances in a Changing World.” The panel will look at how countries and companies can adapt to a changing trade world, find practical ways to open markets, and build a new trading system that supports sustainable global growth. A major part of the visit will include one‑on‑one meetings with CEOs of top German companies such as Schaeffler Group, Renk Vehicle Mobility Solutions, Herrenknecht AG, Infineon Technologies AG, Enertrag SE, and Mercedes-Benz Group AG. He will also chair a roundtable with CEOs and leaders of German Mittelstandcompanies and meet with representatives of the Federation of German Industries (BDI) and the Asia-Pacific Association of German Business (APA). These meetings will help find synergies, support investment, and strengthen business links, especially in areas that focus on sustainability, innovation, and advanced manufacturing. This visit shows how India and its European partners are aligning their priorities, turning high‑level promises into lasting economic partnerships that boost innovation, resilience, and shared growth. ***** AD/AN/SA
announcements.original_title: Union Commerce and Industry Minister Shri Piyush Goyal to visit Germany to Strengthen Economic and Trade Partnership
announcements.summary:
Union Minister Piyush Goyal will visit Berlin on 23 rd October 2025 to strengthen ties with Germany.
He will meet officials, business leaders, and speak at the Berlin Global Dialogue to boost trade, investment and sustainable growth.

announcements.title: DPIIT starts Campaign 5.0 to make cleanliness a habit and cut backlogs
announcements.content: The Department for Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade (DPIIT) and its sub-organizations are working on Special Campaign 5.0 guided by the Department of Administrative Reforms and Public Grievances (DARPG). The campaign aims to make Swachhata a regular practice and reduce pending work in all offices. In the first two weeks of the implementation, DPIIT has made notable progress on many fronts. All types of pending references – from VIPs, the Prime Minister’s Office, MPs, State Governments, the Cabinet, and Public Grievances or Appeals – have been identified and are being dealt with systematically for proper disposal. As of 22nd October 2025, DPIIT has achieved remarkable progress under Special Campaign 5.0. Over 47% of PMO references and more than 60% of public grievances have been successfully disposed of. The Department has also closed over 75% of identified e‑files, showing a strong commitment to efficient record management. Additionally, 291 cleanliness campaigns – nearly 60% of the planned activities – have already been completed across DPIIT and its sub-organizations. These efforts show continuous action to promote Swachhata and improve workplace environments, making the experience better for officials and staff. Special Campaign 5.0, conducted from 2nd to 31st October 2025, followed a preparatory phase held between 15th and 30th September 2025. The campaign has increased awareness about the importance of cleanliness, efficient record management, and timely disposal of pending matters. DPIIT remains committed to fully disposing of pendencies and making Swachhata a routine practice in all its offices by 31st October 2025, contributing to a cleaner, more efficient, and responsive government working environment. *** Abhishek Dayal/ Abhijith Narayanan/ Ishita Biswas

announcements.title: DPIIT signs agreement with Primus Partners to boost startups
announcements.content: The Department for Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade (DPIIT), part of the Ministry of Commerce and Industry, has signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with Primus Partners Pvt Ltd. The aim is to improve cooperation and strengthen India's startup and innovation ecosystem. The partnership aims to give more help to early and growing product startups by providing training, expert guidance, ways to reach markets, awareness of policies, and support for using technology. On the day, Shri Sanjiv, Joint Secretary of DPIIT, said, “This partnership confirms DPIIT’s dedication to building an economy that is driven by innovation and relies on creativity, technology, and business.” Today, India's startup scene is on the brink of worldwide change. By improving connections between policies, businesses, and innovation, we want to create routes that let startups grow sustainably, create jobs, and help India become a leading global innovation hub. Shri Davinder Sandhu, Co-Founder and Chairman of Primus Partners, said the partnership with DPIIT would help startups through organized mentoring, sharing of knowledge, and connections with industries. He added that these efforts will help create a strong environment that encourages innovation and entrepreneurship. The MoU strengthens DPIIT’s focus on encouraging industry-led participation to boost India's startup ecosystem, supporting innovation, self-reliance, and inclusive growth. ***** AD/AN/SA'

announcements.title: DPIIT signs agreement with Kotak Mahindra Bank to support startups
announcements.content: The Department for Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade (DPIIT), part of the Ministry of Commerce and Industry of the Government of India, signed an agreement (MoU) with Kotak Mahindra Bank Ltd. to give better financial and non‑financial help to startups all over India. This partnership aims to build a framework that lets startups get tailored banking services, credit, funding, digital payment tools, and training. It shows DPIIT’s promise to grow an innovation‑driven economy and speed up India’s path to becoming a global startup hub. Under the MoU, Kotak Mahindra Bank will offer special services to DPIIT‑recognised startups, such as zero‑balance current accounts, working‑capital and term loans, API‑based banking platforms, digital payment solutions, and special startup cards. The bank will also help with mentorship, investment advice, incubation, and networking, so startups can move from ideas to growth. Shri Sanjiv, Joint Secretary of DPIIT, said: “This partnership shows DPIIT’s effort to build a lively and inclusive innovation ecosystem that gives startups the support they need at every step. By linking policy, industry, and finance, we want to strengthen the link between entrepreneurial dreams and lasting results, making sure India’s innovators have the right tools to grow worldwide.” Shri Raghavendra Singh, President of Kotak Mahindra Bank Ltd., said the partnership will help startups by giving tailored finance, mentorship, and connections that let founders expand effectively. The program will provide a flexible support system with banking, advice, technology, funding, and market connections. It is meant to help startups at all stages, from early ideas to market growth. By combining Kotak’s banking expertise with DPIIT’s policy guidance, this partnership will speed India’s move to a self‑sufficient, innovation‑led economy. ***** AD/AN/SA

announcements.title: BIRC 2025 will showcase India’s role in global rice supply
announcements.content:
The Department of Commerce, Ministry of Commerce & Industry, Government of India, announced that the Bharat International Rice Conference (BIRC) 2025 will take place at Bharat Mandapam, Pragati Maidan, New Delhi, on 30–31 October 2025.
The conference is a global platform that follows the Viksit Bharat @2047 vision. It will bring together producers, exporters, importers, policymakers, financiers, logisticians, research institutions, and other service providers to improve transparency, efficiency, and resilience in the global rice trade. The main topics will be sustainability, innovation, and rules‑based trade.
At the opening of BIRC 2025 in New Delhi, APEDA Chairman Shri Abhishek Dev said that the foreign ministers of the Philippines, Ghana, Namibia, and The Gambia will join the two‑day event. India is one of the world’s biggest rice producers and exporters, sending rice to more than 172 countries. BIRC 2025 gives stakeholders a chance to strengthen their role in global food supply chains. The conference is organized by the Indian Rice Exporters’ Federation (IREF), which represents more than 7,500 exporters in India, together with the Agricultural and Processed Food Products Export Development Authority (APEDA). APEDA is a statutory body under the APEDA Act, 1985, that promotes exports of about 800 agricultural products, including rice. The conference has support from many ministries, departments, and state governments.
Supporting institutions include the Ministry of Commerce & Industry, Ministry of Consumer Affairs, Food & Public Distribution, Ministry of Food Processing Industries, Ministry of Cooperation, and Ministry of Agriculture & Farmers Welfare. The states of Odisha, Telangana, Meghalaya, Assam, and Manipur also support the event. Other partners are the Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR) and cooperative groups like National Cooperative Exports Limited (NCEL), National Cooperative Organics Limited (NCOL), Bhartiya Beej Sahakarita Samiti Ltd. (BBSSL), and Krishak Bharati Cooperative Agri Limited (Kribhco).
More than 3,000 farmers and Farmer Producer Organisations (FPOs), more than 1,000 foreign buyers from over 80 countries, and 2,500 exporters, millers, and related businesses are expected to join. BIRC 2025 will launch a Vision & Roadmap document that gives detailed action plans for the rice sector, matching the Ministry’s long‑term policies. Stakeholders will meet in panel discussions with experts, policymakers, industry leaders, trade groups, and research institutes to shape the Vision & Action Plan. The final document will be prepared over the next six months using the results from technical sessions, consultations, and expert talks at the conference.
The Department of Commerce will coordinate the process with APEDA, IREF, partner ministries, and top research bodies like ICAR and the International Rice Research Institute (IRRI), plus major cooperative societies and state governments. Eight technical sessions will be held over the two days to build the Vision & Roadmap. Senior officials and top experts will chair the sessions.
India made about 150 million tonnes of rice in 2024–25 on almost 47 million hectares, about 28 percent of the world’s total. Yields rose from 2.72 tonnes per hectare in 2014–15 to about 3.2 tonnes per hectare in 2024–25, thanks to better seeds, better farming practices, and more irrigation.
In FY 2024–25, India exported 20.1 million metric tonnes of rice worth about USD 12.95 billion to over 172 countries. BIRC 2025 points out that rice is a key part of global food security. Since 1961, rice production has tripled from 216 million tonnes to almost 776 million tonnes. More than four billion people rely on rice for food and income, and about 150 million small farmers grow it in over 100 countries. The world rice market is worth about USD 330 billion and is the third biggest traded food item.
Rice farming uses a lot of resources, about 24–30 percent of global irrigation water and around 167 million hectares. The conference will discuss new ideas in farming, irrigation, certification, and traceability to make the sector more sustainable and cut its environmental impact. BIRC 2025 will have many themed activities and sessions.
A coffee‑table book that shows India’s rice heritage, including Basmati and non‑Basmati types, historic GI stories, farmer stories, and new ideas, will be launched. BIRC 2025 seeks to open ₹1.80 lakh crore worth of new import markets and sign ₹25,000 crore in export agreements. A Culinary Experience Zone, organized by IREF, APEDA, IRRI, and ITC Hotels, will let chefs show how Indian rice can be used in global dishes. Taste tests and buyer clinics will evaluate quality and preferences, and quick export registration will turn interest into trade agreements. The program shows that Indian rice is a genuine, high‑quality option for many cuisines, helping reach ₹1.80 lakh crore in markets and ₹25,000 crore in exports.

BIRC 2025 will have an AgriTech Pavilion that will launch and demo India’s first AI‑based sorting machine at Bharat Mandapam, Pragati Maidan, on 30–31 October 2025. This new system uses Artificial Intelligence and Big Data to look at colour, shape, size, and structure of rice grains all at once. It can sort by colour and separate broken grains in one step. The technology offers better accuracy, faster work, and lower cost, using less power, fewer workers, and less space.
A Women Entrepreneurs, Startups and MSME Pavilion will display new ideas for all parts of farming. It will show seed development, climate‑smart farming, post‑harvest tech, milling and colour grading, packaging and branding, quality checks using QR codes and blockchain, online markets, and financial products. The pavilion will have live demos, mentorship talks, and chances to start exporting for new businesses.
Pavilions from Jammu & Kashmir, Manipur, Telangana, Odisha, Meghalaya, Assam, Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Chhattisgarh, and Haryana will show their GI and special rice types, eco‑friendly farming, processing facilities, transport routes, investment opportunities, and ways to meet buyers.
Meghalaya’s government will join BIRC 2025 to show its traditional rice types like Pnah Iong (Black Sticky Rice), Mynri (Golden Rice of Ri‑Bhoi), Mangsang Rice, Minil, and Khaw Biriun. These are grown in eco‑friendly, rain‑fed ways, showing the state’s focus on organic farming.
Meghalaya’s role matches its State Rice Mission and the Integrated Basin Development and Livelihood Programme (IBDLP). These programs aim to raise crop output, add value, and improve market access for small farmers and protect native rice varieties.
Telangana will show how it has become a big centre for top‑quality rice exports. Good policies and new infrastructure help it. Paddy output grew from 68.17 lakh tonnes in 2014–15 to about 277.67 lakh tonnes in 2024–25, making Telangana important for India’s export farming. The state will talk business and display its best varieties, like Telangana Sona (RNR 15048), BPT 5204 (Samba Mahsuri), MTU 1010, and KNM 1638, for foreign buyers.
Bharat Organics, part of National Cooperative Organics Limited (NCOL), will launch its Organic Rice line and a Direct‑to‑Consumer platform at BIRC 2025. The line has two main types—Traditional Basmati and Traditional Brown Basmati—plus ten single‑origin varieties like Kala Namak (Uttar Pradesh), Indrayani (Maharashtra), Gobindobhog (West Bengal), Black Rice (Manipur), and Red Matta.
Bharat Organics wants to give certified, farmer‑direct, chemical‑free rice, while keeping trade fair, transparent, and helping small farmers get better markets.
The Directorate General of Foreign Trade (DGFT) will show its Trade Connect e‑Platform at the event. The site gives exporters one online place to get Certificates of Origin, tariff details for each country, listings of trade shows, product and market guides, and tools to link with overseas buyers and make personal microsites for better visibility.
BIRC 2025 will also sign an agreement to set up an Incubation and Agricultural Research Centre in New Delhi. The centre will work on sustainable and climate‑smart rice farming, researching seeds, growing, and post‑harvest care. Agreements will also help place agricultural graduates into research jobs, boosting innovation and jobs in farming research.
ICAR and IRRI will run a farmer training session at the event, teaching sustainable practices. The lesson will cover climate‑smart farming, efficient water use, and soil health to increase yield and protect the environment.
From now on, BIRC will be held every year as a leading platform for global interaction, policy talks, and cooperation in the rice chain. IRRI South Asia Regional Centre (IRRI‑SARC) in Varanasi is the research partner, and E&Y and S&P Global are knowledge partners.
Countries partnering in the event are the Philippines, Myanmar, Niger, Comoros, Jordan, Liberia, The Gambia, and Somalia. *** Abhishek Dayal/ Abhijith Narayanan/ Nihi Sharma/ Ishita Biswas

announcements.title: Posts department starts medicine delivery for ex‑soldiers health scheme
announcements.content: The Department of Posts (DoP) together with the Department of Ex-servicemen (DESW) has started a new service to make it easier to get medicines that are not available at ECHS polyclinics for Ex-Servicemen Contributory Health Scheme (ECHS). Under this program, medicines will be bought and packed by Village Level Entrepreneurs (VLEs) at the Common Service Centre (CSC) located at ECHS polyclinics. Delivery will be handled by India Post’s delivery network. This will ensure that medicines reach ECHS beneficiaries quickly, safely, and everywhere in the country. The service was first tested in Delhi on 31 July 2025 and received a positive response. It was then extended to the NCR area, covering Haryana and Uttar Pradesh. After the pilot delivered more than 1700 medicine packets, a full mapping of 458 ECHS locations across the country has been completed. The service will be available nationwide from 17 October 2025. This initiative shows how the Department of Posts uses its postal network for welfare projects and public service. The service will provide timely and reliable delivery of medicines to ECHS beneficiaries, confirming India Post’s role as a trusted partner in building the nation and helping citizens. ***** Samrat / Allen
announcements.original_title: Department of Posts Launches Medicine Delivery Service for Ex-Servicemen Contributory Health Scheme Beneficiaries
announcements.summary:
India Post and the Department of Ex-servicemen will now deliver medicines that are not found in ECHS polyclinics.
The service, tested in Delhi on 31 July 2025 and expanded to Haryana and Uttar Pradesh, will start nationwide from 17 October 2025, ensuring quick and safe delivery to all beneficiaries.

announcements.title: India's telecom sector rises under PM Modi's leadership
announcements.content:
Union Minister for Communications and Development of North Eastern Region, Shri Jyotiraditya M. Scindia, held a press conference today to talk about what the Ministry of Communications has achieved. He spoke about the Department of Telecommunications (DoT) and Department of Posts (DoP). Dr. Chandra Sekhar Pemmasani (Minister of State of Communications), Dr. Neeraj Mittal (Secretary of Department of Telecommunications) and Smt. Vandita Kaul (Secretary of Department of Posts) were also present.

In his opening, Mr. Scindia said India is no longer just a follower in telecom. He said, 'India has become a leader in telecom, in both services and products.' He added that the number of customers and the optical fibre network have grown many times. Internet and broadband connections have also increased a lot.

He said that if we look at scale, no one matches India. India would be the third largest digital nation if we count all digital use. The Prime Minister’s vision 11 years ago to create a digital highway is now a reality. He called BSNL’s turnaround one of the most impressive achievements. After 18 years BSNL made a profit, with ₹262 crore in Q3 and ₹280 crore in Q4 of FY2024‑25. BSNL’s EBITDA rose to ₹5,395 crore and losses dropped from ₹5,400 crore to ₹2,400 crore.

The country has also launched a fully indigenous 4G stack, a big breakthrough that puts India among a few countries that can build telecom technology from scratch. In the ‘100% telecom saturation’ mission, India has reached 75% of its goal in one year. Out of 17,000 towers planned, about 13,000 are already installed. In the district scheme, 81% coverage has been achieved. In Left‑Wing Extremism (LWE) areas, coverage went from 0% to 57% in Phase‑I and from 74% to 87% in Phase‑II. For island areas coverage improved from 38% to 84%.

To speed up projects, the ministry made a real‑time dashboard to track land, forest and security issues. Mr. Scindia also highlighted advances in telecom security. AI tools like ASTR have cut more than 82 lakh fake mobile connections, and the Financial Fraud Risk Indicator stopped scams worth almost ₹200 crore. ‘Google has joined this effort, which is a huge boost,’ he said. A unified Digital Intelligence Platform (DIP) now lets over 750 government and private groups share data, including all state governments, banks and police.

TRAI now reports service quality every month instead of every quarter. Operators must make tower maps public and meet targets such as less than 2% drop‑call rate and latency under 50 ms by April 2026. The ministry also set up a single‑window portal to speed right‑of‑way approvals, cutting the average time from 448 days in 2019 to just 33 days in 2025.

Mr. Scindia said the ministry is moving toward accountability and teamwork. ‘Every BSNL Chief General Manager is now a CEO of their area, setting and reviewing quarterly targets,’ he said. The DoT also held a ‘9‑to‑9’ marathon review meeting to check performance and share best practices. He said India’s telecom story is about transformation, resilience and leadership.

Secretary (T) Dr. Neeraj Mittal added that under Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s visionary leadership, the Department of Telecommunications has worked with the spirit of Samaveshit (inclusion), Tvarit (speed), Surakshit (security) and Viksit (development) to ensure that no citizen, village or enterprise is left behind in India’s digital journey. Mr. Scindia concluded that the ministry is committed to universal connectivity, indigenous innovation, citizen protection and global leadership. ‘Digital Bharat continues to inspire the world as a model of inclusive growth, with secure, self‑reliant and innovative telecom at its backbone,’ he said.

The past year has been extraordinary for @DoT_India, @IndiaPostOffice and @MDONER_India, marked by reforms, inclusive growth and new steps in service for every citizen of Bharat. Guided by the visionary leadership of Hon’ble PM Shri… pic.twitter.com/E6SG2NC5pb

announcements.title: Halfway results of Special Campaign 5.0 in Posts Department
announcements.content:
The Department of Posts, under the Ministry of Communications, has seen good progress up to the middle of Special Campaign 5.0, which is being carried out in all postal offices in the country.

The campaign’s goals are to make cleanliness a regular practice, cut backlogs, and improve record keeping. All levels of postal work – from head offices to branch offices, circles, regional and sorting offices – have joined enthusiastically.

• Cleanliness Drives: About 47,358 of 1,25,000 postal sites have been cleaned as part of Swachhata activities, making them cleaner, more organized, and easier for citizens.
• Dak Chaupals: These are community centers where citizens can access government services right at their doorstep, helping to reach the last mile and improve service delivery. So far, about 4,952 DakChaupals have been set up across the country.
• Removal of Pending Files: 32,249 physical files were examined; 7,611 were removed or closed, boosting office efficiency.
• Grievance Redressal: More than 57,961 pending complaints and appeals have been solved, showing the Department’s commitment to responsive governance.
• Space Management: About 13,049 sq. ft. of space were cleared by digitizing records and getting rid of outdated materials.
• Scrap Disposal Revenue: Selling useless items and scrap has earned ₹ 32,48,216.

Beautification: Post offices nationwide have put up bright wall art showing cleanliness, postal history, and public awareness. These artworks improve the look of the offices and help spread the Swachhata message to citizens and employees.

Circles also focus on making decorative items from waste as part of ‘Best out of Waste’, stressing recycling and upcycling.

The next half of the campaign will build on what has been achieved, keep cleanliness habits going, and reinforce accountability and efficiency in the Department of Posts.

***** SAMRAT/ALLEN
announcements.original_title: Momentum in Mission Mode: Midway Achievements of Special Campaign 5.0 in the Department of Posts
announcements.summary:
The Department of Posts has made good progress in Special Campaign 5.0, cleaning 47,358 of 1,25,000 post offices and setting up 4,952 DakChaupals across the country.
They have closed 7,611 files, solved 57,961 complaints, cleared 13,049 sq. ft. of space, and earned ₹ 32,48,216 from scrap disposal.

announcements.title: TRAI checks phone network quality in Agartala, Tripura
announcements.content:
TRAI released its Independent Drive Test (IDT) results for Assam (LSA). The tests covered many city routes in Agartala and nearby areas during August 2025. The tests were conducted under the supervision of the TRAI Regional Office, Kolkata, to measure real mobile network performance in different places such as cities, schools, offices, and rural homes. From 25th August 2025 to 29th August 2025, TRAI teams carried out detailed tests in Agartala and surrounding areas of Tripura. They covered 292.5 Km of city drive, 10 hotspot locations and 1.7 Km of walk test. They evaluated 2G, 3G, 4G, and 5G, showing what users experience on different phones. The findings have already been shared with all the TSPs.

Key Parameters Assessed: a) Voice Services: Call Setup Success Rate (CSSR), Drop Call Rate (DCR), Call Setup Time, Call Silence Rate, Speech Quality (MOS), Coverage. b) Data Services: Download/Upload Throughput, Latency, Jitter, Packet Drop Rate, Video Streaming Delay.

Overall mobile network performance in Agartala and nearby areas: Call Setup Success Rate – Airtel 97.77%, BSNL 83.23%, RJIL 95.20%, VIL 82.28% in Auto‑selection mode (5G/4G/3G/2G). Drop Call Rate – Airtel 0.91%, BSNL 5.83%, RJIL 0.00%, VIL 2.48% in Auto‑selection mode (5G/4G/3G/2G). 5G Data Services delivered a maximum average download speed of 209.52 Mbps and a maximum average upload speed of 22.09 Mbps in city drive.

Areas assessed include Mohanpur, Khowai, Chebri, Kalyanpur, Kamalnagar, Teliamura, Jirania, Gakulnagar, Bishalgarh, Kakraban, Udaipur, Jampuijala and Shyamnagar. TRAI also evaluated real‑world conditions at: (i) District and Sessions Judge Court Agartala, (ii) Khowai Hospital Chowmuhani Khowai, (iii) Maharaja Bir Bikram College Agartala, (iv) Neermahal Rudijala, (v) Netaji Subhash Mahavidyalaya Udaipur Dhwajnagar, (vi) Secretariat Complex, (vii) Teliamura Higher Secondary School Karailong, (viii) Tripura University Agartala, (ix) Tripurasundari Shaktipeeth Agartala, and (x) Ujjayanta Palace through static testing. Walk‑tests were carried out at (i) Agartala City Centre, (ii) Agartala Railway Station, and (iii) ILS Hospitals Agartala.

Performance against key QoS parameters: CSSR – Call Setup Success Rate (%), CST – Call Setup Time (seconds), DCR – Drop Call Rate (%), MOS – Mean Opinion Score.

Voice services summary: Call Setup Success Rate – Airtel 97.77%, BSNL 83.23%, RJIL 95.20%, VIL 82.28% in Auto‑selection mode (5G/4G/3G/2G). Call Setup Time – Airtel 2.46s, BSNL 2.84s, RJIL 0.73s, VIL 1.51s in Auto‑selection mode (5G/4G/3G/2G). Drop Call Rate – Airtel 0.91%, BSNL 5.83%, RJIL 0.00%, VIL 2.48% in Auto‑selection mode (5G/4G/3G/2G). Call Silence/Mute Rate – Airtel 2.70%, BSNL 1.66%, RJIL 3.42%, VIL 1.58% in packet‑switched network (5G/4G). MOS – Airtel 4.02, BSNL 2.72, RJIL 3.86, VIL 4.58.

Data services summary: Overall download speed – Airtel (5G/4G/2G) 116.89 Mbps, BSNL (4G/3G/2G) 0.89 Mbps, RJIL (5G/4G) 209.52 Mbps, VIL (4G/2G) 23.17 Mbps. Overall upload speed – Airtel (5G/4G/2G) 22.09 Mbps, BSNL (4G/3G/2G) 2.62 Mbps, RJIL (5G/4G) 14.72 Mbps, VIL (4G/2G) 8.00 Mbps. 50th percentile latency – Airtel 28.60 ms, BSNL 86.00 ms, RJIL 21.60 ms, VIL 47.85 ms. Hotspot data performance (Mbps): Airtel – 4G D/L 25.03, 4G U/L 13.36, 5G D/L 143.425, 5G U/L 40.93; BSNL – 4G D/L 0.574, 4G U/L 3.11; RJIL – 4G D/L 21.994, 4G U/L 6.89, 5G D/L 209.40, 5G U/L 13.78; VIL – 4G D/L 24.54, 4G U/L 9.50. Note: “D/L” Download speed, “U/L” Upload speed.

The tests used TRAI‑recommended equipment and standardised protocols in real‑time environments. The detailed report is available on the TRAI website www.trai.gov.in. For any clarification or information, contact Shri Kaushik Mukherjee, Advisor (Regional Office, Kolkata) TRAI via email adv.kolkata@trai.gov.in or phone +91-33-22361401. ***** Samrat/Allen

announcements.title: TRAI checks phone network quality in Silchar, Hailakandi, Karimganj, Assam
announcements.content:
The Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (TRAI) published the results of its Independent Drive Test (IDT) for Assam (LSA). The test covered many city routes in Silchar city, Hailakandi and Karimganj districts, and nearby areas during August 2025. The tests were carried out under the supervision of the TRAI Regional Office in Kolkata, and they were meant to record how well mobile networks work in real life. They looked at different places such as urban areas, school and college sites, and rural homes.

From 18 to 22 August 2025, TRAI teams performed detailed tests across Silchar city, Hailakandi and Karimganj districts and the surrounding areas. They covered 284.1 Km of city drive test, 10 hotspot locations, and 2.4 Km of walk test. They checked 2G, 3G, 4G and 5G services, showing how users experience the network on different phones.

The IDT results were already shared with all the telecom service providers (TSPs). The main items checked were:

a) Voice services: Call Setup Success Rate (CSSR), Drop Call Rate (DCR), Call Setup Time, Call Silence Rate, Speech Quality (MOS), Coverage.

b) Data services: Download/Upload Throughput, Latency, Jitter, Packet Drop Rate, Video Streaming Delay.

announcements.title: TEC signs agreement with IIT Hyderabad for telecom research and standards
announcements.content: The Telecommunication Engineering Centre (TEC), which is the technical part of the Department of Telecommunications (DoT) of the Government of India, has signed an agreement (MoU) with the Indian Institute of Technology Hyderabad (IIT Hyderabad) to work together on studies, research, and technical input in advanced telecom technologies and global standardization. The partnership will create India-only standards and test methods, look into future network tech like 6G, AI, and Non-Terrestrial Networks (NTNs), and boost India’s role in ITU-T Study Groups. The MoU was signed on 24th October 2025 by Shri Amit Kumar Srivastava, DDG (Mobile Technologies), TEC and Prof. Budaraju Srinivasa Murty, Director, IITH, in front of Shri Syed Tausif Abbas, Sr. DDG and Head (TEC) and Prof. Kiran Kumar Kuchi, IITH, at IIT Hyderabad. This partnership gives a formal plan for TEC to work closely with IIT Hyderabad on next-gen telecom and standardization. Key Areas of Collaboration: The partnership will speed up homegrown R&D and make India more influential in global standardization by boosting its work with bodies like ITU and 3GPP. It will support the Atmanirbhar Bharat goal by enhancing local research, design and manufacturing in telecom—creating India-only standards, test methods and local solutions that increase self-reliance, protect vital communications, and cut reliance on imports. About TEC: TEC is the technical part of the Department of Telecommunications (DoT), Government of India. It creates standards, specifications, and rules for testing telecom equipment and networks in India, making sure they work together, are high quality, and follow global best practices. TEC represents India at international meetings like the ITU-T and ITU-R and leads National Working Groups for global standardization. About IIT Hyderabad: IIT Hyderabad, founded in 2008, is a top national institute known for strong teaching and research in advanced telecom, 5G/6G, AI in telecom, and new ICT areas. announcements.title: TEC signs agreement with IIIT Hyderabad for telecom research and standards
announcements.content:
The Telecommunication Engineering Centre (TEC), the technical part of the Department of Telecommunications (DoT) in India, has signed an agreement with the International Institute of Information Technology, Hyderabad (IIIT-Hyderabad) to do joint technical studies and research.

The partnership will create India-specific rules and testing methods, look at future network technologies like Artificial Intelligence (AI), Cyber Security, Smart Cities, and Quantum Communications, and help India add more to ITU-T Study Groups.

The agreement was signed on 24 October 2025 by Shri Amit Kumar Srivastava, DDG (Mobile Technologies) from TEC, and Prof. Sandeep Shukla, Director of IIIT-Hyderabad, in front of Shri Syed Tausif Abbas, Senior DDG and Head (TEC), and senior officials of IIIT-Hyderabad.

This agreement sets up a formal plan for TEC and IIIT-Hyderabad to work closely on new telecom tech and standardization.

Key areas: the partnership will speed up local R&D and boost India's influence in global standardization by strengthening its work with bodies like ITU and 3GPP.

It will also support Atmanirbhar Bharat by improving local research, design, and manufacturing in telecom, creating India-specific standards, testing methods, and home-made solutions that increase self-reliance, protect key communication systems, and cut dependence on imports.

About TEC: The Telecommunication Engineering Centre (TEC) is the technical part of the Department of Telecommunications (DoT) in India. TEC makes rules, specifications, and checks that telecom gear and networks in India meet standards. It ensures they work together, are good quality, and follow global best practices. TEC represents India at places like ITU-T, ITU-R and leads National Working Groups for global standardization.

About IIIT-Hyderabad: The International Institute of Information Technology (IIIT-Hyderabad) is a top national institute with strong academics and research in advanced telecom, 5G/6G, AI in telecom, and new ICT fields. announcements.title: DoT holds cyber security webinar to boost telecom resilience
announcements.content: The Department of Telecommunications (DoT) is marking October as National Cyber Security Awareness Month. To support the campaign, the Director General Telecom (DGT HQ), DoT, held an informative webinar on 24th October 2025 to build a culture of cyber awareness and resilience online. The webinar gathered experts and professionals from the telecom sector to discuss new cyber threats, governance problems, and ways to make organisations resistant to phishing. The event was attended by Ms. Sunita Chandra, Director General Telecom, Sh. Suresh Puri, Additional Director General, DGT HQ, and other senior officers from DGT HQ and DoT HQ. About 250 people from DoT field units, Telecom Service Providers, and Internet Service Providers joined the webinar, showing strong interest in the telecom community. DG Telecom stressed that everyone must take responsibility and be aware to keep cyberspace safe, and the Addl. DG updated participants on the progress of setting up the Telecom-CSIRT and the readiness of DoT field units. Cyber Security Expert Dr. Rohit Gautam noted that phishing is still the most common and harmful cyberattack, making up almost 90% of breaches worldwide. He explained that attacks that target people, like phishing, vishing, and deepfake frauds, keep taking advantage of user trust and cost more than $9.5 trillion each year worldwide. Key lessons were how to spot social engineering attacks, recognise suspicious messages, and see real examples of homograph and AI-powered phishing. Industry Expert Sh. Abhijit Tripathy explained that Governance, Risk, and Compliance (GRC) is the foundation of an organisation’s cyber resilience. He simplified GRC ideas and showed how people, processes, and technology can work together to improve security. Cyber Security Expert Sh. Sampat Ray talked about new mobile cyber threats and phishing. He pointed out the rapid growth of AI-enabled malware, fake mobile apps, and voice phishing (vishing) scams that hit people and businesses. He also explained the rise of advanced phishing using deepfake audio and AI messages and shared ways to stop these threats. The webinar clearly showed how collective responsibility, smart decisions, and constant vigilance are needed to protect the country’s telecom infrastructure. announcements.title: Pause new telecom license applications while new rules start
announcements.content: The Telecommunications Act, 2023 was published in the Official Gazette of India on 24.12.2023. It will start on a date decided by the Central Government through a notice in the Official Gazette; different parts of the Act may start on different dates. Section 3 authorises the provision of telecom services and the setting up, running, maintenance or expansion of telecom networks. These authorisations will replace the old licensing system (Unified License, Unified License(VNO), Standalone Licenses, Registrations, Permissions and No Objection Certificate) once the rules under Section 3 are announced. Because we are switching to this new authorisation system, there may be some uncertainties and difficulties with new applications. To manage this, we have decided to pause new applications for Unified License, Unified License(VNO), Standalone Licenses, Registrations, Permissions and No Objection Certificate from 10.11.2025 until the authorisation rules are notified. Applications already submitted before that date will still be processed. announcements.title: If Vegetable Oil Rules are Ignored, Strict Action Will Follow
announcements.content: The Department of Food and Public Distribution, under the Ministry of Consumer Affairs, Food & Public Distribution, has announced a major change to the Vegetable Oil Products, Production and Availability (Regulation) Order, 2011 (VOPPA Order). The new VOPPA Order, 2025 is meant to give better control and more openness in India’s edible oil sector. Under the new order, all companies that produce, process, blend, re-pack, or otherwise deal with edible oil must register with the VOPPA Order and submit monthly reports of their production and stock through the special online portal. This rule change is essential to collect accurate data, monitor the market in real time, and improve policy decisions. It supports the Government of India’s effort for food security and stronger supply chains. The response from the edible oil industry is encouraging. Many oil units across the country have already signed up on the National Single Window System portal and are regularly sending their monthly returns at https://www.edibleoilindia.in. This shows that industry players are committed to transparency and compliance. All units that produce, process, blend or re-pack edible oil must do the following under the new VOPPA Order: - Register through the National Single Window System at https://www.nsws.gov.in. - Then file monthly production, stock, and availability returns at https://www.edibleoilindia.in. If a unit does not register or submit returns, it will be treated as a violation. Those units will face penalties under the new VOPPA Order and the Collection of Statistics Act, 2008. To enforce this, the Department plans to carry out inspections and verify non-compliant units on the field. These checks will show the seriousness of compliance and keep the national data system reliable for the edible oil sector. Compliance with the new order is not just a rule—it is a critical part of India’s food security system. The initiative helps better planning, informed decisions, and creates a smoother and clearer edible oil market. The Department urges all stakeholders to comply as soon as possible and to help build a strong, reliable, data-driven edible oil sector in the country. Useful Links To Get Registration: https://www.nsws.gov.in To File Monthly Returns: https://www.edibleoilindia. ******* Nihi Sharma
