announcements.title: J&K Lieutenant Governor goes to Russia to bring back Buddha relics
announcements.content:
Jammu and Kashmir Lieutenant Governor Shri Manoj Sinha said that showing the Holy Relics of Lord Buddha in Kalmykia will make people from India and Russia feel closer. After paying respect to the relics at the famous Geden Sheddup Choikorling Monastery, called the "Golden Abode of Shakyamuni Buddha," he said that this event is a big return of faith for the Kalmyk people, the only Buddhist nation in Europe. It shows a strong spiritual friendship between India and Russia and highlights India’s cultural ties.

He gave a "Khatak" to the relics and lit a lamp in the temple. He also offered prayers and presented a "Khatak" before Bakula Rinpoche. He gave a Kashmiri shawl to Shajin Lama and received blessings.

On Friday, the Lieutenant Governor arrived in Russia to bring the relics back to India after their show in Elista, the capital of the Republic of Kalmykia. He was welcomed by Tserenov Erdni Nikolayevich, the First Deputy Chairman of the Government of Kalmykia, Dzhambinov Ochir Vladimirovich, and India’s Deputy Chief of Mission Shri Nikhilesh Giri. The group will bring the relics back to India on October 19th 2025.

Earlier, he announced his trip to Kalmykia, saying he would lead the team to return the holy relics. He posted on X: "Leaving for Kalmykia, Russia, where I will lead the delegation to bring back holy relics of Lord Buddha after a week‑long exhibition. I sincerely thank Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi for this sacred opportunity. ‘Om Mamo Buddhaya’.

The exhibition of the sacred relics has attracted an unprecedented response in Kalmykia. Over Ninety Thousand devotees have visited the relics at the Geden Sheddup Choikorling Monastery. The relics, a National Treasure of India, were brought to Elista by a high‑level delegation led by Shri Keshav Prasad Maurya, Deputy Chief Minister of Uttar Pradesh, and senior Indian monks. The delegation has held special prayers and blessings for Kalmykia’s largely Buddhist community.

This first‑ever exhibition in the Russian Republic shows the deep cultural bond between India and Russia and revives the legacy of 19th‑century Buddhist monk and diplomat Kushok Bakula Rinpoche, who helped bring Buddhism back to Mongolia and interest in the Buddha’s teachings in places like Kalmykia, Buryatia, and Tuva.

The event is organized by the BTI section of the Ministry of Culture, Government of India, with the International Buddhist Confederation (IBC), the National Museum, and the Indira Gandhi National Centre for the Arts (IGNCA). The exhibition will run in Elista until October 18, 2025.

*** Sunil Kumar Tiwari pibculture[at]gmail[dot]com

announcements.title: CGDA runs 214th Defence Accounts outreach in Kerala
announcements.content: Controller of Defence Accounts (CGDA), Chennai held the 214th SPARSH Outreach Programme of the Defence Accounts Department in Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala on 16th October 2025. Governor of Kerala, Shri Rajendra Vishwanath Arlekar, opened the event. More than 1100 defence veterans and family pensioners from Thiruvananthapuram and nearby districts came to the programme. At the event, the Governor gave cheques worth Rs 40 lakh to five defence pensioners and family pensioners whose complaints were solved through SPARSH. He also honoured six Veer Naris whose husbands made the supreme sacrifice on duty. In his speech, the Governor praised the sacrifices of the Veer Naris and called them VEER MATHAS. He congratulated the Defence Accounts Department for opening SPARSH Service Centres in 12 of the 14 districts in Kerala. He urged the Department to open two more SPARSH Service Centres in Idukki and Malappuram so the state has full coverage. He praised the work of CDA Chennai in setting up thirty help desks with CGDA headquarters, PCDA (Pensions) Prayagraj, eight Record Offices, four Banks and other agencies to help defence pensioners and family pensioners with SPARSH issues. Shri Raj Kumar Arora, Controller General of Defence Accounts, New Delhi, and Shri T. Jayaseelan, Controller of Defence Accounts, Chennai attended the occasion. In his address, Shri Raj Kumar Arora said that the SPARSH outreach programmes are held across the country to resolve as many complaints as possible and to provide pension services directly to pensioners. He noted that CGDA paid the One Rank One Pension (OROP) 3 arrears of more than Rs 1200 crores to more than 20 lakh defence pensioners and family pensioners in just 15 days. *** SR/PC

announcements.title: Defence Secretary calls for public-private industrial policy
announcements.content: Defence Secretary Shri Rajesh Kumar Singh said a clear policy plan is needed to strengthen India’s domestic industry by working together between the government and private companies. He gave the opening speech at the ‘Strategic Insight Conference on Indigenous Development of Critical Technologies for Air Power’ organized by the Centre for Aerospace Power and Strategic Studies (CAPSS) in New Delhi on October 17, 2025. The Secretary said that making the industry more diverse will end monopolies, make business easier, and boost innovation across the sector. He repeated the government’s firm commitment to Aatmanirbharta in defence, stressing the importance of developing advanced aircraft technologies, field tests, and long-range air-to-air missiles to make India’s air power stronger. In his special address, Vice Chief of the Air Staff Air Marshal Narmdeshwar Tiwari pointed out how air power helped achieve results, as seen in Operation Sindoor. He said that besides designing and building Indian aircraft, India must also focus on becoming expert in electronic warfare, advanced sensors, radars, and data links. In her keynote, Director General of AERO, DRDO Dr K Rajalakshmi Menon talked about how UAVs, multi-sensor fusion, and artificial intelligence can change air operations. She mentioned progress in stealth tech, aerostats, and airships with better sensors, and how quantum, photonic, and blockchain tech are being added to defence systems. DG of CAPSS, Air Vice Marshal (Retd) Anil Golani highlighted how Aatmanirbharta matters in a changing security environment and growing tech competition nearby. He stressed using AI, advanced avionics, and next-gen propulsion, and said that developing smart control propulsion, super-cruise capability, and fly-by-light systems will shape India’s future aerospace dominance. During the event, the Defence Secretary released a book titled ‘Asian Defence Review 2025: Geo-political Shifts and Strategic Partnership Multilateralism in the Indo-Pacific’. Several technical sessions were held on joint jet engine development, fighter aircraft programmes, unmanned systems, and strengthening the aerospace production ecosystem. Senior officials from the Ministry of Defence, the Indian Air Force, DRDO, and industry leaders gathered to discuss India’s path to technological self-reliance in aerospace and defence. *** SR/Savvy
announcements.original_title: Need for a structured policy framework to strengthen India’s domestic industrial base through balanced synergy between public & private sectors: Defence Secretary
announcements.summary:
Defence Secretary Rajesh Kumar Singh said India needs a clear plan with the government and private companies to strengthen domestic industry.
He highlighted the importance of self-reliance in aircraft, sensors and advanced tech to boost India’s air power.

announcements.title: Sixth ASW SWC launched by 528 (Magdala) at CSL Kochi
announcements.content: BY 528 (Magdala), the sixth ship in a group of eight Anti‑Submarine Warfare Shallow Water Crafts, was launched on 18 Oct 2025 at Cochin Shipyard Limited in Kochi. Following naval tradition, Mrs. Renu Rajaram launched the ship in front of Vice Admiral Rajaram Swaminathan, the Controller of Warship Production and Acquisition, and other senior officers from the Indian Navy and CSL. The ship was designed and built in India by Cochin Shipyard Limited. The first ship is expected to be delivered by the end of October 2025. ASW SWCs will improve underwater awareness, anti‑submarine warfare, and mine‑laying abilities. The ships use three diesel‑engine powered waterjets. They carry important sensors like a hull‑mounted sonar and a low‑frequency variable depth sonar. They also have modern weapons, including torpedoes, anti‑submarine rockets, an NSG‑30 gun, and a 12.7 mm SRCG. Launching Magdala is an important step in the Indian Navy’s effort to become self‑reliant in shipbuilding, weapons, sensors, and advanced communications and electronic warfare. With over 80% of its parts made locally, the ship will give the Indian Navy strong tools to protect the country’s maritime interests in the Indian Ocean. ______________________________________________ VM/SPS 221/25

announcements.title: Lt Gen CG Muralidharan starts as Army Medical Services Director General
announcements.content: Lt Gen CG Muralidharan has become the Director General of Medical Services (Army), replacing Lt Gen Sadhna S Nair, AVSM, VSM, who retired on 30 September 2025 after more than four decades of distinguished service to the nation. Lt Gen Muralidharan graduated from the well‑known Armed Forces Medical College (AFMC) in Pune and joined the Army Medical Corps in 1987. A noted radiologist, he has had a distinguished career that balanced command, staff, and teaching roles. He has worked at many medical levels in the Northern and Western regions, gaining valuable operational and administrative experience in different settings. As the head of the Army Medical Services, Lt Gen Muralidharan will focus on ensuring comprehensive medical care for active soldiers, veterans, and their families. He will strengthen the readiness of frontline medical units amid changing security threats, new technology, and the evolving nature of modern war. Under his leadership, the Army Medical Corps will keep its strong promise to provide world‑class healthcare to the Armed Forces community, following its noble motto — “Sarve Santu Niramayah” — which means health and wellbeing for all. **** SR/NIRMIT

announcements.title: Defence Minister honors 10 police heroes who died in 1959 Ladakh ambush
announcements.content: The Defence Minister Shri Rajnath Singh will lay a wreath at the National Police Memorial in New Delhi on October 21, 2025, on Police Commemoration Day. On October 21, 1959, ten brave policemen gave their lives in an ambush by heavily armed Chinese troops in Hot Springs, Ladakh. Since then, October 21 has been observed as Police Commemoration Day every year. A joint parade of the Central Armed Police Forces (CAPFs) and Delhi Police will be held as part of the event. The Defence Minister, the Union Home Minister, MPs with police background, heads of CAPFs/CPOs, and others will also lay wreaths. Retired DGs, police officers and other dignitaries will also attend. The Defence Minister will also speak. In recognition of the sacrifices made by police and their key role in protecting national security, Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi dedicated the National Police Memorial at Chanakyapuri, New Delhi to the nation on Police Commemoration Day 2018. The museum is a historical and evolving exhibition on policing in India. It is open to the public every day except Monday. CAPFs organise band display, parade, and retreat ceremony at the National Police Memorial every Saturday and Sunday evening, starting one hour before sunset. The Memorial gives police forces a sense of national identity, pride, unity of purpose, common history, and destiny, and reinforces their commitment to protect the nation even at the cost of their lives. It includes a Central Sculpture, a Wall of Valour, and a museum. The Central Sculpture, a 30‑foot tall granite cenotaph, symbolizes strength, resilience, and self‑less service of police. The Wall of Valour lists the names of martyrs and acknowledges the bravery and sacrifice of police who have died in duty since Independence. As part of the remembrances, CAPFs/CPOs organize various commemorative events at the National Police Memorial from October 22 to 30, including visits by families of the fallen, police band display, motorcycle rallies, run for martyrs, blood donation camps, essay and painting competitions for children, and videos showing the sacrifice, courage, and services of police. Similar programmes are organized by all police forces across the country during this period. ******* VK/Savvy
announcements.original_title: Police Commemoration Day: Raksha Mantri to lay a wreath at NPM & pay homage to 10 valiant policemen who laid down their lives in an ambush laid by heavily armed Chinese troops at Hot Springs, Ladakh in 1959
announcements.summary:
The Defence Minister Shri Rajnath Singh will lay a wreath at the National Police Memorial on Police Commemoration Day, October 21, 2025.
A joint parade of police forces and a wreath-laying ceremony will honor the 10 brave policemen who died on October 21, 1959 and celebrate the sacrifices of police.

announcements.title: Defence Minister dedicates titanium and superalloy plant at PTC Lucknow
announcements.content:
"India must produce rare materials used in defence and aerospace to become a technology creator and safeguard its technological sovereignty," said Defence Minister Shri Rajnath Singh. He dedicated a Titanium and Superalloy Materials Plant at PTC Industries’ Strategic Materials Technology Complex in Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh on October 18, 2025.

He highlighted that Rare Earth Materials are essential for defence, space, electronics and other sectors, and only a few countries can refine them into high‑end products. The newly opened plant, one of the first private‑sector units to make aero‑engine parts and super‑alloy components, will help India produce these rare materials.

The Minister noted that India previously depended on other countries for advanced materials and critical technologies needed for defence and aerospace, which slowed the sector’s growth. The new plant marks a change in this trend. He added that India’s true strength comes when it can make its own materials, components, chips and alloys. The plant places India among a select group of nations that can produce their own critical defence and aerospace materials.

"With this, we can manufacture parts used in our fighter jets, missiles, naval systems and satellites," he said.

He stressed that while technology is power, material is the real strength. Whether it is a semiconductor chip, bullet material or engine turbine part, none is possible without strategic materials.

"We are building a foundation that will strengthen India’s technological independence in the coming years," he added.

Calling the plant a living example of Aatmanirbhar Bharat, he said it will benefit not only the industry but society as a whole. It creates an innovation chain that will achieve the goal of Aatmanirbhar Bharat in the defence sector and give fresh momentum to the state economy.

On the Complex, he expressed confidence that it adds a new dimension to Uttar Pradesh’s industrial map. The complex, with ancillary units and supplier industries, will create direct and indirect jobs in the state. He added that the UP Defence Industrial Corridor will be among the most advanced manufacturing zones in Asia, linking to start‑ups and MSMEs, providing jobs for youth and opportunities for training.

He praised Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath for the state’s progress in becoming an industrial leader over the last 10 years. Improved law and order has boosted investor confidence and factories, IT hubs and research centres are being set up, making the state the country’s growth engine.

Hailing India’s changed mindset, he said, "We are entering a new era and have moved beyond Make‑in‑India to Design, Develop and Deliver in India." He highlighted the private sector’s role in defence production and research, saying any goal is possible if industry and government work together.

He called on youth, innovators, MSMEs and start‑ups to seize opportunities in the defence sector as a responsibility to the nation. The current work will inspire a new generation of innovators.

He recognised progress in public‑private partnership in defence manufacturing and promised government policy support and cooperation to stakeholders in India’s defence and aerospace sector. He urged all stakeholders to pursue the goal of making India a global defence manufacturing hub through innovation, dedication and passion.

Earlier, he toured the Complex with Yogi Adityanath, Deputy Chief Minister Brajesh Pathak, Secretary of the Department of Defence R&D, Chairman DRDO Dr Samir V Kamat and DG (BrahMos) Dr Jaytirth R Joshi. The dignitaries were briefed on the facilities by PTC Industries’ Chairman and Managing Director Shri Sachin Agarwal.

An MoU was signed between PTC Industries Limited and Bharat Dynamics Limited to form a joint venture for design, development and manufacture of propulsion systems, guided bombs and small aeroengines for missiles, UAVs and loitering munitions. The collaboration aims to use both organisations’ strengths and accelerate indigenisation of advanced propulsion technologies, reducing import dependence and strengthening India’s defence manufacturing base.

PTC Industries received a Letter of Technical Acceptance from the Centre for Military Airworthiness and Certification under DRDO for the indigenous development and manufacture of the Titanium Rear Fin Root Casting for the Advanced Medium Combat Aircraft program. Developed with the Defence Metallurgical Research Laboratory and the Aeronautical Development Agency, this marks a critical step in India’s ability to produce structural castings for next‑generation fighter aircraft.

PTC Industries also received a Letter of Technical Acceptance for the indigenous development and manufacture of Oil Tank Assembly Titanium Castings for the Kaveri Derivative Engine. This will be executed with the Gas Turbine Research Establishment.

Furthering its collaboration with GTRE, PTC Industries received a Purchase Order for Post‑Cast Operations to produce Single Crystal Ready‑to‑Fit Turbine Blades for the Kaveri Derivative Engine. This marks an important step in India’s capability to produce single‑crystal turbine blades, a complex and high‑value component in modern jet engines.

Spread over 50 acres, the Strategic Materials Technology Complex was built with an investment of Rs 1,000 crore. With a production capacity of over 6,000 tonnes per annum, the plant enables India to produce aviation‑grade Titanium and Superalloys from domestic and recycled sources – a decisive move toward strategic material independence.
****** VK/SPS/Savvy
announcements.original_title: Raksha Mantri dedicates to the nation Titanium & Superalloy Materials Plant at PTC Industries’ Strategic Materials Technology Complex in Lucknow
announcements.summary:
India will now make its own rare defence and aerospace materials so it can build parts for fighter jets and missiles without buying from abroad.
The new PTC Industries plant in Lucknow will help keep India’s technology safe and strong.

announcements.title: Defence Minister and UP Chief Minister launch first BrahMos missiles in Lucknow
announcements.content:
Raksha Mantri Shri Rajnath Singh and Uttar Pradesh Chief Minister Shri Yogi Adityanath, on October 18, 2025, started the first batch of BrahMos missiles made at the BrahMos Integration and Testing Facility Centre in Lucknow. The new facility, part of the UP Defence Industrial Corridor, was opened virtually by Raksha Mantri on May 11, 2025, and in five months the first missiles were ready to use. He said BrahMos is more than a missile; it shows India’s growing ability to make its own defence tools. The missile has a traditional warhead and a modern guided system and can travel long distances at supersonic speed. Its speed, accuracy and power make it one of the best systems in the world. It is now a key part of our Armed Forces. He also spoke about BrahMos in Operation Sindoor, saying the missile has proven it is not just a test but a strong proof of national security. Every part of Pakistan’s land can now be reached by BrahMos. Operation Sindoor shows we can win every time, and we must keep improving. The operation was only a preview. It has shown Pakistan what may come next.

Raksha Mantri said India is now stronger in security and shows the world it is a reliable partner in defence and technology. Achievements like BrahMos prove that Made-in-India is more than a slogan; it is a global brand. Whether we export BrahMos to the Philippines or help other countries, India is now a giver, not just a taker. This is the real spirit of Aatmanirbhar Bharat, a vision that the Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi-led Government started in 2014. PM Modi has shown us a vision of an India that is fully developed, self-reliant and ready to lead the world by 2047. Defence will play a key role.

Shri Rajnath Singh told us that the BrahMos team has signed contracts worth about Rs 4,000 crore with two countries in the last month. He added that in coming years experts from many countries will visit Lucknow, making the city a knowledge hub and leader in defence technology. The Lucknow unit of BrahMos will turnover about Rs 3,000 crore next year and collect about Rs 500 crore in GST.

The 200-acre facility was built for Rs 380 crore. Raksha Mantri said it is not just a defence plant but also a new source of jobs and growth. About 100 missile systems will be made each year. With the investment coming to Uttar Pradesh and the progress in the state, the region will become a symbol of a new era of growth and defence.

He pointed to reports of supply chain issues in other countries and said we need to strengthen small industries that make thousands of parts needed for a large weapon system so we rely less on others. As technology grows, supply chains diversify. These chains often link to other countries. If a person, company or country refuses to give a spare part, the product cannot be made. We must strengthen small industries so we do not rely on others for spare parts. Whether it is advanced seekers or ramjet engines, we must develop all technology in India so our supply chain stays inside India.

Raksha Mantri urged a clear project plan to bring small entrepreneurs into the defence system. The UP Defence Industrial Corridor will succeed only when small industries grow with big companies. I am sure that in the future UP will be a manufacturing hub and a new centre for innovation and jobs for entrepreneurs, big and small.

Shri Rajnath Singh added that places like the BrahMos Integration and Testing Facility Centre boost both security and the economy. The government gets a lot of GST from the missiles being delivered, which shows each missile protects the nation and also helps the economy. From the taxes of one missile, the government can build many schools, set up many hospitals and run programmes that benefit people.

In his speech, the UP Chief Minister called BrahMos a missile of Aatmanirbharta, meeting the country’s defence needs. He thanked Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi and Raksha Mantri Shri Rajnath Singh for giving Lucknow the chance to join the movement toward self-reliance in defence by making BrahMos missiles. The Chief Minister said missiles made in Lucknow assure safety and prosperity for the nation. He praised progress in all six nodes of the UP Defence Industrial Corridor, noting more than 15,000 youth have jobs in the state.

The BrahMos facility is a major project under the UP Defence Industrial Corridor. It does all steps of assembly, integration and testing to high technical standards. With its first missile shipment, Uttar Pradesh is now a key partner in the ‘Make in India, Make for the World’ program. The Lucknow unit is the first in the corridor to handle the full manufacturing and testing process in India, strengthening strategic independence and industry growth.

Shri Rajnath Singh and Shri Yogi Adityanath also opened the Booster Building and saw a live demo of the booster docking. They also reviewed presentations at the Airframe and Avionics, Pre-Dispatch Inspection and Warhead Buildings, and the BrahMos simulator. A mobile autonomous launcher was also shown.

DG (BrahMos) Dr Jaytirth R. Joshi gave the GST bill and a cheque of about Rs 40 crore to the UP Chief Minister, showing revenue for the state. UP Deputy Chief Minister Shri Brajesh Pathak and Secretary, Department of Defence R&D and Chairman DRDO Dr Samir V Kamat were also present.

*** VK/SPS/Savvy
announcements.original_title: Aatmanirbhar Bharat: Raksha Mantri and UP Chief Minister flag-off first batch of BrahMos missiles manufactured at BrahMos Integration & Testing Facility Centre under UP Defence Corridor in Lucknow
announcements.summary:
On October 18, 2025, Rajnath Singh and Yogi Adityanath launched the first BrahMos missiles made in Lucknow, showing India's growing defence skill.
The new plant, part of the UP Defence Industrial Corridor, also brings jobs, growth and a boost to the country's self-reliance.

announcements.title: Army chief visits forward areas, checks readiness and community work
announcements.content: Chief of the Army Staff, General Upendra Dwivedi, visited forward posts in the central sector to see how ready the troops were, to encourage them, and to strengthen ties between the army and local civilians in a key area. During the visit, the COAS looked at units posted at high altitudes in Pithoragarh and nearby posts. He was briefed on upgrades such as advanced surveillance systems, special mobility vehicles, new tech, better use of reconnaissance tools, and cooperation with allied security forces. He praised the professionalism, discipline, quick thinking and creative use of new gear in tough terrain. He spoke with soldiers in remote areas, thanked them for their resilience, courage and steadfast commitment to duty in harsh weather and difficult terrain. He confirmed that the Indian Army is fully ready to face changing security threats, keeping the core principle of "Service Before Self." The Chief also spoke with veterans and local people, thanked them for their sacrifice and sent warm Diwali wishes to all ranks and their families. He stressed the strategic importance of the Kumaon region, especially as a gateway to the border areas of Nepal and China, and praised local patriotism and resilience. He recalled the proud legacy of the Kumaon Regiment and reviewed projects under Operation Sadbhavna and the Vibrant Village Programme, which include tent homestays in Garbyang and Kalapani, road work, hybrid power, medical camps and farm help through polyhouses. He highlighted that the army in Kumaon means "strength with compassion," defending the border while helping local communities. At the end of the tour, General Dwivedi reaffirmed the army’s firm determination to keep high standards, improve civil‑military relations and uphold the highest traditions of duty, honor and service to the nation.
announcements.original_title: CHIEF OF ARMY STAFF VISITS FORWARD AREAS IN CENTRAL SECTOR, REVIEWS OPERATIONAL READINESS AND COMMUNITY INITIATIVES
announcements.summary:
General Upendra Dwivedi visited army posts in the Kumaon region to check readiness, encourage troops, and talk with soldiers and local people.
He praised the army’s discipline, said they are ready for threats, sent Diwali wishes, and highlighted projects that help local communities.

announcements.title: Police Commemoration Day: Minister honors police at National Memorial
announcements.content: Raksha Mantri Shri Rajnath Singh, on October 21, 2025, placed a wreath at the National Police Memorial in New Delhi for Police Commemoration Day. That day in 1959, 10 brave policemen gave their lives when Chinese troops with heavy weapons ambushed them at Hot Springs, Ladakh. In his speech, the Raksha Mantri praised the fallen heroes and thanked the police and paramilitary forces for their service to the nation. He said the armed forces and police are pillars of national security. While the armed forces protect the country and its borders, the police protect society and its values. “The military and police work on different levels, but their goal is the same – to protect the nation. As we aim for Viksit Bharat by 2047, balancing external and internal security is more important than ever,” he added. On current challenges, Shri Rajnath Singh noted that along with border instability, new kinds of crime, terrorism, and ideological wars are emerging inside the country. He said crime has become more organized, hidden, and complex, and its aim is to create chaos, erode trust, and threaten national stability. He praised the police for preventing crime and for maintaining public trust. “If people sleep peacefully today, it is because they trust our vigilant armed forces and alert police. This trust is the basis of our country’s stability,” he said. He also highlighted that Naxalism had been a long‑term internal security problem. He said the joint efforts of police, CRPF, BSF, and local governments have stopped the problem from worsening, and people in areas affected by left‑wing extremism feel relieved. He believes the problem will end by March next year. “Several top Naxalites were eliminated this year. Those who used to fight the state are now surrendering and joining normal development. The number of districts affected by left‑wing extremism has fallen sharply. Areas that were once Naxalite strongholds are now becoming education hubs. Areas once known as the Red Corridor are now growth corridors. Our police and security forces played a big part in this success,” he said. The Raksha Mantri repeated that the Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi‑led Government is committed to ensuring national security and involves the police in this mission. “For a long time, we did not fully recognize the police’s contributions. But under PM Modi’s leadership, the government built the National Police Memorial in 2018 to honor our police. In addition, the police now have advanced weapons and better facilities. They have modern equipment such as surveillance systems, drones, forensic labs, and digital policing. States are also given enough resources to modernize the police,” he said. Shri Rajnath Singh called for better use of resources, which can only happen through coordination and integration with security agencies. He emphasized that society and police depend on each other and that a balanced relationship between them will make the security system stronger and more alert. “Policing works best when citizens partner and respect the law. When society and police have mutual understanding and responsibility, both benefit,” he added. A joint parade of Central Armed Police Forces (CAPFs) and Delhi Police took place as part of the event. The Union Minister of State for Home Affairs Shri Bandi Sanjay Kumar, Home Secretary Shri Govind Mohan, Director of the Intelligence Bureau Shri Tapan Deka, DG of BSF Shri Daljit Singh Chawdhary, other CAPF heads, retired DGs, and police officers attended the event. **** VK/SR/Savvy
announcements.original_title: Police Commemoration Day: Raksha Mantri lays wreath at National Police Memorial, New Delhi; Pays glowing tributes to police & paramilitary forces for their service to the nation
announcements.summary:
The Defence Minister laid a wreath at the National Police Memorial on Police Commemoration Day, honoring fallen policemen and praising police for keeping society safe.
He said police and armed forces together protect the country and must work closely for a secure future.

announcements.title: Defense Minister gives honorary Lt. Colonel rank to javelin star Neeraj Chopra
announcements.content: On October 22, 2025, the Defence Minister Shri Rajnath Singh officially awarded Neeraj Chopra, a top javelin thrower and two-time Olympic medalist, the honorary rank of Lieutenant Colonel in the Territorial Army. The ceremony took place at South Block, New Delhi. During the event, the Minister spoke with Lt Col (Hony) Neeraj Chopra and his family, calling him a model of perseverance, patriotism, and the Indian spirit of striving for excellence. He added, 'Lt Col (Hony) Neeraj Chopra shows the highest values of discipline, dedication and national pride, inspiring both athletes and the Armed Forces.' The Chief of the Army Staff General Upendra Dwivedi and other senior Indian Army and Territorial Army officers were also present. Neeraj Chopra joined the Indian Army in 2016 and served with The Rajputana Rifles. Born on 24 December 1997 in Khandra village, Panipat district, Haryana, he has made the nation proud with his achievements in international athletics. He made history by becoming the first Indian to win an Olympic Gold in track and field at the Tokyo Olympics in 2020. He also won a Silver at the Paris Olympics in 2024 and a Gold at the World Athletics Championships in 2023. He has earned many Gold medals at the Asian Games, Commonwealth Games, and Diamond League. His best throw of 90.23 metres (2025) is a record in Indian sports. For his outstanding achievements, President Smt Droupadi Murmu gave him an honorary commission in the Territorial Army on April 16, 2025. Earlier, he received the Padma Shri, Major Dhyan Chand Khel Ratna Award, Arjuna Award, Param Vishisht Seva Medal and Vishisht Seva Medal.
announcements.original_title: Raksha Mantri formally confers insignia of Honorary rank of Lieutenant Colonel in Territorial Army upon star javelin thrower Neeraj Chopra
announcements.summary:
On October 22, 2025, Defence Minister Shri Rajnath Singh gave Neeraj Chopra the honorary rank of Lieutenant Colonel in the Territorial Army.
The ceremony honored his Olympic medals, record javelin throw of 90.23 metres, and his dedication to the nation.

announcements.title: Japan-India Sea Drill 2025
announcements.content: Indian Naval Ship (INS) Sahyadri, an indigenously built Shivalik-class Guided Missile Stealth Frigate, participated in the Sea phase of JAIMEX-25 (Japan India Maritime Exercise) from 16 to 18 Oct 2025 and made a port call at Yokosuka, Japan, on 21 Oct 2025 for the Harbour phase. Prior to arriving at Yokosuka, INS Sahyadri and JMSDF Ships Asahi, Oumi and Submarine Jinryu took part in the sea phase of JAIMEX-25. The sea phase had advanced anti-submarine warfare and missile defence drills, improving teamwork by doing flight operations and replenishment at sea. JAIMEX-25 shows the strong and growing navy interactions that support the Special Strategic and Global Partnership started in 2014. The partnership is an important base for keeping peace and stability in the Indo-Pacific sea area. During the harbour part at Yokosuka, crews of INS Sahyadri and the Japanese units will take part in many professional and cultural exchanges. Activities will include visiting each other's decks, joint planning, sharing best practices, and a group yoga session to build friendship and unity. The port visit is also an important interaction as the ship continues its long-range deployment to the Indo-Pacific. Commissioned in 2012, INS Sahyadri shows India's growing effort to build defence tech at home and its vision of ‘ Aatmanirbhar Bharat’ (Self-Reliant India). The stealth frigate with many roles has been in many operations, bilateral and multilateral exercises. India and Japan's strategic partnership has been strong for a long time, focusing on defence and sea cooperation. The Indian Navy and Japan's JMSDF have led this partnership with a shared aim of a free, open, and inclusive Indo-Pacific region. ______________________________________________________________ VM/SPS   223/25

announcements.summary:
The INS Sahyadri frigate joined the Japan‑India maritime exercise JAIMEX‑25, doing sea drills with Japanese ships from 16 to 18 Oct 2025, and visited Yokosuka on 21 Oct 2025 for the harbour phase.
Crew members will exchange ideas, share best practices, and do a group yoga session to strengthen friendship while the ship continues its long deployment across the Indo‑Pacific.

announcements.content: The Ministry of Defence's Special Campaign 5.0, running from 2nd to 31st October 2025, is being actively carried out by the Armed Forces and all defence establishments across the country. announcements.title: Operation Sindoor shows India ready for any challenge, Defence Minister says
announcements.content: Operation Sindoor was a sign of India's strength and ability. It told the world that we are ready to respond to any challenge," said Raksha Mantri Shri Rajnath Singh during the Naval Commanders’ Conference in New Delhi on October 23, 2025. Raksha Mantri praised the Indian Navy for creating a deterrent posture that made Pakistan stay near its coast. He said the world saw the Navy’s readiness, professional skill and power during the operation. He described the Navy’s presence in the Indian Ocean Region (IOR) as giving comfort to friendly nations and discomfort to those who want to destabilise the region. "IOR has become the centre of modern geopolitics. It is no longer passive; it has become a place of competition and cooperation. The Indian Navy, with its many capabilities, has led the region. In the last six months, our ships, submarines and naval aircraft have been used on an unprecedented scale. The Navy also gave safe passage to about 335 merchant vessels, equal to about 1.2 million metric tons of cargo and a trade value of $5.6 billion. This shows that India is now a trusted and capable partner in the global maritime economy," said Shri Rajnath Singh. He said a self-reliant Navy is the base of a confident and powerful country, and thanked the Navy for improving its skills with local equipment and for leading the Aatmanirbhar Bharat movement. "In the last 10 years, about 67 percent of the Navy’s big purchase contracts were with Indian companies. This shows we no longer rely only on imports. We use our own talent and the skills of MSMEs and start‑ups. The Navy is now working on 194 innovation and indigenisation projects under iDEX, TDF, SPRINT, and Make-in-India. These projects have made the Navy more tech‑independent and have brought private companies and young creators into the mission," he said. He said modern warfare is about technology and intelligence. The government led by Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi is giving more focus to self‑reliance in defence, local innovation and advanced technologies. "Maritime readiness is no longer just about ships or submarines. It is about technology‑driven, network‑centric and autonomous systems. We must protect ourselves from the enemy’s modern tech, while improving our own skills in these areas. We have the chance and the skill. We are making our own equipment on our land," he said. Raksha Mantri noted that under Aatmanirbhar Bharat, the Indian Navy is not only building defence equipment but also helping build the nation. "Today, our Navy has become a pioneer in the country’s self‑reliance, innovation and industry. Every ship or submarine built creates a new job; every engine creates a new skill; every local system reduces India’s dependence. Project 17A ships, with more than 75 percent local parts, have created about 1.27 lakh jobs in shipyards like MDL and GRSE. This proves each Navy project connects to security, economy and young people’s jobs," he said. He also said the Navy has worked more with MSMEs and small shipyards. Recently, contracts worth about Rs 315 crore were awarded for yard craft, a big step toward the Voice for Local vision. "The Navy has made many new steps in its aviation sector. Projects like the Multi‑role Maritime Reconnaissance Aircraft, Utility Helicopters, Twin‑engine Deck Fighters, and Naval Shipborne Unmanned Aerial Systems give a new direction to our domestic aviation industry. This not only fills critical gaps but also strengthens self‑reliance," he added. Raksha Mantri said it is important to balance strategy and buying the best equipment for modern wars. "No country can win a war only with equipment and warships. Technology gives an edge, but geography, tricks, timing and human judgement must always be part of the plan. Fleet size and modernisation are important, but using platforms tactically is also key. Agility and adaptability are essential in planning," he said. He said we must move the naval strategy and thinking to match the fast changing world. "We must work together in three areas: capability, people and partnerships. Capability means technology & strength; people means sailors & their families; partnerships mean industry, academia & international cooperation. When these three come together, our Navy will become even more reliable and powerful," he said. Chief of Defence Staff General Anil Chauhan, Chief of the Naval Staff Admiral Dinesh K Tripathi, Defence Secretary Shri Rajesh Kumar Singh, Secretary DDR&D and Chairman DRDO Dr Samir V. Kamat and naval commanders were at the event. The conference is a chance to talk closely with national leaders and officials, and to fine‑tune the Navy’s view on handling many challenges in the current geo‑strategic environment. The Navy’s top leaders are reviewing readiness on the west and east coasts, boosting local production and innovation under the Make‑in‑India scheme, advancing the government’s vision of MAHASAGAR (Mutual and Holistic Advancement for Security Across all Regions) and promoting the Indian Navy as the Preferred Security Partner in the IOR and Indo‑Pacific. ******* SR/VM/Savvy
announcements.original_title: Operation Sindoor sent a global message that India is ever ready to respond to every challenge: Raksha Mantri at Naval Commanders’ Conference
announcements.summary:
Operation Sindoor showed India's strength and the Indian Navy's readiness to protect the Indian Ocean Region.
It highlighted the Navy's self‑reliance, with 335 merchant vessels safely passed and $5.6 billion of trade, and 194 innovation projects under iDEX, TDF, SPRINT, and Make-in-India.

announcements.title: Defence Minister releases 2025 Defence Procurement Manual
announcements.content: Raksha Mantri Shri Rajnath Singh released the Defence Procurement Manual (DPM) 2025 at a ceremony in South Block, New Delhi on October 23, 2025. Starting from November 01, 2025, the new manual will help the three Services and other units in the Ministry of Defence buy goods worth about Rs 1 lakh crore. He thanked the Ministry of Defence and the HQ Integrated Defence Staff for revising the manual and said it will make processes easier, give consistency, and help the Armed Forces get the equipment and services they need for readiness. It will also give more chances to MSMEs and start‑ups in defence manufacturing and technology, while keeping fairness, transparency and accountability in buying. Dr Mayank Sharma, Financial Advisor (Defence Services), gave a short overview of DPM 2025 and said the manual was made after close talks with the services and other stakeholders. Key points: Some rules have been changed to speed up decisions and make business easier. Liquidated damages (LD) for late delivery of stores and services have been relaxed; a maximum of 10% LD will only apply for very long delays. In cases of indigenisation, only 0.1% LD per week will apply instead of 0.5% per week. There are also rules for guaranteed orders up to five years for items made by public or private companies under indigenisation. The new manual says a Limited Tender enquiry can be used for values up to Rs 50 lakh, and beyond that only in special cases. The rule that requires a ‘No objection certificate’ from the former Ordnance Factory Board before buying from other sources has been removed. The manual lets you plan for a 15% growth of work when repairing ships or overhauling aircraft equipment. This will lower downtime and keep platforms ready. Rules for procurement on a PAC basis (Proprietary Article Certificate) have been updated while keeping its validity at 2 years. All Requests for Proposals (RFPs) issued after November 01, 2025 will follow DPM 2025. RFPs issued before or up to October 31, 2025 will still follow DPM 2009, as amended. RFPs issued earlier but retracted or to be re‑issued on or after November 01, 2025 will follow DPM 2025. The manual is in two volumes. Volume I has the main procurement rules. Volume II has the forms, appendices and government orders referred to in Volume I. Volume I has fourteen chapters, including three new ones: Promoting Self‑reliance through Innovation and Indigenisation, Information and Communication Technology Procurement and Consultancy, and Non‑Consultancy Services. The new chapter on self‑reliance will encourage local design and development of defence items to reach the goal of Aatmanirbharta in defence manufacturing and technology. A PDF copy of the DPM 2025 is available on the MoD website. The ceremony was attended by the Chief of Defence Staff, the Chief of Naval Staff, the Chief of Army Staff, the Defence Secretary, the Secretary of the Department of Defence (R&D), the Chairman of DRDO, the Secretary (Defence Production), the Secretary (Ex‑servicemen Welfare), Dr Mayank Sharma, the Vice Chief of the Air Staff, the Controller General of Defence Accounts, an Officer on Special Duty in the Department of Ex‑servicemen Welfare, and other senior officials. ******** SR/Savvy
announcements.original_title: Raksha Mantri releases Defence Procurement Manual 2025
announcements.summary:
In a ceremony on 23 October 2025, the Defence Minister released a new manual to make buying equipment for the Army, Navy and Air Force easier and faster.
Starting 1 November 2025 the manual will guide purchases worth Rs 1 lakh crore and give more chances to local small businesses, while keeping buying fair and clear.

announcements.title: DAC approves proposals worth 79,000 crore to boost armed forces
announcements.content: The Defence Acquisition Council, led by Defence Minister Shri Rajnath Singh, approved several defence projects worth about Rs 79,000 crore in a meeting at South Block, New Delhi on October 23, 2025. For the Indian Army, an Acceptance of Necessity (AoN) was given for buying the Nag Missile System (Tracked) Mk-II (NAMIS), Ground Based Mobile ELINT System (GBMES) and High Mobility Vehicles (HMVs) with a Material Handling Crane. NAMIS (Tracked) will help the army destroy enemy tanks, bunkers and other fortifications. GBMES will give the army 24‑hour electronic tracking of enemy signals. HMVs will greatly improve supply support in varied terrain. For the Indian Navy, an AoN was approved for purchasing Landing Platform Docks (LPD), 30mm Naval Surface Gun (NSG), Advanced Light Weight Torpedoes (ALWT), Electro Optical Infra‑Red Search and Track System and Smart Ammunition for 76mm Super Rapid Gun Mount. LPDs will allow the navy to carry out amphibious operations with the army and air force. The LPD’s sea power will also help with peacekeeping, humanitarian aid and disaster relief. ALWT, made by Naval Science & Technological Laboratory, DRDO, can hit conventional, nuclear and small submarines. 30mm NSG will boost the navy and coast guard ability to handle low‑intensity maritime actions and piracy. For the Indian Air Force, an AoN was granted for the Collaborative Long Range Target Saturation/Destruction System (CLRTS/DS) and other items. CLRTS/DS can launch, land, fly, find targets and drop its payload on its own in the mission zone. **** SR/Savvy
announcements.original_title: DAC clears proposals, worth about Rs 79,000 crore, to enhance the capability of the Armed Forces
announcements.summary: On October 23, 2025 the Defence Acquisition Council approved defence projects worth Rs 79,000 crore. The army, navy and air force will get new gear such as NAMIS, GBMES, HMVs, LPDs, 30mm NSG, ALWT, CLRTS/DS and other equipment.

announcements.title: Operation Sindoor warned Pakistan; it will think twice before attacking India
announcements.content: “Pakistan will think twice before attacking India because our Armed Forces gave them a strong warning during Operation Sindoor,” said Raksha Mantri Shri Rajnath Singh while talking to soldiers at the Barakhana dinner in Jaisalmer, Rajasthan on October 23, 2025. He said the operation is not finished, only paused, and warned Pakistan that a harsher response would come if it attacks again. “Our pilots only showed a small display of India’s power to Pakistan. If they get a chance, they will show our real strength,” he added. He reminded that our enemies are never idle, and urged the Armed Forces to stay alert and ready to take action. Raksha Mantri spoke about how the Armed Forces can help the Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi-led Government’s vision to make India a developed, self-reliant nation by 2047. “Our soldiers protect borders and build the nation. This century and the future belong to us; with our progress towards self‑reliance, I am sure our military will become the best in the world,” he said. He also noted the government’s promise to build better border infrastructure. Raksha Mantri said Barakhana represents India’s culture, civilization, and values, where all are treated equally. “Our forces bring together people of many religions, castes, languages, and regions. The diversity shows itself in one shared meal at Barakhana, making it better than any other dinner,” he said. Before the Barakhana, Raksha Mantri opened ‘Shauryavan’, a unique Cacti and Botanical Garden in Jaisalmer. ‘Shauryavan’, an Indian Army project, turns the Thar Desert into an oasis, symbolising resilience, ecology and new ideas. He also paid tribute at the Jaisalmer War Memorial, a ‘Shaurya Gantavya’, under the ‘Bharat Ranbhoomi Darshan’ program. He saw a collection of war trophies and artifacts that tell the story of the Indian Army’s bravery. He watched the first Holographic Light & Sound Show at the Memorial, a modern technology addition that makes the Memorial a top destination. Chief of the Army Staff General Upendra Dwivedi, Defence Secretary Shri Rajesh Kumar Singh, Vice Chief of the Army Staff Lieutenant General Pushpendra Singh, all Army Commanders, and other senior officers were present. On October 24, 2025, Raksha Mantri will visit forward areas and watch a new ‘Capability Demonstration Exercise’ by the Southern Command. He will also speak at the Army Commanders’ Conference in Jaisalmer. ******** SR/NA/Savvy/KB
announcements.original_title: Operation Sindoor gave Pakistan a good dose of caution, it will now think twice before attempting any misadventure against India: Raksha Mantri
announcements.summary:
Pakistan will think twice before attacking India because the Armed Forces gave a strong warning during Operation Sindoor, as said by Raksha Mantri Shri Rajnath Singh.
He urged soldiers to stay alert and ready, promising a harsher response if Pakistan attacks again and stressing India’s power and self‑reliance by 2047.

announcements.title: Project Arunank (BRO) marks 18th Raising Day
announcements.content: Project Arunank of the Border Roads Organisation (BRO) marked its 18th Raising Day in Naharlagun, Arunachal Pradesh on October 24, 2025, celebrating 17 years of hard work in one of India's toughest areas. Since 2008, the Project has built and kept more than 696 km of roads and 1.18 km of large bridges, giving important links to faraway valleys and forward areas in Arunachal Pradesh and meeting the needs of the Armed Forces. A major success was finishing the 278 km Hapoli-Sarli-Huri Road, paved for the first time since independence, linking one of the most isolated parts of Kurung Kumey district. Project Arunank has also used new and green methods like Steel Slag, Cut-and-Cover Tunnels, Geo Cells, Plastic Sheets, GGBFS Concrete and Gabion Walls, making roads stronger and kinder to the environment. Important milestones include upgrading the Hapoli-Sarli-Huri Road to NHDL standards in 2020 and widening the Kimin-Potin Road in 2021. In 2022, a link to Maza, the last area along the Line of Actual Control, was made on December 28, 2022. The TCC-Maza Road will open in November 2025, after the TCC-Taksing Road was finished earlier this year. Also, the Huri-Tapa and Taksing Ghora Camp-Lung OP roads should finish by the end of 2025 under mission-mode work, showing the project’s promise to finish projects on time and strategically. A Motorable Expedition was arranged along the Naharlagun-Joram Top-Sangram-Ziro-Naharlagun route to boost road links and safety awareness. Under the green program ‘Ek Ped Maa Ke Naam,’ 23,850 trees were planted throughout Arunachal Pradesh, showing BRO’s care for the environment. At the event, new welfare steps were started for Casual Paid Labourers, such as better shelters, protective clothes, and regular health camps, acknowledging their important role in BRO’s work. With this strong base, BRO’s future plans will include widening roads, building new bridges and tunnels, and improving high‑altitude links for civilians and defence. Using new tech like geotextiles, slope stabilisation systems, digital monitoring tools and eco-friendly building methods will make roads stronger and safer while cutting long‑term upkeep. ******* SR/KB

announcements.title: ICG launches two fast patrol boats, Ajit and Aparajit
announcements.content: On October 24, 2025, the Indian Coast Guard (ICG) launched two new Fast Patrol Vessels (FPVs) named ICG Ship Ajit and ICGS Aparajit at Goa Shipyard Limited (GSL). These are the seventh and eighth ships of a series of eight FPVs that GSL is building for the ICG, showing progress in India’s coastal surveillance and response. The FPVs were designed and built entirely by GSL, showing India’s growing shipbuilding strength. They are 52 metres long, weigh 320 tonnes, and use Controllable Pitch Propellers (CPP) – the first of their kind for this class in India – giving better manoeuvring and fuel efficiency. The ships can perform many tasks such as protecting fisheries, patrolling the coast, stopping smuggling and piracy, and rescuing people in distress, especially around India’s islands and Exclusive Economic Zone. The launch was conducted by Smt. Manju Sharma. Dr. Mayank Sharma, Financial Advisor (Defence Services), was the chief guest. Commander, ICG Region (West) Inspector General Bhisham Sharma and other senior officers from ICG and GSL were also present. Dr. Mayank Sharma praised the ICG and GSL, saying the project helps the local industry, creates jobs, and supports MSME ecosystem, and shows how such projects strengthen India’s maritime independence. With these two FPVs added, the ICG is growing its fleet of fast, modern vessels, improving readiness and safety along India’s long coastline. The launch also strengthens GSL’s role as a main builder of next‑generation Indian defence ships. ********** SR/KB

announcements.title: Delivery of Mahe, first anti-submarine shallow‑water craft from CSL Kochi
announcements.content: ‘Mahe’, the first of eight Anti-Submarine Warfare Shallow Water Crafts (ASW SWC) built by Cochin Shipyard Limited (CSL) in Kochi, was delivered to the Indian Navy on 23 Oct 2025. Named after the historic port town in the Union Territory of Puducherry, ‘Mahe’ represents India’s strong maritime history. The ship was designed and built in India by CSL, showing India’s growing independence in naval shipbuilding. It can do underwater monitoring, Low Intensity Maritime Operations (LIMO), anti-submarine warfare (ASW) in coastal waters, and has advanced mine‑laying ability. Roughly 78 metres long and weighing about 1,100 tons, the vessel is powerful in underwater combat, carrying torpedoes, Multifunctional Anti-Submarine Rockets, and advanced radars and sonars. Adding these ASW SWCs will greatly improve the Indian Navy’s ASW power and strengthen sea security near the coast. Delivering ‘Mahe’, with over 80% locally made parts, is another achievement that confirms the Government of India’s ‘Aatmanirbhar Bharat’ goal. ______________________________________________________________ VM/SPS      224/25

announcements.title: Defense Minister checks army readiness at Jaisalmer conference, visits Tanot and Laungewala
announcements.content:
Raksha Mantri Shri Rajnath Singh reviewed the security situation and the readiness of the Indian Army at the Army Commanders’ Conference in Jaisalmer. He also visited the forward areas of Tanot and Laungewala in Rajasthan on October 24, 2025. During the conference, senior leaders of the Indian Army discussed key topics such as Grey Zone Warfare, the plan for joint operations, self‑reliance and innovation. The audience included Chief of Defence Staff General Anil Chauhan, Chief of the Army Staff General Upendra Dwivedi, Defence Secretary Shri Rajesh Kumar Singh, Vice Chief of the Army Staff Lieutenant General Pushpendra Singh and all Army Commanders.

In his speech, Raksha Mantri described Operation Sindoor as a showcase of India’s military strength and national character. He said the soldiers showed that their power comes not only from weapons but also from their moral discipline and clear strategy. "Operation Sindoor will be remembered not just as a military action but as a symbol of the nation’s bravery and restraint. Our forces acted with precision and respect for human dignity. The operation is not finished. Our mission for peace will continue as long as any terrorist mind remains alive," he added.

Shri Rajnath Singh said that Operation Sindoor has created a new way of thinking: India will respond to any terrorist act on its own terms. "This is India’s new Defence Doctrine, which shows both determination and courage," he said.

Raksha Mantri thanked the soldiers for guarding the nation 24X7 and urged them never to underestimate the enemy and to stay alert and ready at all times.

He called on the Commanders to keep working on defence diplomacy, self‑reliance, information warfare, defence infrastructure and force modernisation to make the Army future‑ready. He praised the professionalism, bravery and resilience of the Indian Armed Forces and confirmed the Government’s promise to give advanced technology, infrastructure and support to keep the Army fully prepared.

Shri Rajnath Singh highlighted the Indian Army’s important role in bringing peace and development to Jammu & Kashmir after Article 370 was removed. "The removal of Article 370 was historic. Today the streets there are filled with hope, not unrest. People feel confident about their future. Most importantly, decision‑making is now in the hands of the local people. The Indian Army has played a key role in this effort," he said.

On the situation along the northern border, Raksha Mantri said that the ongoing talks and steps to reduce tension show India’s balanced and firm foreign policy. "Our policy is clear: we will keep talking, and we will keep our readiness on the border," he said.

He praised the soldiers’ willpower and discipline, calling it proof that the Indian military is one of the most adaptable forces in the world. "Whether it’s the freezing icy terrain of Siachen, the hot desert of Rajasthan, or counter‑insurgency in dense forests, our soldiers always show their capability and commitment. Despite tough conditions and varied challenges, they adapt and strengthen national security," he said.

Raksha Mantri noted that modern warfare is driven by technology, but the soldiers are still the country’s greatest asset. He said machines boost strength, but the human spirit delivers results. He added that today’s war is fought in invisible realms such as cyberspace, information, electronic disruption and space control, and that quick decisions and soldiers’ willpower are key.

At the conference, Shri Rajnath Singh also virtually opened new technology hubs called Edge Data Centres at Konark and the Fire & Fury Corps of the Indian Army. By next year, all Corps will have Edge Data Centres across the nation. He launched the Equipment Helpline for the Indian Army, the Sainik Yatri Mitra App and released the Defence Millet Dishes Compendium compiled by the Army Service Corp Centre & College in Bengaluru. He also inaugurated Naman Centres to help veterans and their families.

In Laungewala, Raksha Mantri laid a wreath at the famous Laungewala Yudh Sthal and paid tribute to the brave hearts of the Indian Army. He opened Chandpuri Hall, an audio‑visual room, in memory of Major (later Brigadier) Kuldip Singh Chandpuri who led the courageous defence during the 1971 Battle of Laungewala. He also congratulated veterans who fought in that battle.

Raksha Mantri reviewed many infrastructure projects aimed at turning the historic site into a national symbol of pride that shows the Indian Army’s valor and resilience. Shri Rajnath Singh also watched a dynamic Capability Demonstration Exercise, showing the integrated use of new units such as the Bhairav Battalion and Ashni Platoon, along with the latest technology brought into the Army for operations. The display highlighted how the Army blends tradition with innovation and focuses on building new skills and modernising its forces.
*** SR/NA/Savvy

announcements.title: Minister Scindia calls Northeast India’s growth engine in media briefing
announcements.content: The Union Minister for Communications and Development of the North Eastern Region, Shri Jyotiraditya M. Scindia, led a Joint Media Briefing today on the One Year Achievements (August 2024 – September 2025) of the Ministry of Development of North Eastern Region (MDoNER), the Department of Posts (DoP), and the Department of Telecommunications (DoT). The event was attended by Dr. Chandra Sekhar Pemmasani, Minister of State for Communications, Dr. Sukanta Majumdar, Minister of State for Education and DoNER, and Sh. Chanchal Kumar, Secretary MDoNER. With the visionary leadership of Hon’ble Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi, the North Eastern Region has changed a lot in the last year. Speaking to the media, Shri Scindia said he is proud of this progress. He said that, following the Prime Minister’s guidance, the Ministry has worked on Reform, Reach and Results, and has seen record growth in infrastructure, investment, governance, and youth involvement. “Today the Northeast shows the spirit of a new India—strong, connected, and ready for the future. Thanks to the Prime Minister’s vision, the region has moved from a frontier to a front‑runner, showing confidence and competitiveness,” he said. Historic Growth and Economic Potential Shri Scindia talked about the big growth potential of the NE region. He said that over the last decade, the region’s GDP growth has been higher than the national average. He also pointed out the high literacy rate and the large young population, with 70% of people under 28 years old. He added, “All of this makes the region a true growth engine for India.” The Minister said the Ministry spent its highest ever amount, ₹3,447.71 crore, in FY 2024–25. That is a 74.4% rise from the previous year and a growth of over 200% in three years. He said this shows MDoNER’s focus on careful spending, digital tracking, and quick delivery. Weekly reviews, releases of funds in four parts, and digital tracking via the Poorvottar Vikas Setu portal have made the process clear and efficient, covering 97% of projects in inspections and bringing 91% of finished projects into use. Reforms, Governance, and Institutional Strengthening The Ministry has set up Chief Minister‑led Sectoral High‑Level Task Forces in eight areas: tourism, investment, handicrafts, agriculture, infrastructure, sports, the north east economic corridor, and protein self‑reliance. These groups help states work together, align policies, and make sure development is shared across the region, not just within each state. Using an Inter‑Ministerial Facilitation Mechanism, MDoNER has sped up approvals for big infrastructure projects like the expansion of Shillong Airport, a new route for NH‑10 in Sikkim, and the development of Kailashahar Airport in Tripura, strengthening the region’s connectivity. Investment and Economic Integration Shri Scindia highlighted the strong investment momentum of the year. The Rising North East Investors Summit 2025, held at Bharat Mandapam, New Delhi, in May 2025, and related events drew eight Chief Ministers, eight Union Ministers, more than 100 ambassadors, and 108 PSUs, leading to investment commitments worth ₹4.48 lakh crore—a historic milestone for the region. The Ashtalakshmi Mahotsav, held on 6‑8 Dec 2024 and opened by the Prime Minister, celebrated the culture of the eight north eastern states and generated investment leads worth ₹2,326 crore. The North East Banker’s Conclave in Agartala, held in December 2024, resulted in 51 new bank branches, more ATM networks, and better MSME credit. Through NEDFi, over 5,300 MSMEs got support and ₹766 crore was raised for start‑ups and businesses, boosting financial inclusion and entrepreneurship. Tourism, Connectivity, and Global Positioning He also talked about MDoNER’s plan to make the Northeast a top global tourism and cultural spot through the Brand Northeast strategy. Every state has chosen special products and experiences—like Muga Silk from Assam, Lakadong Turmeric from Meghalaya, Polo from Manipur, Organic Farming from Sikkim, and Queen Pineapple from Tripura—to showcase its identity. Eight famous tourism spots—Kaziranga, Ziro, Sohra, Thenzawl, Matabari, Kisama, Namchi, and Moirang—are being upgraded into world‑class attractions through public‑private partnerships. Homestay and eco‑tourism options have grown in all states, raising rural incomes by 45% and supporting sustainable livelihoods. Shri Scindia spoke about the need for better connectivity to reach tourism’s full potential. He noted that in the last 11 years, airports grew from 9 in 8 states, with none in Sikkim and Arunachal Pradesh, to 17, including 4 in Arunachal Pradesh alone. He said all NE states will be linked by rail by 2029. Work on the Kaladan and India‑Myanmar‑Thailand Trilateral Highway projects is also underway to connect the NE region with the rest of the world. “The region is becoming India’s gateway rather than the last frontier,” he added. Agriculture, Industry and Entrepreneurship Shri Scindia highlighted the government’s work to diversify the Northeast’s economy with industry‑led agriculture and horticulture. The National Mission on Edible Oils – Oil Palm has started over 68,000 hectares of plantations and set up 47 nurseries and five seed gardens. The Agarwood business has increased its export quota six times and opened an export portal with DGFT, and a GI registration is underway. The bamboo industry, with 22 projects worth ₹126.7 crore, has trained 2,587 artisans and introduced Amazon‑linked market models, linking local crafts to global markets. These actions are creating jobs, boosting exports, and supporting rural entrepreneurship. ***** Samrat/Allen'

announcements.title: Earth Sciences Ministry Makes Big Progress in SCDPM 5.0
announcements.content: 22 nd October, 2025 : The Ministry of Earth Sciences (MoES) has made good progress as part of the ongoing Special Campaign for Disposal of Pending Matters (SCDPM) 5.0. The SCDPM, now in its fifth edition in 2025, continues to focus on making offices cleaner, improving records, and ensuring that pending matters are dealt with on time in all government offices. The SCDPM 5.0, launched nationwide on October 02 this year, will keep up the effort for the whole month of October, in honour of Mahatma Gandhi. The campaign aims to improve how the government works, increase transparency, and deliver better public services. It is led by the DARPG (Department of Administrative Reforms and Public Grievances). Following Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi’s ‘Swachh Bharat’ vision, MoES, as part of SCDPM 5.0, has run 54 cleanliness drives, reviewed 192 files after looking through more than 500 files and records, handled 3 PMO references, 3 state government references, 2 MP references, and 9 public grievances, and properly disposed of scrap (including e‑waste) that earned over Rs 33.23 lakhs and freed about 8,750 square feet of space. Work has also focused on making rules and processes easier. The review of activities under SCDPM 5.0 across MoES institutions, including regional centres and field units, is overseen by a team led by Joint Secretary MoES Shri D Senthil Pandiyan. They hold regular meetings to monitor progress and solve problems. Nodal officers for SCDPM 5.0 at MoES institutions report daily and give timely updates through the latest digital tools, such as social media, mobile app groups, and the DARPG SCDPM portal for real‑time assessment. “The SCDPM is more than a campaign. It is a promise and a chance to modernise governance and give public services faster, clearer, and more citizen‑focused. We must stay focused on making MoES institutes models of excellent administration,” said Shri Pandiyan. Moving forward, MoES will keep running more cleanliness drives, make office space and work processes more efficient, and promote better disposal of pending matters in line with the government’s goal of transparency, good governance, and public service. **** NKR/AK'

announcements.title: IndiaAI and WHO request AI health study abstracts by Oct 31, 2025
announcements.content: The IndiaAI Mission, part of the Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology (MeitY) in India, together with the World Health Organization (WHO), invites people worldwide to submit short papers (abstracts) that show how Artificial Intelligence (AI) can be used effectively in health care. Papers chosen will be asked to write a chapter for the new Casebook on AI Health Use Cases Across the Global South. The Casebook will be released at the India–AI Impact Summit 2026 in New Delhi in February. IndiaAI and WHO created the Casebook to help leaders, makers, and scholars copy and grow AI projects that work well in the Global South. It will share real experiences and lessons to help use AI responsibly and speed up digital changes in health care. People from the Global South, including researchers, makers, and institutions, can send abstracts (no more than 250 words) about successful, practical, and scalable AI health projects by 31st October 2025. You can find the rules and application form at https://impact.indiaai.gov.in/events/who. Authors whose abstracts are chosen will be asked to write a full chapter (2,500–3,000 words) explaining the AI solution, how it was put into practice, ethical issues, results, and lessons learned. If you have questions, email fellow3.gpai-india@meity.gov.in. Use the subject line: “Call for Abstracts – Query – [Author Name]”. *** Dharmendra Tewari \ Navin Sreejith

announcements.title: Government changes IT Rule 3(1)(d) to improve transparency, accountability and protection
announcements.content: The Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology (MeitY) has published the 2025 Amendment Rules to update the 2021 Information Technology (Intermediary Guidelines and Digital Media Ethics Code) Rules (IT Rules, 2021). These changes make intermediaries' duties clearer under the 2000 Information Technology Act (IT Act). In particular, the new Rule 3(1)(d) adds safeguards so that taking down illegal content is done openly, fairly, and with accountability. The updated Rules start on 15th November, 2025. Background: The IT Rules, 2021 were first issued on 25th February, 2021, and amended on 28th October, 2022 and 6th April, 2023. They set duties for intermediaries, such as social‑media platforms, to keep online safety, security, and accountability. Rule 3(1)(d) says intermediaries must delete unlawful information when they know it, either from a court order or a notice from the appropriate government. MeitY’s review found the need for extra safeguards to make senior officials accountable, to describe unlawful content clearly, and to review government orders regularly at a higher level. Key features and expected impact: For details, see the Gazette Notification and the latest IT Rules, 2021 (amended up to October 2025) on https://egazette.gov.in and the MeitY website https://www.meity.gov.in/. ***** Dharmendra Tewari\\Navin Sreejith

announcements.title: India Should Use AI for Everyone's Benefit: Shri S. Krishnan, Secretary, MeitY
announcements.content:
The Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology (MeitY) held a Curtain Raiser event on October 23, 2025, to build excitement for its participation in the Emerging Science, Technology, and Innovation Conclave (ESTIC) 2025.
The event was led by Shri S Krishnan, Secretary MeitY, with Dr. Ganesh Ramakrishnan, Chair Professor of the Department of Computer Science and Engineering, IIT Bombay, and Ms. Kavita Bhatia, Scientist G and Group Coordinator, AI & ET Division, MeitY in attendance.
During the Curtain Raiser, Shri S. Krishnan, Secretary, MeitY said, "If India wants to become a developed country, we must use technology, and AI is perhaps the most important technology driving that change. To do this, we need inclusive ways that let everyone access and benefit from AI in real ways. In that sense, this event is very important, and its theme, 'Artificial Intelligence for Social Impact,' is a good fit. It shows our focus on how AI can truly help society and shape how we see and use technology. India's goal is clear – we must see AI as a good force and approach it positively and changefully."
Ms. Kavita Bhatia added, "AI is a powerful tool that lets us jump over old development obstacles and spark large social and economic change. Our approach follows the Prime Minister’s inclusive development philosophy, which is rooted in the idea of Sabka Saath, Sabka Vikas, Sabka Vishwas, aur Sabka Prayaas, putting 'AI for All' at its heart."
Dr. Ganesh Ramakrishnan said, "India has a special advantage because of its diversity and strong digital public infrastructure. Aadhaar, UPI, and other platforms give the backbone for large AI solutions. Great projects like Bhashini and the National Sovereign AI Ecosystem, BharatGen, show our commitment to building context-aware, multilingual, and multimodal AI that is rooted in India. It is also important to make sure these technologies reach the underserved and help Indian industry and startups use AI’s power."
About ESTIC 2025 The ESTIC 2025, scheduled for November 3 - 5, 2025, at Bharat Mandapam, is organized by the Department of Science and Technology under the guidance of the Office of Principal Scientific Adviser to the Government of India, showing cutting-edge developments that will shape India’s innovation-driven growth, advancing the vision of Viksit Bharat 2047.
Event details are on the official website: https://estic.dst.gov.in/index.html
About 'Artificial Intelligence for Social Impact' Session at ESTIC 2025 As part of ESTIC 2025, MeitY will host a dedicated session on Artificial Intelligence for Social Impact on November 4, 2025, highlighting India’s commitment to building a responsible, inclusive, and transformative AI ecosystem.
The session will focus on creating India-centric, resource-efficient AI solutions that solve real-world problems and produce measurable social benefit.
It will bring together key people from government, universities, research, and industry, showing the importance of teamwork to advance India’s AI and emerging tech ecosystem.
The keynote speaker will be Dr. Sridhar Vembu, Founder and Chief Scientist, Zoho.
Other speakers include Shri Abhishek Singh, Additional Secretary, MeitY; Dr. Sriram Raghavan, Vice President, IBM Research for AI; Dr. Geetha Manjunath, Founder and CEO, Niramai; Shri Amit Sheth, Founding Director, AI Institute, University of South Carolina; Shri Shashi Shekhar Vempati, Co-founder, DeepTech for Bharat Foundation and Former CEO, Prasar Bharati; Dr. Harrick Mayank Vin, Chief Technology Officer, Tata Consultancy Services; Prof. Balaraman Ravindran, Head, Department of DSAI, IIT Madras; Ms. Debjani Ghosh, Distinguished Fellow, NITI Aayog; Dr. Rimjhim Agrawal, Co-founder and CTO, BrainSightAI; Dr. P. Venkat Rangan, Vice Chancellor, Amrita University; and Mr. Alpan Raval, Chief Scientist, AI/ML, Wadhwani AI.
Building on the vision shown at ESTIC 2025, MeitY will host the India–AI Impact Summit 2026 on February 19 – 20, 2026, in New Delhi.
The Summit will highlight AI’s transformative power in promoting inclusive growth, sustainability, and fair development, centered around three core values – People, Planet, and Progress.
*** Dharmendra Tewari\\Navin Sreejith

announcements.title: Environment Minister Bhupender Yadav gives closing remarks at G20 in Cape Town.
announcements.content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi has often said that we should remember that we are only caretakers of the planet, not owners. This was said by Union Environment Minister Bhupender Yadav in Cape Town today. He delivered India’s closing statement at the G20 Climate and Environmental Sustainability Working Group Ministerial Meeting in South Africa. The minister expressed deep gratitude to South Africa for its strong leadership and for working hard on complex environmental issues. In his speech, Yadav recalled Mahatma Gandhi and said, ‘Truth must be spoken, heard and accepted. Today we must accept the truth that climate change and environmental damage are real problems before us.’ He added that global challenges can only be met through cooperation, collaboration, and commitment. Repeating his points from the summit’s opening remarks, Yadav said the past decade of the Paris Agreement shows that nothing is impossible. India’s experience shows that growth and environmental protection can move together through a planet‑friendly, people‑friendly model. The minister reminded the audience that G20 countries represent more than 80% of the world’s GDP and population, and therefore must work together as a team, especially to meet the needs of the Global South. He said, ‘Our approach to environmental issues must be practical and inspiring. Practical – to consider each country’s situation, capacity and responsibility. Inspiring – because we owe it to future generations.’ Yadav highlighted India’s climate‑change achievements, noting that the country increased its non‑fossil electricity share to over 50% in 2025, meeting its revised NDC target five years early. For example, solar capacity grew from 2.8 GW in 2014 to 127 GW in 2025, a 45‑fold increase in 11 years. This shows that where there is will, there is a way. As Nelson Mandela once said, ‘It always seems impossible until it’s done,’ Yadav added. He concluded by urging everyone to draw inspiration from great leaders, accept the truth, stay united, trust each other, and work together to improve people’s lives and save the planet.
