announcements.title: CAQM starts 12-point plan for NCR air quality right away
announcements.content:
Today, Delhi’s daily average AQI was 296 ('Poor'), per the CPCB daily bulletin. Hourly AQI rose to 300 at 6 PM and 302 at 7 PM ('Very Poor'). The CAQM Sub‑Committee on GRAP convened an urgent meeting to review air quality and weather conditions.

They reviewed forecasts from IMD and IITM and decided to activate the 12‑point Stage‑II GRAP across NCR to stop further decline. All Stage‑II actions (AQI 301–400) will be implemented immediately by all NCR agencies, adding to existing Stage‑I measures. PCBs of NCR states and DPCC were instructed to enforce Stage‑II strictly.

Citizens were urged to follow the steps in the Citizen Charter for Stage‑II and Stage‑I:
● Use public transport; cut personal vehicle use.
● Choose less congested routes, even if longer.
● Replace car air filters regularly.
● Avoid dust‑generating construction Oct–Jan.
● Do not burn solid waste or biomass.

The 12‑point Stage‑II plan includes:
1. Daily mechanical or vacuum sweeping and water sprinkling of selected roads; increase machine shifts.
2. Daily water sprinkling plus dust suppressants before peak traffic, especially on hotspots; dispose dust properly.
3. Intensify inspections to enforce dust control at construction sites.
4. Target pollution reduction in all NCR hotspots; intensify remedial actions in main sectors.
5. Ensure uninterrupted power to discourage alternative generators (DG sets).
6. Follow the DG set operation schedule per Direction 76/29.09.2023:
   – Up to 800 kW: meet MoEFCC GSR 804 (E) standards.
   – 800 kW and above: any emission control system, meeting prescribed standards.
   – 41–800 kW: dual‑fuel or certified retro‑fit ECDs.
   – 19–41 kW: dual‑fuel.
   – <19 kW: only for emergency services (elevators, medical, rail, metro, airports, etc.).
7. Coordinate traffic movements; deploy staff at congested intersections.
8. Broadcast air‑pollution alerts on media.
9. Raise parking fees to curb private transport.
10. Expand CNG/electric buses and metro; add vehicles and increase frequency; offer lower rates for off‑peak.
11. Resident Welfare Associations must give electric heaters to staff in security, sanitation, horticulture, etc., to prevent biomass burning in winter.
12. Ban inter‑state buses from NCR states, except EV, CNG, or BS‑VI diesel, entering Delhi (except those with All India Tourist Permit).

The Commission monitors closely and will review air quality regularly. The GRAP schedule is on the website https://caqm.nic.in
announcements.original_title: CAQM invokes 12-point action plan as per Stage-II of the extant GRAP in the entire NCR with immediate effect
announcements.type: Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change

A 12‑point plan has started across NCR to clean the air and stop it from getting worse. Check the plan at https://caqm.nic.in.

announcements.title: India ranks 9th worldwide in forest area, 3rd in yearly growth
announcements.content: India has reached a big milestone in protecting the environment. It is now 9th in the world for total forest area, according to the 2025 Global Forest Resources Assessment by the FAO in Bali. Union Minister for Environment, Forest and Climate Change, Shri Bhupender Yadav, shared this news in a post on X. India is now 9th in the 2025 Global Forest Assessment 🌳🌲. This is a reason for all Indians to celebrate. We moved from 10th in the last assessment to 9th. We also keep 3rd worldwide in annual forest growth, showing our dedication to sustainable forest care and balance, the Minister said. Shri Yadav said this success shows how well the Government of India’s policies and programmes under Prime Minister Narendra Modi work, focused on protecting forests, planting trees, and involving communities. The Prime Minister’s “Ek Ped Ma Ke Naam” campaign and his focus on environmental awareness have encouraged people across the country to plant and protect trees. This growing participation builds a strong sense of shared responsibility for a greener, sustainable future. The success comes thanks to the Modi government’s plans and policies to protect and grow forests, and the large plantation efforts by State Governments, the Minister said. pic.twitter.com/nDC5uzPuNi ***** VM

announcements.type: Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change
announcements.summary:
India has climbed to 9th place worldwide for forest area, a big win for the environment in the 2025 Global Forest Assessment.
The 'Ek Ped Ma Ke Naam' campaign, led by the government, encourages people to plant trees and protect forests.

announcements.title: Shri Tarun Kumar Pithode becomes full-time CAQM Secretary
announcements.content: Shri Tarun Kumar Pithode, an officer from the 2009 batch of the Indian Administrative Service (IAS) in the Madhya Pradesh group, has started his new role as the full‑time Member Secretary of the Commission for Air Quality Management in NCR and Adjoining Areas (CAQM) from today. He was previously the Joint Secretary in the Union Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change. Now he is the Member‑Secretary of the Commission. He will serve for a total of five years until 08.09.2029, or until further instructions, whichever comes first. Shri Pithode, IAS replaces Shri Arvind Kumar Nautiyal, IRSME (1992), in this important role. ***** VM

announcements.title: Biodiversity Authority gives 1.36 crore for conservation in Maharashtra and Uttar Pradesh
announcements.content: The National Biodiversity Authority (NBA) has shown its strong commitment to fair sharing and protecting biodiversity by giving ₹1.36 crore to local communities in Maharashtra and Uttar Pradesh. The money will be sent through State Biodiversity Boards to three Biodiversity Management Committees: Sakharwadi village, Phaltan Taluk, Satara District, Maharashtra; Kunjirwadi village, Haveli Taluk, Pune; and Kasganj area, Etah District, Uttar Pradesh. Each committee will receive Rs.45.50 lakhs. This move demonstrates the government’s firm commitment to fairness, sustainability, and conservation. The payment is an Access and Benefit Sharing (ABS) payment after a company used microbes from soil and industrial waste to make fructo-oligosaccharides products. The funds will be used for activities under Section 44 of the Biological Diversity Act 2002 and related rules. This plan shows the NBA’s active role in recognizing and rewarding local communities that protect India’s biodiversity. By giving benefits back to local people, the NBA helps build a model where conservation and community prosperity grow together. It also meets India’s National Biodiversity Target 13 of the updated NBSAP 2024-2030, which matches the Kunming Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework adopted at CoP-15 of the UN Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD). ***** VM

announcements.title: Finance minister checks Karnataka Grameena Bank’s performance in Ballari
announcements.content:
On 16th October 2025, Union Minister of Finance and Corporate Affairs Smt. Nirmala Sitharaman chaired a meeting at Ballari, Karnataka to review the performance of Karnataka Grameena Bank (KaGB). Attendees included Sh. M Nagaraju, Secretary (DFS), Sh. Shaji K.V., Chairman NABARD, ED Canara Bank, and other senior officials from the Department of Financial Services and the Ministry of Finance.

During the meeting, the Finance Minister looked at key indicators such as credit growth, NPAs, the bank’s performance in financial inclusion, and how well KaGB implements government-sponsored schemes. She asked KaGB to raise its share of agriculture credit at the grassroots level, especially in emerging economic areas, and directed all stakeholders to unlock the potential of allied agriculture activities in the region. KaGB and Canara Bank were told to work with state government departments to boost credit to MSMEs and allied sectors.

The rationalisation of GST rates has opened new opportunities in rural areas because consumption has risen, signalling more bank funding, the Minister said. She urged rural banks to use this chance to meet credit needs in semi‑urban and rural areas. She noted that some FPOs receive capital from Development Financial Institutions and government departments, but banks should meet working‑capital needs. Rural banks should tailor their products and services to the convenience and demand of Farmer Producer Organisations (FPOs). This will help both banks and FPOs use their resources for mutual benefit and for the sustainable growth of the rural economy.

She also mentioned that many companies are shifting services like data‑centre services from tier‑1 to tier‑2 and tier‑3 cities. Rural banks should focus on such emerging areas to improve their financial health. KaGB must focus on its operations to become profitable and overcome challenges posed by stressed assets.

The Minister asked KaGB and its sponsor bank to collaborate with panchayat and district committees to improve the screening of applications under government schemes such as PM‑Vishwakarma and PMFME. She urged KaGB to expand its presence in the Kalyan Karnataka region by opening new branches where banking outlets are scarce. KaGB was advised to boost operational efficiency by improving asset quality, adopting new technology, and strengthening customer service.

Secretary (DFS) Sh. M Nagaraju said that after amalgamation, system and process integration is complete. He stressed KaGB’s medium‑term business plan and its review by the sponsor bank for long‑term sustainability and viability. He highlighted potential in agro‑processing and MSME in the region and urged KaGB to partner with NABARD to add value for farmers in agriculture and allied sectors. He praised KaGB’s progress in Atal Pension Yojana and suggested improving its performance in other financial inclusion schemes such as PMJJBY, PMSBY, and PMJDY. He also suggested a roadmap to partner PSBs to provide banking services in underserved areas. He emphasized the need for staff integration and skill upgrading after amalgamation. ****** NB/AD
announcements.original_title: Union Minister for Finance and Corporate Affairs Smt. Nirmala Sitharaman reviews business performance of Karnataka Grameena Bank at Ballari, Karnataka
announcements.summary:
On 16th October 2025, the Union Minister of Finance, Nirmala Sitharaman, met with officials at Ballari to discuss how Karnataka Grameena Bank (KaGB) can grow its agriculture credit and help farmers.
She urged the bank to open more branches in the Kalyan Karnataka region, use new technology, and work with schemes like PM‑Vishwakarma and PMFME to help small businesses and farmers.

announcements.title: Finance, Commerce, and Railways Ministers hold GST Bachat Utsav conference in Delhi
announcements.content:
Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman, Commerce Minister Piyush Goyal and Railways & IT Minister Ashwini Vaishnaw held a joint press conference on the GST Bachat Utsav in New Delhi today.

She said Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced at the Red Fort that the Next‑Gen GST Reforms would launch before Diwali. She added that the reforms – lower rates, simpler processes, fewer tax slabs and clear classification – were finished early. The reforms began on the first day of Navratri and people have accepted them well.

The Finance Minister explained that India started and carried out GST. The opposition never introduced GST or tried to change it. What we do now is a deliberate choice, showing cooperation between the Central Government and the GST Council to give more benefits to citizens.

Lowering tax rates helps consumers, and this is what Prime Minister Modi has asked us to do. We have followed this from 2017 to now.

She added that since September 22 the government has collected data from local levels on all goods. We have been watching the prices of 54 items closely to ensure the new tax rules help consumers. The benefits have reached all 54 items. The Revenue Department is also watching these 54 products during the transition.

Goyal thanked the Prime Minister and Finance Minister for making this year’s Navratri special with the launch of the next‑generation GST on September 22. He said the reform has brought excitement and energy to the country, to ordinary people, industry, business and households.

He called it the biggest reform since independence, saying the indirect tax system affects 140 crore Indians. The relief of Rs 2.5 lakh crore from both direct and indirect taxes is unprecedented. He noted that the big income‑tax relief announced on February 1 helped people save more and have more disposable income.

He said, guided by the Prime Minister, the Finance Minister worked on tax reforms for a year and a half, ending with the announcement on 3 September 2025.

He said the reforms are already boosting investment, business and industry, which has spurred the economy and increased consumer spending. He added that as infrastructure and daily goods become cheaper, the rise in supply and demand drives faster growth, making India the fastest‑growing large economy in the world.

Ashwini Vaishnaw said the electronics sector has grown remarkably and GST reforms have boosted consumption, investment and manufacturing. He said the economy shows strong fundamentals from record consumer demand, stable policy and a fast‑growing manufacturing base.

He added that during Navratri this year, electronics sales rose 20–25% compared to last year. Big retail chains saw record demand for TVs, washing machines, smartphones and air conditioners. 85‑inch TVs sold out completely, and many families upgraded appliances to newer models, showing higher consumer confidence and buying power.

He said GST reforms gave the economy stability, especially helping middle‑class families by keeping food inflation lower. Food prices fell about 2% in the last four months, keeping household buying power and steady demand.

Higher demand has led to double‑digit growth in electronics manufacturing, creating jobs for more than 25 lakh people.

India has also overtaken its neighbor in exporting smartphones to the United States, a huge market. A big global firm now makes 20% of its total production in India, showing India is a top manufacturing choice.

More demand leads to more investment, which then boosts demand again, creating a positive growth cycle.

He noted a key milestone: production started at two semiconductor plants – CG Semi and Kaynes – a major step toward India’s semiconductor self‑reliance. With these plants operating, India has entered a new phase in its semiconductor sector, fitting the Prime Minister’s vision of a tech‑empowered, self‑reliant country.

He said that out of India’s ₹335 lakh crore GDP last year, ₹202 lakh crore was from consumption and ₹98 lakh crore from investment.

GST reforms are clearly visible: consumption grew almost 10% this year, adding about ₹20 lakh crore to spending. This rise should also increase investment, boosting growth and showing how GST reforms strengthen the link between spending and investment.

announcements.title: DRI stops smuggling of 83,520 Chinese firecrackers at Tuticorin, arrests 4
announcements.content: To stop the illegal import of firecrackers before Deepawali, the Directorate of Revenue Intelligence (DRI) continued 'Operation Fire Trail' and seized two 40-foot containers at Tuticorin Port. The containers held 83,520 pieces of Chinese firecrackers that had been wrongly declared as engineering goods. The smuggled goods, worth ₹5.01 crore, were taken along with cover cargo of silicon sealant guns. From 14 to 18 October 2025, DRI teams arrested the importer in Tuticorin and, after investigating, also took three other people (two from Mumbai) in Chennai and Tuticorin. All four are in judicial custody for their involvement. Importing firecrackers is banned under the ITC (HS) classification in the Foreign Trade Policy and needs a licence from DGFT and PESO under the Explosive Rules, 2008. Illegal import and mis-declaration break trade and safety laws and threaten public safety and port facilities because firecrackers are highly flammable. DRI is determined to fight smuggling, protect national infrastructure, and keep the public safe. **** NB/KMN
announcements.original_title: Directorate of Revenue Intelligence (DRI) foils smuggling of 83,520 pieces of Chinese firecrackers worth ₹5.01 crore in ‘Operation Fire Trail’ at Tuticorin Port; 4 arrested
announcements.summary:
DRI stopped a smuggling of 83,520 firecrackers hidden in two containers and arrested the importer and three others.
The seized goods were worth ₹5.01 crore, and the operation shows DRI's fight against illegal firecracker import.

announcements.title: DRI stops 46,640 smuggled firecrackers at Nhava Sheva port; one arrested
announcements.content: In a major breakthrough under its ongoing "Operation Fire Trail", the Directorate of Revenue Intelligence (DRI) stopped a sophisticated smuggling attempt that involved the illegal import of Chinese fireworks and firecrackers into India. During the operation, DRI officers intercepted a 40-foot container at Nhava Sheva port, coming from China and destined for ICD Ankleshwar. The container was declared as carrying leggings. A detailed inspection revealed 46,640 pieces of firecrackers hidden behind a thin layer of clothes at the front. The entire shipment, valued at ₹4.82 crore, was seized. Further searches uncovered documents that exposed the smuggling network’s method, and a key person from Veraval, Gujarat was arrested. Importing firecrackers is ‘Restricted’ under the ITC (HS) Classification of the Foreign Trade Policy and requires valid licences from both the Directorate General of Foreign Trade (DGFT) and the Petroleum and Explosives Safety Organization (PESO) under the Explosives Rules, 2008. Illicit import of such hazardous goods poses serious risks to public safety, national security, major port infrastructure, and the wider shipping and logistics chain. The DRI remains steadfast in its mission to protect the public from dangerous contraband and uphold the integrity of the country’s trade and security ecosystem, by detecting and dismantling organized smuggling networks. **** NB/KMN
announcements.original_title: DRI seizes smuggled 46,640 pieces firecrackers worth ₹4.82 crore under “operation fire trail” at Nhava Sheva port; one arrested
announcements.summary:
The Directorate of Revenue Intelligence stopped a large smuggling of Chinese fireworks disguised as clothing at Nhava Sheva port.
46,640 firecrackers were seized, and a key smuggler from Veraval was arrested.

announcements.title: New banking law rules on nominations start 1 November 2025
announcements.content: The key changes about nominations under the Banking Laws (Amendment) Act, 2025 will start on 1st November 2025. The Act was notified on 15th April 2025 (see Gazette link). It includes 19 changes in five laws: Reserve Bank of India Act, 1934; Banking Regulation Act, 1949; State Bank of India Act, 1955; Banking Companies (Acquisition and Transfer of Undertakings) Act, 1970; and 1980. The notice says the Act will become effective on dates chosen by the Central Government via the Official Gazette, and different parts can start on different dates. The Central Government has set 1st November 2025 as the start date for Sections 10, 11, 12, and 13. The Gazette notice is available at the link below. These sections deal with nomination options for deposit accounts, safe custody items, and bank safety lockers. Key points: The new rules let depositors choose nominees as they wish, while keeping claim settlement uniform, clear, and efficient across banks. The Banking Companies (Nomination) Rules, 2025, which explain how to make, cancel, or list multiple nominees and give the required forms, will be published later to apply these rules in all banks. Earlier, the government set 1st August 2025 as the start date for Sections 3, 4, 5, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19, and 20, according to Gazette Notification S.O. 3494(E) dated 29th July 2025 (link below). The Act aims to improve governance in banks, make reporting to the RBI uniform, protect depositors and investors, raise audit quality in public sector banks, and make it easier for customers with better nomination facilities. It also changes the tenure of directors (except the Chairman and full‑time directors) in cooperative banks. Links: - Gazette Notification S.O. 4789 (E) dated 22.10.2025 https://egazette.gov.in/(S(ez1raoliuesdpfg0gurwb5uo))/ViewPDF.aspx - Gazette Notification dated 15 th April 2025 https://financialservices.gov.in/beta/sites/default/files/2025-05/Gazettee-Notification_1.pdf - Gazette Notification S.O. 3494(E) dated 29th July 2025: https://egazette.gov.in/WriteReadData/2025/265059.pdf - Earlier PIB release dated 30th July 2025: https://www.pib.gov.in/PressReleasePage.aspx?PRID=2150371 **** NB/AD
announcements.original_title: Key Provisions relating to Nomination under the Banking Laws (Amendment) Act, 2025 to come into effect from 1st November 2025
announcements.summary:
Bank rules will start on 1st November 2025, letting people choose their own nominees for bank accounts, lockers and safe‑custody items.
The new rules aim to make claim settlement clear and fair across all banks.

announcements.title: DRI breaks up drug‑making and selling network in Delhi NCR
announcements.content: The Directorate of Revenue Intelligence (DRI) has successfully stopped a large drug manufacturing and distribution network that operated across the National Capital Region. The operation ran from 21 st to 23 rd October 2025. Based on clear information from DRI, officers raided a hidden factory for making methamphetamine at a farm near tall apartment buildings in Greater Noida. They seized 11.40 kg of amphetamine and 110.923 kg of chemicals used to make it. At the same time, they caught the main organizer of the group at his house in Gurugram and found 1.33 kg of amphetamine in his possession. In a quick follow‑up, DRI officers found another location that was thought to store and sell drugs in West Delhi. The site was in a crowded and tight area, which made it hard to operate. During the raid, many people tried to stop the police. Even with aggressive people and the danger of destroying evidence, the DRI team, with help from Delhi Police, handled the situation carefully and did the search. The raid led to many arrests and the recovery of 7.79 kg of cocaine, 1.87 kg of heroin, 3.54 kg of amphetamine, 2 kg of ganja, 0.15 kg of methaqualone and 4.50 kg of chemicals used to make drugs, plus ₹37 lakh in cash that was likely from drug sales. Overall, 16.27 kg of amphetamine, 7.9 kg of cocaine, 1.8 kg of heroin, 2.13 kg of ganja and 115.42 kg of chemicals, worth about ₹108.81 crore on the illegal international market, were seized. In total, 26 foreign citizens were arrested. This tough operation, done across many areas and in hard conditions, shows DRI’s dedication to using intelligence for law enforcement, working with other agencies, and its firm determination to fight drug smuggling and fake drug production. Further investigation is underway. **** NB/KMN
announcements.original_title: DRI dismantles narcotics manufacturing and distribution network in Delhi NCR
announcements.summary:
DRI stopped a big drug network that ran from 21 st to 23 rd October 2025, raiding a hidden factory and seizing many kilos of drugs and chemicals.
26 foreign citizens were arrested, showing DRI’s strong use of intelligence and teamwork with Delhi Police.

announcements.title: State minister George Kurian will meet Kerala fishers on Oct 25, 2025
announcements.content: Shri George Kurian, Union Minister of State for Fisheries, Animal Husbandry and Dairying, will speak at two events under the ‘Fisheries Outreach and Awareness Programme’ on 25th October 2025 in Thrissur and Ernakulam districts of Kerala. The Outreach Programme aims to let fishers and fish farmers know about various welfare schemes of the Government of India that are designed to improve their living and to promote sustainable fishing practices. During the events, Hon’ble Minister of State Shri George Kurian will hand out Kisan Credit Cards (KCCs), transponders, and NFDP registration certificates. He will also talk with fishers and fish farmers from the Thrissur and Ernakulam districts to understand their problems and challenges, and to talk about ways to strengthen Kerala’s fishing and aquaculture sectors. The morning session will be held at Kodiyampuzha Devasom Hall, Nattika, Thrissur District, at 10:00 AM, and the afternoon session will take place at Njarakkal Sree Narayana Auditorium, Vypeen, Ernakulam District, at 3:30 PM. More than 500 local fishers and fish farmers are expected to join the programmes. These events will give the Minister a chance to meet directly with people in the fishing sector and to give out key benefits from the Department of Fisheries, Government of India. Background The fishing sector plays a key role in supporting the living of nearly 3 crore people across India. The country has become a global leader in fishing – ranked 2nd in overall fish production and aquaculture, and 1st in shrimp production and exports. Since the launch of targeted actions in 2015, the Government of India has committed a total investment of ₹38,572 crore to speed up sector growth. These efforts have resulted in a 103% increase in total fish production over the past decade. In Kerala, the Government of India has carried out several strategic investments to strengthen fishing infrastructure. Under the Fisheries and Aquaculture Infrastructure Development Fund (FIDF), four projects have been approved in the state, with a total project cost of ₹211.98 crore. Also, under the Pradhan Mantri Matsya Sampada Yojana (PMMSY), a central share of ₹544.59 crore has been approved for Kerala, covering a wide range of actions. These include ₹58.94 crore for building a modern wholesale fish market to improve post-harvest handling and market efficiency, and ₹36 lakh for setting up small fish feed mills with a capacity of 2 tonnes per day, supporting small fish farmers. announcements.title: Nationwide CPR Awareness Week set up to boost community response
announcements.content:
The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare held a country‑wide CPR Awareness Week from 13th to 17th October 2025 to help people understand and practice Compression‑only CPR. The goal was to make citizens aware that quick help from witnesses can save lives in heart attacks and other emergencies.

Even though CPR can save lives, the number of people who give CPR in India is below international levels. The week was meant to close this gap by offering more CPR training, spreading awareness, and encouraging people from all groups to be ready to act.

The week’s aims were to raise awareness that CPR saves lives, give hands‑on training and demos with many partners, get young people to volunteer and help communities, and use online tools to reach many people.

The week was carried out by many partners nationwide. State and Union Territory health and education departments organized local training. Central government ministries like Home Affairs, Defence, Labour & Employment, Youth Affairs, Sports, Electronics & IT, Higher Education, School Education & Literacy, Railways, Health Research, and NDMA helped reach many people. Central government hospitals, AIIMS, Institutes of National Importance, and other ministries’ institutes ran training sessions. The Indian Red Cross Society used its local centres for community CPR training. Professional bodies ran programs through their state chapters. Online outreach and youth participation were boosted by the MyGov platform of the Ministry of Electronics & IT and the MyBharat platform of the Ministry of Youth Affairs & Sports.

Many activities were held all week to get people involved. 14,701 people joined the first live pledge and CPR demo on the ECHO platform and YouTube Live. Citizens could also pledge online on MyGov, and 79,870 people signed their commitment. A panel talk on “CPR Techniques and the Role of Bystanders” had six experts from AIIMS New Delhi, Dr. RML Hospital, Safdarjung Hospital, and SGT Medical College. The session was led by the Deputy Director General of Disaster Management Cell and was seen by 10,129 viewers via ECHO and YouTube Live. They also saw a live CPR demo and how to use an Automated External Defibrillator (AED).

Across India, training in Compression‑only CPR was given by state and UT health departments, Central Government Hospitals, AIIMS, INIs, the Indian Red Cross Society, and professional bodies, teaching 6,06,374 people. At Nirman Bhawan, training for Central Government staff, CISF personnel, housekeeping staff, and ministry officials helped 264 participants. On 16th October, a special training was held for 70 Prime Minister’s Office officials.

A CPR Quiz on MyGov and MyBharat had 36,040 participants. The Volunteer for Bharat initiative had 368 youths help spread CPR awareness. The Ministry’s Media Cell ran many social media and digital actions, including an educational CPR video on the Ministry’s YouTube channel for States and UTs. Expert interviews in English and Hindi were shared on social media, explaining CPR’s technical details and its importance. Other IEC materials and event promos got high online viewership.

A live CPR demo by experts on 13th October with the Secretary (Health) was covered by news outlets like Doordarshan. A special program called “Total Health – Medical Emergency” aired on DD News on 19th October, showing live compression‑only CPR demos with AIIMS New Delhi experts on the panel.

In total, more than 7,47,000 citizens were reached during the week, and over 6,06,374 people received hands‑on training.

***** SR HFW-Report on CPR Awareness Week /22nd Oct 2025/1

announcements.title: Health Secretary launches training on handling chemical emergencies
announcements.content: Chemical emergencies are a growing risk to people's health, the environment, and society. They show that we need stronger national readiness and response. In our fast growing industrial economy, staying prepared for such emergencies is essential. To improve readiness, the Secretary of Health and Family Welfare and senior officials from ministries, national agencies, experts from the private sector, industry and academia released modules on Public Health Management of Chemical Emergencies today at Nirman Bhawan, New Delhi. The National Centre for Disease Control (NCDC), Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW) of India, with the National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA) and technical help from World Health Organization (WHO India), created three training modules: Module 1: Preparedness, Surveillance, and Response for Public Health Management of Chemical Emergencies; Module 2: Pre-Hospital Management of Chemical Emergencies; Module 3: Medical Management of Chemical Emergencies. These modules give public health workers, healthcare staff, emergency responders, and policymakers the skills, knowledge, and tools needed to manage chemical incidents quickly and effectively. Strengthening chemical emergency management also helps meet the core capacities of the International Health Regulations (IHR 2005) and supports national and global health security. The launch event brought together officials from the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, NDMA, central government ministries, central institutions, academia, the WHO Country Office for India, and other partners to reaffirm the commitment to building a “Self-reliant Resilient Nation”. *** SR HFW- Launch of Training Modules/23 rd Oct 2025/1

announcements.title: Defense Minister Rajnath Singh honors fallen police on Oct 21
announcements.content: Raksha Mantri Shri Rajnath Singh will honour the martyrs on Police Commemoration Day at the National Police Memorial in New Delhi on Tuesday, 21st October 2025. On 21 October 1959, ten brave police officers died when Chinese troops ambushed them at Hot Springs, Ladakh. Since that day, 21 October has been Police Commemoration Day every year. To recognise the sacrifices of police and their key role in keeping the country safe, the Prime Minister dedicated the National Police Memorial (NPM) in Chanakyapuri, New Delhi to the nation on Police Commemoration Day 2018. The memorial gives police a sense of national identity, pride, unity, shared history, and purpose, and strengthens their promise to protect the nation even if it costs them their lives. The memorial has a central sculpture, the "Wall of Valour", and a museum. The 30‑foot high granite statue, a cenotaph, shows strength, resilience, and self‑less service of police. The Wall of Valour engraves the names of those who died, showing respect for their bravery and sacrifice since independence. The museum displays the history of policing in India and continues to grow. The memorial is a place of pilgrimage, a place where police and citizens alike can pay tribute. The National Police Memorial is open to the public every day except Monday. CAPFs hold a band display, parade, and retreat ceremony at the memorial every Saturday and Sunday evening, starting one hour before sunset. Police Commemoration Day, 21 October, is observed nationwide to honour police martyrs. The main ceremony is held at the memorial in New Delhi. Raksha Mantri Shri Rajnath Singh will lead the ceremony and honour the martyrs. A joint parade of Central Armed Police Forces (CAPFs) and Delhi Police will take place. Raksha Mantri, the Union Minister of State for Home Affairs, MPs with police background, heads of CAPFs/CPOs, and others will honour the martyrs by laying wreaths. Retired DGs, police officers, and other dignitaries will also attend. Besides honouring the martyrs, Raksha Mantri will speak to the assembly, remember the fallen, and outline policing challenges. The program ends with Raksha Mantri laying a wreath at the altar for the martyrs of Hot Springs. The event will be broadcast live on Doordarshan, webcast on police websites, and covered by AIR and the media. As part of the remembrance, CAPFs/CPOs organise various commemorative events at the memorial from 22 to 30 October, including visits by families of martyrs, police band display, motorcycle rallies, runs for the martyrs, blood donation camps, essay and painting contests for children, and shows of videos about sacrifice, bravery and police services. Similar programs are held by all police forces across the country during this period. National Police Memorial Chanakyapuri, New Delhi **** RK/AK/PS/PR

announcements.title: Home Minister Amit Shah releases 1950.80 crore early to Karnataka and Maharashtra

Under the leadership of Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi and the guidance of Union Home Minister and Minister of Cooperation Shri Amit Shah, the Central Government is fully committed to provide all possible assistance to states hit by floods, landslides and cloudbursts. This year, the Centre has already released Rs.13,603.20 crore to 27 states under the SDRF and Rs.2,189.28 crore under the NDRF to 15 states. Additionally, Rs.4,571.30 crore has been released from the State Disaster Mitigation Fund (SDMF) to 21 states and Rs.372.09 crore from the National Disaster Mitigation Fund (NDMF) to 09 states. The Central Government has also supplied all logistic help, including deploying the necessary NDRF teams, Army teams and Air Force support to all states affected by floods, landslides and cloudbursts. announcements.title: 14th India‑Bhutan border meeting held in Thimphu
announcements.content: The 14th India‑Bhutan Meeting on Border Management and Security was held in Thimphu, Bhutan from October 16–17, 2025. The Indian delegation included officials from the Sashastra Seema Bal, Land Ports Authority of India, Department of Telecommunications, Narcotics Control Bureau, Survey of India, Customs and representatives from Assam, West Bengal, Sikkim, and Arunachal Pradesh. Both delegations said they were happy with the friendly and productive talks and promised to keep working together to make the border area safe, secure and prosperous. Reaffirming their strong friendship, India and Bhutan pledged to strengthen cooperation in traditional and new areas. Their long‑standing partnership, based on shared geography, culture and people ties, remains a model for regional cooperation. The last meeting was in 2019. ***** RK/RR/PY/PR

announcements.title: Rashtriya Ekta Diwas marks Sardar Patel’s birthday on Oct 31
announcements.content: Rashtriya Ekta Diwas is observed every year on 31 st October to remember the birth of Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, called the Iron Man of India. It represents India’s unity, integrity and national solidarity. This year’s observance is especially important as it marks the 150th birth anniversary of Sardar Patel. The celebrations this year are different in many ways and will be memorable. They remind people of Sardar Patel’s key role in creating an independent India and bringing together 562 princely states, which laid the foundation of modern India. Because of his leadership and steady commitment to national unity, Sardar Patel is admired as the "Architect of National Unity and the Iron Man of India." Ekta Nagar, located between the Satpura and Vindhyachal ranges, shows the idea of "Unity in Diversity" by mixing natural beauty and cultural richness. This year’s special events will include a grand parade and cultural festival in Ekta Nagar, Narmada district, Gujarat. During the parade, the Central Armed Police Forces (CAPFs) and state police will show their skills, discipline and bravery. The National Unity Day parade will have groups from the Border Security Force (BSF), Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF), Central Industrial Security Force (CISF), Indo-Tibetan Border Police (ITBP) and Sashastra Seema Bal (SSB) and police from Assam, Tripura, Odisha, Chhattisgarh, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Punjab, Jammu & Kashmir, Kerala, Andhra Pradesh and the NCC. It will also feature cavalry, camel teams, dog demonstrations, martial arts and unarmed combat drills. Women police officers and staff will also take part. The Guard of Honour for the Prime Minister will be led by a female officer. Women from CISF and CRPF will show martial arts and unarmed combat, proving the strength and courage of India’s daughters. The parade will also have a marching team with only Indian breed dogs of the BSF, the Gujarat Police Horse Contingent, the Assam Police Motorcycle Daredevil Show and the BSF Camel Contingent and Camel Mounted Band, which will attract many viewers. Indigenous dog breeds – Rampur Hounds and Mudhol Hounds – will display their skills. These breeds have helped the BSF in many operations and show the spirit of Aatmanirbhar Bharat. At the All India Police Dog Competition, the Mudhol Hound "Riya" won first place and will lead the dog squad at this year’s parade. Cadets of the National Cadet Corps (NCC) and school bands will add to the ceremony with striking performances. Young NCC cadets will share the message "Unity is Strength" through their discipline and enthusiasm. The Indian Air Force’s Surya Kiran Team will perform a spectacular air show. Tableaux from different states and union territories will also be part of the parade to show unity in diversity. There will be 10 tableaux from the National Security Guard (NSG), NDRF, Gujarat, Jammu & Kashmir, Andaman & Nicobar Islands, Manipur, Maharashtra, Chhattisgarh, Uttarakhand and Puducherry, all with the theme "Unity in Diversity." Brass bands from BSF, CRPF, CISF, SSB, Delhi Police, Maharashtra, Madhya Pradesh, Gujarat and Jammu & Kashmir will also play. Five Shaurya Chakra winners from CRPF and 16 gallantry medal winners from BSF will be seen in the parade. They showed great courage in anti‑Naxal operations in Jharkhand and counter‑terror operations in Jammu & Kashmir. BSF personnel also showed bravery during Operation Sindoor on the western border. Beside the parade, a cultural program organized by the Ministry of Culture, GoI, will showcase 900 artists performing India’s classical dances, highlighting the rich diversity of our culture and national unity. The Rashtriya Ekta Diwas celebrations aim to highlight the spirit of national unity, harmony and patriotism, inspiring people to accept these values. All citizens are encouraged to join and be part of this grand and auspicious celebration. From November 1 to 15, 2025, Ekta Nagar will host the Bharat Parv, featuring cultural performances and a food festival from different states. The festival will end on November 15 with special programs celebrating God Birsa Munda Jayanti, highlighting the glorious culture and resilient spirit of our tribal communities. ***** RK / RR / PS

announcements.title: Union minister checks PM SVANidhi scheme progress with states, UTs, banks
announcements.content: The Union Minister of Housing and Urban Affairs, Shri Manohar Lal, led a review meeting on the PM SVANidhi Scheme with representatives from 33 States and Union Territories, senior officials from MoHUA and DFS, and major banks/SLBC conveners in New Delhi today. The meeting followed the Cabinet’s approval to restructure and extend the scheme. The minister talked with State Urban Development Ministers, Principal Secretaries, Mission Directors, DFS officials, and senior banking leaders to check each state’s progress and solve operational problems. He urged States, UTs and banks to speed up awareness, find eligible street vendors, quickly handle returned applications, and faster approve and pay pending loans. The minister said it is important to help street vendors move from the first loan tranche to the second, and then to the third, so they gain better credit and more livelihood options. He also stressed the need to onboard beneficiaries digitally to achieve 100% coverage and active digital use, and ordered that all street food vendors get Hygiene and Food Safety training through FSSAI. To boost the scheme, the minister announced a month‑long national drive, ‘SVANidhi Sankalp Abhiyaan’, from 3 rd November to 2 nd December 2025, to improve outreach and speed up application processing by ULBs and banks. The minister reaffirmed the government’s promise to provide timely credit to street vendors and to ensure effective implementation of PM SVANidhi with States, UTs, ULBs and banks.

announcements.title: Mines ministry sets faster deadlines to start auctioned mineral blocks
announcements.content: The Ministry of Mines has issued an amendment to the Mineral (Auction) Rules, 2015. It sets intermediate deadlines for tasks that must be finished after the Letter of Intent (LoI) is issued and before the mining lease is signed. Since the auction system started in 2015, 585 major mineral blocks have been sold, including 34 blocks that the Central government sold. At first, auctions were slow, but in the last three years more than 100 blocks a year have been sold on average. In the first seven months of this year, 112 blocks have already been sold. To match the higher number of auctions, the mines that have been sold must be started quickly to boost mineral output. To do this, the Ministry has taken steps such as regular meetings with the successful bidders, state governments and other stakeholders. It has also set up a PMU to monitor the start‑up of mines. On 17.10.2025, the Ministry released the amendment, adding intermediate deadlines for tasks between the LoI and the lease. Before the amendment, the rules only gave a general period of three years (which could be extended by two more years) to sign the lease from the LoI date. Missing this deadline would cancel the block’s auction. But there was no way to check progress during the stages between the LoI and the lease. So there were few chances for corrections. The new rules now impose intermediate deadlines, and delays will lead to penalties. The penalties are kept reasonable. If the final deadline is met on time, any earlier penalties can be reduced from the auction premium to be paid. The main goal is to get the mine operating on time, not to punish. The amendment also offers rewards for early start‑up. It aims to stop bidders from holding onto blocks without doing work. Key points of the rule change are: - These amendments were made after talking with all relevant stakeholders. ***** Shuhaib T

announcements.title: Push to get critical minerals from recycling
announcements.content: The Union Cabinet on 3rd September 2025 approved a ₹1,500 crore incentive scheme for recycling critical minerals. The scheme, part of the National Critical Mineral Mission, aims to give a simple way to keep the supply chain steady in the near future. After talks with stakeholders, the Ministry of Mines released detailed guidelines on 2nd October 2025. The application process for the incentive started on 2nd October 2025. Stakeholders welcomed the quick launch and are actively working with the Ministry. Eligible materials include e‑waste, used lithium‑ion batteries (LIBs), and other scrap such as catalytic converters from old vehicles. Estimates say the country generates about 1.75 million tonnes of e‑waste and about 60 thousand tonnes of used LIBs each year. Customs duty is removed on LIB scrap under the Union Budget 2025‑26, making imports easier. In the next 4‑5 years, the availability of these wastes will grow a lot. Feedstock is also being secured by formalising collection under the Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) framework and by integrating waste into the recycling system with help from government agencies. Under EPR, e‑waste and battery rules require the extraction of specified end products. Still, the country’s capacity to process black mass or powder is limited, so these are exported before the valuable minerals are extracted. The scheme will give incentives to the part of the recycling chain that actually extracts critical minerals, not just to those that produce black mass. This will bring more recyclers, especially dismantlers, crushers and shredders, into the formal system. Many private companies already run efficient scrap collection. Very few companies do full battery scrap to metal recycling (R4). The scheme encourages wider participation and aims to bring more beneficiaries. The total incentive is capped at ₹50 crore for large recyclers and ₹25 crore for small recyclers. The scheme will help increase capacity in recycling using processes like hydrometallurgy. Proven end‑to‑end recycling technologies exist in the country. Top institutes such as IITs, CSIR and other research labs have developed and shown local capabilities in metal extraction, recycling and purification. Some of these institutes also provide training in mineral processing, beneficiation and extractive metallurgy. Any skill needs can be met through partnerships with these institutions. The Ministry of Mines is working closely with the private sector to build enough capacity in the country to fully use e‑waste and recover critical minerals in a few years. **** Shuhaib T
announcements.original_title: A strong push for critical mineral extraction from recycling
announcements.summary:
The Union Cabinet on 3rd September 2025 approved a ₹1,500 crore incentive scheme for recycling critical minerals.
The scheme will give money to recyclers who pull minerals out of e‑waste and used batteries and will help grow the country’s recycling capacity.

announcements.title: India shifts renewable focus from speed to strong systems for development
announcements.content:
India's renewable energy sector is moving into a new stage that focuses on the quality of its systems, not just how fast capacity grows. After ten years of rapid growth, the focus is now on building a strong, controllable, and reliable clean‑energy system that can help India reach its goal of 500 GW of non‑fossil power by 2030. The Ministry of New and Renewable Energy (MNRE) says India’s renewable growth is still one of the fastest worldwide, moving from just speed to strong systems, from numbers to quality, and from growth to lasting integration.

A Shift from Quantity to Quality

In the past ten years, India’s renewable capacity has grown more than five times, from below 35 GW in 2014 to over 197 GW today (not counting large hydro). Such fast growth eventually reaches a point where the next jump needs more than just power; it needs deeper system changes. The sector is now in that phase, where the focus is moving from adding power to using it. We are now dealing with grid integration, energy storage, mixing different sources, and market reforms—these are the real bases for a future with more than 500 GW of non‑fossil power. So, the recent slowdown in adding capacity is a reset—a needed pause so that future growth is steady, controllable, and strong.

India’s RE Growth Remains Among the Fastest in the World, Driven by Multi‑Pathway Expansion

More than 40 GW of awarded renewable projects are now in late stages of getting PPAs, PSAs, or transmission links—showing the sector has a strong pipeline of committed investment. The truth is that India’s renewable market has grown faster than its grid and contractual systems, a common problem for countries going through big energy changes. In this context, enforcing the Renewable Power Purchase Obligation by states and DISCOMs, upgrading transmission lines to move power, and using technology to integrate the grid are top priorities before moving forward with big renewable bids.

In the current year, Central Renewable Energy Implementing agencies (REIAs) have done bids for 5.6 GW, while State agencies have done bids for 3.5 MW. Additionally Commercial and Industrial Consumers are likely to add nearly 6 GW of renewable energy capacity in calendar year 2025. Thus, capacity addition of RE is progressing through multiple pathways and not necessarily through REIA led bids alone. Global headwinds have also played a role: supply‑chain disruptions, fluctuating module prices, and tighter financing conditions have slowed commissioning timelines. Yet India continues to add 15–25 GW of new renewable capacity annually—a rate that remains among the fastest in the world.

A Deliberate Policy Pivot

Over the past two years, policy attention has consciously shifted from pure capacity growth to system design. Tenders for RE power with energy storage or peak power supply now dominate auctions, signaling a move toward firm and dispatchable green power. Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) are being integrated at both grid and project levels, marking the emergence of a new market. Domestic manufacturing, incentivised through the Production‑Linked Incentive (PLI) scheme, Domestic Content Requirement, imposition of duties, implementation of ALMM, and duty exemptions for capital equipment, is reducing import dependency and creating industrial depth. In addition, the recalibration of GST structures and ALMM provisions represents a strategic consolidation phase, aligning fiscal policy with the twin objectives of domestic value chain depth and technology assurance. Far from being disruptive, these adjustments are designed to stabilise costs, enhance module reliability, and promote scale efficiencies in India’s maturing solar manufacturing ecosystem.

Concurrently, the trajectory of battery storage deployment is advancing through viability gap‑funded projects, sovereign tenders, and emerging storage obligations, establishing the foundation for firm, dispatchable renewable capacity. These measures signal a shift from expansion‑led growth to a more resilient, quality‑driven, and system‑integrated renewable energy architecture. Such transitions take time to yield visible capacity figures, but they represent lasting structural progress—the kind that underpins a robust energy future.

Transmission Reforms Poised to Unlock Over 200 GW of Renewable Potential

Transmission has emerged as the new frontier. India’s grid is being reimagined through the ₹2.4 lakh crore Transmission Plan for 500 GW, linking renewable‑rich states with demand centres. The Government is prioritizing investment in transmission infrastructure through the Green Energy Corridors and new high‑capacity transmission lines from Rajasthan, Gujarat, and Ladakh. While these projects are multi‑year efforts, once operational they will unlock over 200 GW of new renewable capacity. The current stage is therefore temporary—a transition lag, not a structural ceiling.

Government has already planned for building HVDC corridors and boosting inter‑regional transmission capacity from 120 GW today to 143 GW by 2027, and 168 GW by 2032. Additionally, the recent amendments to the CERC General Network Access (GNA) Regulations, 2025 have significantly improved the outlook for transmission readiness. The introduction of time‑segmented access—solar‑hours and non‑solar‑hours—allows dynamic sharing of corridors between solar, wind, and storage projects, unlocking idle capacity and easing congestion in RE‑rich states. Provisions for source flexibility, stricter connectivity norms, and greater substation‑level transparency further streamline grid access and curb speculative allocations. These reforms mark a decisive step toward optimising transmission utilisation and fast‑tracking stranded renewable projects, directly addressing one of the sector’s core implementation challenges.

India Remains a Magnet for Clean Energy Capital

Despite short‑term delays, India remains a magnet for clean energy capital. Renewable tariffs continue to be among the lowest globally, ensuring long‑term competitiveness. India continues to be one of the most attractive destinations for investment in the clean energy sector, and international interest remains high. Global investors are not exiting India; they are repositioning towards integrated and storage‑backed portfolios. The sector’s fundamentals—strong demand growth, policy continuity, and cost competitiveness—remain firmly intact.

The Real RE Story: From Expansion to Integration

The deeper story is one of evolution, not erosion. India’s clean energy transition is entering a phase where the core challenges are about integration, reliability, and scale efficiency. A temporary flattening of the project pipeline in this context is a mark of maturity. The sector is doing the harder work now—synchronising renewables with grid infrastructure, financial discipline, and long‑term market design.

To complement physical grid expansion, Virtual Power Purchase Agreements (VPPAs) and other market‑based instruments will play a pivotal role in accelerating renewable energy deployment. VPPAs allow corporate and institutional buyers to contract renewable power virtually—decoupling procurement from physical delivery—thereby deepening demand, providing price certainty to developers, and stimulating private investment in projects awaiting grid connectivity. Coupled with green attribute trading, market‑based ancillary services, and day‑ahead and real‑time market integration, these instruments will create a robust ecosystem for flexible, demand‑driven renewable growth. Such mechanisms are in the process of being strategically incorporated under the Electricity (Amendment) Bill or through CERC market regulations, with enabling policy support from MNRE and MoP, to align corporate procurement, grid flexibility, and national decarbonisation targets.

Looking Ahead

The next phase of growth is already taking shape: These are the levers that will propel India toward its 2030 targets—not by sheer speed, but by strategic endurance.

Viksit Bharat: A Renewable Energy Transition Growing Up

India’s clean energy transition is not defined by quarterly numbers but by institutional durability and stickability. After a decade of sprinting, the sector is learning to move forward by synchronising capacity with grid strength, local manufacturing, and financial stability. India’s RE journey is, in a phase of consolidation—one that ensures that when the next acceleration comes, it will be both faster and far more sustainable. India’s renewable story has not lost momentum. It has gained maturity.

*** Navin Sreejith
announcements.original_title: India Reframes Its Renewable Revolution: The Next Big Leap from Speed to System Strength for Viksit Bharat
announcements.type: Ministry of New and Renewable Energy
announcements.summary:
India is moving from just growing renewable power fast to making the power system strong, reliable and ready for 500 GW of clean energy by 2030.
The focus is now on quality, integration, grid upgrades and storage so the growth is steady and sustainable.

announcements.title: Centre gives ₹730 crore grants to rural bodies in Gujarat, Haryana
announcements.content: The Union Government released XV Finance Commission (XV FC) Grants in the Financial Year 2025–26 to support Rural Local Bodies (RLBs) in Gujarat and Haryana. In Gujarat, the second installment of Untied Grants for the Financial Year 2024–25, worth ₹522.20 crores, was released to all 38 District Panchayats, 247 eligible Block Panchayats, and 14,547 eligible Gram Panchayats. An additional ₹13.5989 crores of the withheld portion of the first installment of Untied Grants for FY 2024–25 was released to 6 more District Panchayats, 5 Block Panchayats and 78 Gram Panchayats. In Haryana, the Union Government released the first installment of Untied Grants for FY 2025–26, amounting to ₹195.129 crores, for 18 District Panchayats, 134 eligible Block Panchayats, and 6,164 Gram Panchayats. The Government of India, through the Ministry of Panchayati Raj and the Ministry of Jal Shakti (Department of Drinking Water and Sanitation), recommends that XV-FC Grants be released to states for Panchayati Raj Institutions / Rural Local Bodies, which are then released by the Ministry of Finance. The grants are recommended and released in two installments each financial year. The Untied Grants are to be used by PRIs/RLBs for local needs under the Twenty‑Nine (29) subjects in the Eleventh Schedule of the Constitution, except for salaries and other establishment costs. The Tied Grants may be used for basic services such as (a) sanitation and maintaining ODF status, including managing and treating household waste, human excreta, and fecal sludge, and (b) providing drinking water, harvesting rainwater, and recycling water.

This short film will be shown nationwide in cinemas, following the Rules for Public Service Awareness Films, except in states where the Model Code of Conduct is in effect. announcements.title: Special Campaign 5.0 boosts decision speed in Personnel & Training
announcements.content: In line with the Hon'ble Prime Minister’s vision to make cleanliness a core policy and improve work efficiency, the Department of Personnel & Training (DoPT) and its attached and subordinate organizations are actively taking part in the main phase of Special Campaign 5.0. The campaign started on 2nd October and will run until 31st October 2025. It aims to bring clear improvements in cleanliness and cut delays in office work. All officers in the Department and its attached and subordinate offices across the country have enthusiastically participated. So far, more than 585 cleanliness sites have been covered. A large awareness drive on Social Media, with many tweets and posts on X and Facebook under #SpecialCampaign 5.0, has attracted a lot of attention. During the campaign, focus has been on improving the work environment and enhancing the office experience for staff. The Department of Personnel and Training recently moved from North Block to Kartavya Bhawan 3 in Delhi. The modern office space helps officers and staff interact better, bond, and work together more cohesively. Records Management: Since the start of Special Campaign 5.0 on 02 October, 2025, over 52,112 physical files and over 2,474 e-files have been reviewed, and 20,391 files were removed. Completed e-files have been closed. In addition, overall cleanliness of government offices was improved, focusing on space management and enhancing the workplace experience at field offices. Sixteen cleanliness campaigns were conducted to clean DoPT offices and its attached and subordinate offices. Disposal of waste and scrap has generated Rs. 2,80,890/- in revenue so far. About 8228 Sq. ft. of space has been freed by disposing of scrap and removing files. During this period, 350 public grievances, 105 grievance appeals, 15 MP references, 1 inter-ministry reference (Cabinet Proposal), and 7 PMO references were replied to and disposed. Special activities and events: The Department has also carried out various activities during Special Campaign 5.0 to promote cleanliness and quickly resolve pending issues. The campaign raises awareness about keeping a clean office environment, boosts productivity, speeds up decision-making, and encourages sustainable development and environmental protection. The Department of Personnel & Training is committed to achieving the targets set in the preparatory phase and to make the campaign a great success. ***** NKR/AK

announcements.title: Haldia terminal handed to PPP operator IRC Natural Resources
announcements.content: The Inland Waterways Authority of India (IWAI) under the Ministry of Ports, Shipping and Waterways has handed over the Haldia Multi‑Modal Terminal (MMT) to IRC Natural Resources. This is an important step in the Indian government’s effort to improve inland waterways and support multimodal logistics through a Public‑Private Partnership (PPP). IWAI built the terminal with financial and technical help from the World Bank. The Haldia MMT in West Bengal can handle 3.08 million metric tonnes of cargo each year. Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi opened the terminal on 13 January 2023. The terminal is located near National Highway 41 and will soon get rail links, making it easier to move goods by road, rail and water. To run the terminal smoothly, IWAI used a PPP model based on Equip, Operate and Transfer (EOT). The company that will run the terminal was chosen through a public bidding process for Operation and Maintenance (O&M) for 10 years, with an option to extend for another 5 years. IRC Natural Resources won the bid with a royalty of ₹105.03 per tonne of cargo that it handles, paid to IWAI. The start of operations at Haldia MMT is expected to move more cargo on inland waterways, giving a cheaper, greener, and faster way to ship goods, especially to the North Eastern states and Bangladesh. This project fits the government’s goal of making Inland Water Transport (IWT) a reliable and efficient logistics option under the Jal Marg Vikas Project (JMVP). The JMVP aims to expand the 1,390 km stretch of National Waterway‑1 (Ganga–Bhagirathi–Hooghly river system) that goes through Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Jharkhand and West Bengal. Under JMVP, IWAI has carried out key work such as keeping the fairways clean, building multi‑modal and inter‑modal terminals, installing modern navigation locks, and adding more than 60 jetties to help river communities. *** GDH/PN/DS

announcements.content:
Union Minister for Railways, Information & Broadcasting, and Electronics & Information Technology, Shri Ashwini Vaishnaw, visited the War Room at the Railway Board in New Delhi today and reviewed passenger movement during the festive season.
Shri Vaishnaw said war rooms have been set up at the division, zone, and railway board levels. He said the board receives live feeds from all locations. He added that mini control rooms have also been established at major stations. This monitoring system allows real‑time coordination across the country about the status of every station, the need for extra trains, and other operational needs.
War rooms have been set up at the division, zone, and railway board level. The board receives feeds from everywhere. Mini control rooms have also been created at major stations. To handle the large number of travelers, waiting areas with all necessary passenger facilities have been set up at major stations such as New Delhi, Anand Vihar Terminal, Udhna, Pune, Mumbai, Bengaluru, and others.

Extra coaches are being added to existing services to meet the higher demand.
Weather‑proof waiting areas are being built at major stations to handle large passenger flows and offer convenient waiting spaces before train departures.
Some stations where waiting areas are being set up include Patna, Danapur, Rajendra Nagar Terminal, Saharsa, Darbhanga, Muzaffarpur, Gaya, Samastipur, Barauni in Bihar and Gorakhpur, Ballia, and Banaras in Uttar Pradesh.

Passenger help booths, information counters, queue management systems and public announcement systems have been improved.
Cleanliness, lighting, and sanitation at all major stations are closely monitored.
Dedicated war rooms at the Railway Board, Zonal, and Divisional levels work around the clock to monitor and coordinate operations, ensuring quick responses to passenger needs.

At stations like Patna, Muzaffarpur, Darbhanga, Gaya, Saharsa, etc., 24/7 medical booths have been set up to deal with any passenger health emergencies.

announcements.title: NHAI Will Use Survey Vehicles on 20,000 km of National Roads
announcements.content: To improve how people travel on national highways, NHAI will use Network Survey Vehicles (NSV) in 23 states over 20,933 km. These vehicles will collect, process, and analyze data about road inventory and pavement condition. The NSVs will gather important information such as surface cracks, potholes, and patches. The data will show road problems, allowing NHAI to fix them and keep highways in better shape. Data from NSV surveys will be uploaded to NHAI’s ‘AI’ based portal called Data Lake. Experts will turn the data into useful knowledge and actionable advice. Data collected regularly, following government rules, will be saved for future use in the Road Asset Management system in the required formats. Pavement surveys will use a 3D laser based NSV system that can automatically detect and report road defects without human help. It uses high‑resolution 360‑degree cameras, DGPS, IMU, and DMI. The system has flexible software to precisely measure and report inventory and pavement data. Data will be collected for all projects with 2, 4, 6, or 8 lanes using NSV before work starts and then every six months. To run this program, NHAI has invited bids from qualified companies. The NSV system is a special tool that uses vehicles with advanced sensors and data tools. These vehicles gather information on road inventory and condition on national highways. The data helps make decisions on pavement maintenance, asset management, and planning, improving safety and efficiency across the country. *** GDH/PN/DS

announcements.title: NHAI will display pass details at toll booths for highway users
announcements.content: To improve transparency and inform users about the Local Monthly Pass and Annual Pass at fee plazas, NHAI has asked its field offices to put clear information about these passes at every fee plaza on National Highways managed by NHAI. The goal is to make sure users know where to find the passes, their costs, and how to get them. Signs will be placed in visible spots like near the fee plaza entry, customer service, and gates. The signs will be in English, Hindi, and local languages. Offices must put up the boards within 30 days and keep them visible day and night as per the rules. The information will also be posted on the Rajmargyatra mobile app and NHAI project websites. Highway users can use different passes that help make travel cheaper and easier. The passes include the Local Monthly Pass for drivers with private vehicles who live within 20 km (or as specified) of a fee plaza. To get a Local Monthly Pass, you need an Aadhar card, Vehicle Registration Certificate, proof of address, and other documents listed at all fee plazas. The pass is issued at the fee plaza helpdesk after documents are checked. The Annual Pass is for one year or 200 crossings, for private vehicles like cars, jeeps, vans. It can be bought on the Rajmargyatra App and is activated on the FASTag attached to the vehicle after a one‑time fee of Rs. 3,000. The Annual Pass works at about 1,150 fee plazas on National Highways and Expressways across the country. By putting clear information on fee plazas, NHAI shows it wants to improve user experience, make travel cheaper, and increase transparency in toll operations.

announcements.title: India creates first homegrown antibiotic 'Nafithromycin' for tough lung infections
announcements.content: Union Minister of State Dr. Jitendra Singh announced that India has made its first home‑grown antibiotic called Nafithromycin. It helps treat lung infections that are hard to cure, and it is especially useful for people with cancer or diabetes that is not well controlled. He said it is the first drug that was fully imagined, made, and tested in India, showing how India can become more self‑sufficient in medicine. The drug was made by the Government of India's Department of Biotechnology together with the well‑known private company Wockhardt. Dr. Singh said this example shows how industry and universities can work together to grow India’s drug industry. He stressed the need to build an innovation system that can run on its own, so India does not need as much government money and can rely more on the private sector and charity to gain worldwide recognition in research. At the start of a 3‑day medical workshop on "Using AI to Combine and Study Big Biological Data", Dr. Singh said India must build a self‑sufficient research ecosystem. He explained that countries that are leaders in science do so by creating models that use private investment and cooperation. He also announced that India has a big win in gene therapy. It was the first successful Indian clinical test for treating Hemophilia, carried out by the Department of Biotechnology in a private hospital, Christian Medical College Vellore. Dr. Singh added that India has already read 10,000 human genomes and wants to reach one million. The gene therapy test showed a 60–70% success rate and no bleeding incidents, a major step in India’s medical research. The results were published in the New England Journal of Medicine, showing India’s growing leadership in advanced medicine. Speaking at the event, Dr. Singh said the Anusandhan National Research Foundation (ANRF) is a big step, with ₹50,000 crore planned over five years, of which ₹36,000 crore comes from non‑government sources. This shows a big change in how India does research, making it more like global standards and involving more universities and businesses. He highlighted that Artificial Intelligence (AI) is a powerful tool today, changing how healthcare is given, how government works, and how decisions are made. AI mobile clinics are already helping rural areas get good care. He also mentioned the AI system for complaints made by the Department of Administrative Reforms and Public Grievances (DARPG), which resolves complaints 97–98% each week, making people happier and improving service. The Minister praised places like Sir Ganga Ram Hospital for using AI, biotechnology, and genetics together to improve health. He urged more cooperation between government, hospitals, and research institutes to achieve the vision of Viksit Bharat @2047. Dr. Singh said India is entering a new era of independence in biotechnology, AI and genetic medicine. He said that combining innovation, teamwork and care will guide India to become a developed country and lead the world in science and technology. The event also had Dr. Shiv Kumar Kalyanaraman, CEO of ANRF, Dr. N.K. Ganguly, Dr. D.S. Rana, and Dr. Ajay Swaroop. **** NKR/AK/SK

announcements.title: National workshop trains teachers on sharing Indian knowledge system
announcements.content: CSIR‑National Institute of Science Communication and Policy Research (NIScPR) held a national workshop for teachers on "Communication and Dissemination of Indian Knowledge Systems" under the national program SVASTIK (Scientifically Validated Societal Traditional Knowledge). The workshop was organized together with the Indian National Young Academy of Science (INYAS) through its main program RuSETUp (Rural Science Education Training Utility Programme) and Maharshi Dayanand University (MDU), Rohtak, on 16th October 2025 at MDU, Rohtak. Over 100 teachers from 75 institutions attended the workshop. The event began with a welcome speech by Dr Surender Yadav of MDU and an opening address by Dr Geetha Vani Rayasam, Director of CSIR‑NIScPR, who joined online. She introduced SVASTIK and praised the cooperation of CSIR‑NIScPR, INYAS, and MDU in spreading IKS to regional schools and teachers. Padma Bhushan Dr Anil P. Joshi, Chief Guest and founder of the Himalayan Environmental Studies and Conservation Organization (HESCO), Dehradun, gave a motivational keynote. He talked about how the economy, ecology, and environment are linked and said that Indian traditional knowledge has always focused on sustainability and self‑reliance. He urged teachers to teach science through India’s traditional knowledge. Prof Rajbir Singh, Vice‑Chancellor of MDU, praised the joint work of CSIR‑NIScPR, INYAS, and MDU in promoting interdisciplinary IKS projects. He said that teachers are the first step in sharing knowledge because they can change society. The vote of thanks was delivered by Dr Charu Lata, SVASTIK coordinator, who thanked all leaders, organizers, and participants for their help. She acknowledged the teamwork of CSIR‑NIScPR, INYAS, and MDU in creating a good platform for sharing knowledge. The first technical session, titled "India’s science & technology heritage: From protection to perpetuation", focused on India’s rich and diverse scientific heritage and how it continues today. Prof Ranjana Aggarwal, an eminent organic chemist, outstanding scientist of CSIR and former director of CSIR‑NIScPR, stressed that a broad view that blends natural, social, and spiritual sciences is the core of India’s scientific heritage. She warned that false information often misrepresents traditional knowledge online and highlighted the need for clear communication, scientific proof, and educational inclusion. She mentioned projects that record and validate traditional practices in several languages, such as CSIR‑NIScPR’s SVASTIK project, the Ministry of AYUSH, AICTE’s IKS divisions, and NEP 2020. Dr Ashwani Tiwari, Associate Professor at JNU’s School of Environmental Sciences, gave an engaging talk on the importance of traditional rainwater harvesting for India’s water shortage. He encouraged teachers to add this traditional water knowledge to their lessons. Dr Charu Lata, principal scientist of CSIR‑NIScPR, gave a talk on India’s traditional food knowledge. She explained the step‑by‑step process of SVASTIK, from finding and checking traditional practices to sharing them with the public through digital and social media. She invited participants to become "Brand Ambassadors of SVASTIK" by sharing local examples of traditional knowledge from their regions. She said that teachers and researchers who link traditional knowledge with verified science are the best at communicating science. The second session began with hands‑on training on how to share traditional knowledge, led by Dr Paramananda Barman, senior scientist and the SVASTIK team from CSIR‑NIScPR. He explained the basics of science communication and its many forms, such as popular science writing, infographics, podcasts, and social media. Participants practiced making communication materials, learning how to design eye‑catching infographics, posters, and short videos about traditional practices. At the end, Dr Raj Mukhopadhyay of ICAR‑Central Soil Salinity Research Institute, Karnal, talked about indigenous soil‑management practices and how they improve soil fertility, microbes, and nutrient cycling. The workshop ended with a feedback session and a vote of thanks. Teachers from schools and colleges thanked the organizers for the enriching experience. In closing, Dr Sandhiya Lakshmanan, senior scientist of CSIR‑NIScPR, thanked all leaders, speakers, and participants for their active participation. ***** NKR/AK
