announcements.title: Dr. Jitendra Singh reviews DBT projects; urges states to boost bioinnovation
announcements.content: Union Minister of State (Independent Charge) for Science and Technology, Dr. Jitendra Singh, said today that we should use local strengths to build a strong Bioinnovation system with active State participation. He was chairing a review meeting of the Department of Biotechnology (DBT), where he looked at current projects and new plans to grow India’s bio-innovation area. He examined a variety of new projects – from biofoundries and local innovation hubs to a mapping of states based on their biotech potential – all aimed at strengthening the country’s bioeconomy through innovation, teamwork, and local involvement. Dr. Singh stressed the need to boost local biotech ecosystems by using regional strengths and working more closely with state governments and local stakeholders. He said that India’s biotech sector has become a key pillar of national development, adding a lot to the economy through health, farming, the environment, and industry. He added that the government’s plan is to make biotech a driver of economic and social change by linking research institutions, start‑ups, and state governments in a shared innovation system. During the meeting, Dr. Singh also congratulated Ms. Ekta Vishnoi, IRS, a Joint Secretary of DBT, who earned a silver medal at the World Powerlifting Championship. He praised her success as both a personal milestone and a sign of India’s growing strength in global sports. He pointed out that sports today show discipline, resilience, and teamwork – qualities that also push India’s science and technology forward. Ms. Vishnoi’s path, he said, shows the perseverance and passion that define the new India – a country that wants to excel in all areas, from research and innovation to sports and global leadership. Dr. Singh added that DBT’s work in human physiology, metabolic research, and health technologies could help the future of performance science in India, showing how biotech and sports can combine to build a stronger, healthier nation. During the review, DBT officials presented new initiatives to expand bio‑foundries and create new partnerships between research bodies and industry. These bio‑foundries are meant to give a platform for quick design, testing, and scaling of biotechnological solutions, bridging the gap between discovery and use. Dr. Singh highlighted the importance of local engagement to drive the next phase of India’s bio‑innovation movement. He noted that the DBT has begun mapping states by their biotech potential and working with them to set up Bio E3 Cells – part of the larger Bio E3 policy that focuses on entrepreneurship, education, and empowerment in biotech. The goal, he said, is to match national priorities with regional strengths, so states can find their unique opportunities in the biotech chain and grow them through focused action. The Minister urged DBT to deepen its work with state governments, universities, and local industries to unlock biotech’s economic potential at the grassroots level. He also praised the Department’s role in supporting innovation‑led start‑ups and building an ecosystem that encourages young entrepreneurs and researchers to turn ideas into workable solutions. Dr. Singh repeated that biotech can answer many of India’s biggest challenges – from sustainable farming to affordable health care and environmental resilience. The government, he said, is committed to ensuring every region benefits from this scientific progress through coordinated policy, investment, and capacity building. The review ended with a call to speed up project implementation and strengthen inter‑government collaboration, marking a renewed push to make India a global hub for biotech‑driven innovation and sustainable growth. **** NKR/AK

announcements.summary:

announcements.title: Dr Singh urges health sector to cut government dependence and boost participation
announcements.content:
Dr Jitendra Singh, Union Minister of State for Science & Technology and other departments, said the health sector should not rely too much on government funding. He called for greater private‑sector involvement, philanthropy and teamwork to meet global standards in health research. He opened the Diabetes Conference "TREAT‑DM 2025 – Translational Research, Adiposopathy, Technology for Diabetes and Metabolic Diseases" with a virtual speech at the J N Tata Auditorium.

He said the era of working alone is over; integration between universities, research and industry is the way forward. He added that the line between public and private has blurred. Because of PM Modi’s reforms, India has opened its space, nuclear and biotechnology sectors to more participants, giving historic results.

India’s space economy has grown from less than 10 USD a decade ago to more than 8 billion USD, and is expected to reach 40–45 billion USD in the next ten years. Similar change is happening in other science and tech fields like biotech and biomedical research.

He highlighted new breakthroughs: India did its first successful homemade gene‑therapy test for Hemophilia, done by the Department of Biotechnology with Christian Medical College, Vellore. The results, published in the New England Journal of Medicine, showed a 60–70 percent correction rate and no bleeding after treatment.

He also said India made its first home‑grown antibiotic Nafithromycin that works against resistant lung infections, especially in diabetic and weak‑immune patients. The drug was made with help from government and industry and is a big step toward Atmanirbhar Bharat in drug making.

He added that India has succeeded in vaccine research and export. "Our home‑made DNA vaccine and other vaccines have been sent to almost 200 countries. This shows India’s commitment to self‑reliance and global help – the spirit of Vishwabandhu Bharat," he said.

He highlighted that India’s Anusandhan National Research Foundation (ANRF) is set up to get steady funding: ₹50,000 crore for five years, of which ₹36,000 crore will come from non‑government sources. This is a big shift toward a self‑sufficient research model that follows global best practices.

He mentioned India’s growing role in bio‑manufacturing: it is third in the Indo‑Pacific region and twelfth worldwide. Devices made at institutes such as Sree Chitra Tirunal Institute for Medical Sciences & Technology, Thiruvananthapuram, are exported, showing the success of home‑grown R&D.

He also mentioned life‑science experiments done on the International Space Station by astronaut Subhanshu Sharma using kits made by the Department of Biotechnology. These studies looked at muscle growth and cell changes from long exposure to electronic environments. "These are Indian experiments with worldwide impact," he said.

He ended by urging researchers to match their work with the vision of Viksit Bharat @ 2047. He said India’s science and tech growth will come from innovation, self‑reliance and global partnership.

The first session also had speeches from Dr C. N. Manjunath, Member of Parliament (Bengaluru Rural) and Guest of Honour; Prof. Govindan Rangarajan, Director, IISc; Prof. Navakanta Bhat, Dean, Division of Interdisciplinary Sciences, IISc; Dr Rohit N. Kulkarni, Harvard Medical School; and other top scientists and doctors from India and abroad.
announcements.original_title: Addressing Bengaluru Diabetes Conference, Dr Jitendra Singh calls upon healthcare sector to move away from overdependence on government funding and encourage a culture of extensive private-sector participation for synergised healthcare;
announcements.summary:
Dr Jitendra Singh said health should use more private money and teamwork to reach global standards, and that the old way of working alone is over.
He highlighted India’s big wins in gene therapy, a new antibiotic, vaccines to 200 countries, and big research funding from non‑government sources, urging scientists to match the vision of Viksit Bharat @ 2047.

announcements.title: MSDE reports mid‑campaign progress of Special Campaign 5.0.
announcements.content: The Government of India has launched Special Campaign 5.0 from 2nd October to 31st October, 2025. This campaign focuses more on field and outstation offices along with Ministries, Departments and their subordinate offices under the Department of Administrative Reforms and Public Grievances (DARPG). The preparatory phase ran from 15th to 30th September, 2025. The goal is to make Swachhata (Cleanliness) a regular practice in government offices, improve office conditions, manage space and records efficiently, and clear pending items such as MP references, inter-ministerial references, state government references, public grievances and parliamentary assurances. Special attention is given to e-Waste disposal (unserviceable computers, printers, LED displays, etc.) as per e-Waste Management Rules, 2022. A VC meeting led by Shri M. Subramanian, Joint Secretary, brought together nodal officers of all MSDE institutions to explain the campaign. Every division in a ministry, department or subordinate office must spot cleanliness areas, pending files, redundant material and documents; reduce pending items; show before and after situations; report daily progress through the SCDPM portal; and share best practices, including ways to turn waste into value or art. Since 2nd October, MSDE has actively taken part in Special Campaign 5.0, identifying key tasks such as cleaning sites and clearing record files. A workshop with the National Archives of India was also held to educate ministry and field officers about the importance of record management. Progress is tracked daily. As of 16th October, 2025, 79% of public grievance cases have been resolved. 634 old files—51% of the target—have been reviewed, recorded and eliminated, and 1,900 cleanliness target units have been improved. MSDE is working hard to clear all pending matters well before the 31.10.2025 deadline. **** SH/IS

announcements.title: ASISSE survey gets feedback on draft questionnaire.
announcements.content:
The service sector is a major part of India’s economy. It makes up more than half of the country’s GDP and gives jobs to millions of people.

Accurate and detailed data about this sector is essential for smart policymaking, good planning, and wise investment choices. The Annual Survey of Unincorporated Sector Enterprises (ASUSE) regularly covers the unincorporated part of the service sector, but we lack consistent information on the incorporated services sector. This gap exists mainly because there is no regular national survey that looks at the different subsectors of incorporated non‑agricultural and non‑manufacturing businesses.

To fill this void, the National Statistics Office (NSO) under the Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation (MoSPI) has planned the Annual Survey of Incorporated Services Sector Enterprises (ASISSE). This survey will use the GSTN data for corporate “Construction,” “Trade,” and “Other Services” (including transport, accommodation and food services, information and communication, health, education, real estate, etc.) as its sampling frame.

Before starting the full annual survey, a national Pilot Study—called the Annual Survey of Services Sector Enterprises (ASSSE)—was carried out in two phases with the GSTN frame. Phase I (May‑August 2024) tested whether the GSTN database is suitable, updated some frame details, and Phase II (November 2024 to January 2025) examined practical aspects such as enterprise responses, clarity of instructions, questionnaire structure, and data collection feasibility. The Technical Report on this pilot is available on MoSPI’s website at https://mospi.gov.in/sites/default/files/publication_reports/TECHNICAL%20REPORT_ASSSE.pdf.

After the pilot, a brainstorming session with government, industry, and academic stakeholders took place on 13 August 2025 in Delhi. The session gathered valuable input. Based on the pilot experience and the brainstorming discussion, the ASISSE questionnaire was drafted under the guidance of the Technical Advisory Group (TAG) for Enterprise Surveys. The draft questionnaire is now posted on the MoSPI website for public review.

Researchers, policymakers, industry groups, academic institutions, and anyone interested are invited to read the questionnaire and share feedback on its structure, content, and coverage. Your comments will improve the quality, reach, and policy relevance of the upcoming ASISSE. Please send suggestions and comments to nssocpd.coord@mospi.gov.in and tc.dpd@mospi.gov.in by 31 October 2025 using the specific format. The draft questionnaire and feedback format can be downloaded from https://mospi.gov.in/sites/default/files/announcements/Circular_17102025.pdf?download=1.

Samrat/Allen

announcements.title: Tribal Business Conclave 2025 to Help Tribal Entrepreneurs Grow
announcements.content: Guided by the vision and inspiration of the Hon’ble Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi, who keeps stressing Janjatiya Gaurav and Vocal for Local as key pillars of India’s development, the Tribal Business Conclave 2025 shows the spirit of ‘Sabka Saath, Sabka Vikas, Sabka Vishwas, aur Sabka Prayas.’ On 17 th October 2025, during the National Conclave on Adi Karmayogi Abhiyan, the Ministry of Tribal Affairs, together with the Ministry of Culture and DPIIT, announced that the Tribal Business Conclave 2025 will be held on 12th November 2025 at Yashobhoomi, New Delhi. The event also revealed the new logo, brochure and digital materials, showing how tradition, business and new ideas join together. Built on the Prime Minister’s vision of Aatmanirbhar Bharat and Viksit Bharat @2047, the Conclave wants to help tribal business owners across India, encouraging growth that is fair, driven by new ideas and lasting. It is a big turning point in India’s progress, putting tribal business at the heart of national growth. Celebrating the Legacy of Bhagwan Birsa Munda 2025 is the year of the 150th birthday of Bhagwan Birsa Munda, whose values of honesty, new ideas and independence still inspire India’s fight for fairness and progress. The Conclave honors his lasting legacy and shows how old knowledge and new business plans work together, backed by many year‑long national programs. Whole‑of‑Government Approach  The Conclave is organized by the Ministry of Tribal Affairs, Ministry of Culture and DPIIT, showing how different groups come together. It gets support from many ministries and state governments, which are key to building local business growth. Important partners are FICCI, PRAYOGI (PanIIT Alumni Reach for Gram Udyogi) Foundation and Startup India, giving a good platform for advice, money and help to start tribal businesses. Highlights of the Conclave  Empowering Tribal Entrepreneurs and Shaping the Future  The Conclave wants to make tribal business common, help local products be known and sold, and build skills for lasting business growth. It will make it easier for tribal communities to get money, link better with markets and find new investments. By combining old knowledge with new business skills and technology, the Conclave will link local ideas with national and worldwide markets, creating business models that are sustainable, efficient and run by communities. Towards Viksit Bharat @2047  The Conclave says the government is determined that Viksit Bharat @2047 will succeed only if people from the ground level and their businesses are central. It says Bharat is ready to lead, powered by new ideas that come from its identity and guided by the Prime Minister’s vision of growth that is fair, steady and independent. More details can be accessed on https://tribalbusinessconclave.com ********* RN/

announcements.title: 8th Nutrition Month 2025 ends in Dehradun, call for India by 2047.
announcements.content:
Dehradun: The closing ceremony of the 8th Rashtriya Poshan Maah 2025 was held at the Himalayan Cultural Centre in Dehradun on Friday. Smt. Savitri Thakur, Union Minister of State for Women and Child Development, was the chief guest. The event marked the end of a month-long Jan Andolan focused on nutrition awareness, community participation, and changing habits. Other attendees included Smt. Rekha Arya, Minister for Women Empowerment and Child Development of Uttarakhand; Shri Ganesh Joshi, Minister for Agriculture and Rural Development of Uttarakhand; Shri Lav Agarwal, Additional Secretary, MoWCD, India; Shri Chandresh Kumar Yadav, Secretary, Department of Women Empowerment and Child Development, Uttarakhand; and Smt. Radhika Jha, Joint Secretary, MoWCD, India.
Smt. Savitri Thakur said, “Nutrition is not just a programme; it is our national duty and moral promise to every child and mother in India.” She noted that Poshan Abhiyaan, launched by Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi on 8 March 2018, has become a people’s movement that brings together many ministries and citizens under the idea of ‘Empowered Women, Nourished India’. She highlighted the first 1,000 days—from conception to age two—as the most important time for a child’s growth, adding that “a healthy mother gives birth to a strong generation; when every household’s plate is balanced, the nation becomes stronger.”
She said women are the base of every family and talked about the theme ‘Healthy Women, Strong Families’. Referring to the ‘Mann Ki Baat’ programme, she said obesity is a big problem, and Poshan Maah wants to make nutrition a people’s movement with community help. She said this year’s Poshan Maah was very inclusive, with men and youth also joining women. “Today’s well‑nourished children are the citizens of a Suposhit Bharat in 2047,” she said. She praised the ‘Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao’ campaign and called for action against social evils like child marriage. She thanked states and Union Territories for their active role and lauded Anganwadi workers and field staff, saying the end of the campaign marks a new start for a lasting movement that should reach every household in India.
Shri Lav Agarwal, Additional Secretary, MoWCD, spoke about progress under Mission Poshan 2.0. He said digital governance and real‑time monitoring tools have made service delivery and transparency better. He reported that 14 lakh Anganwadi Centres in 36 States and UTs serve more than 10 crore beneficiaries, including children, pregnant women, nursing mothers, and adolescent girls. He mentioned the Poshan Tracker App has changed service delivery and beneficiary management. More than 13 lakh Anganwadi workers now have smartphones linked to the app, ensuring accurate data and timely nutrition. About 13.87 lakh centres also have growth‑monitoring devices. NFHS‑5 data shows India’s malnutrition indicators have improved: stunting fell from 38.4% to 35.5% and underweight dropped from 35.8% to 32.1%. “These are not just numbers,” Agarwal said, “but signs of hope for millions of children moving from malnutrition to nutrition.” He added that 2 lakh Anganwadi Centres are being upgraded to ‘Saksham Anganwadi Centres’ with safe drinking water, sanitation, ECCE learning materials, and digital tools, building a foundation for Suposhit Bharat 2047. “This is not just about implementing schemes,” he said, “but about nurturing a generation that will be India’s Amrit Peedhi in 2047—healthy, educated, empowered, and compassionate.”
During the ceremony, Smt. Rekha Arya said that nutrition for children and pregnant women is the real strength of a ‘Golden India.’ She praised the government’s efforts, noting that real‑time data through the Poshan Tracker has made service delivery more transparent and accountable, calling it ‘a seal of trust on ground‑level commitment.’ Shri Ganesh Joshi welcomed dignitaries and Anganwadi workers, noting that under Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s leadership, Uttarakhand has seen a big drop in anemia. He talked about 2023 as the International Year of Millets, calling millets a ‘game‑changer’ for nutrition and local farming, and said local produce is the backbone of India’s food self‑reliance.
Smt. Thakur visited an exhibition by the Department of Women Empowerment and Child Development, Uttarakhand, where she met Anganwadi workers and local producers showing millet‑based items such as Kodou, Kauni, Jhangora etc. She congratulated Poshan Champions and Mission Shakti Champions and gave out Mahalaxmi Kits. She also transferred an amount of 1,56,33,000 as part of the Mukhyamantri Vatsalya Yojana to 5211 beneficiaries of the state through Direct Benefit Transfer. A video message from Union Minister Smt. Annapurna Devi was shown during the programme, where she said that under Poshan Abhiyaan, the Government of India wants every child to be healthy and every mother empowered. She remembered that when Prime Minister Modi launched Poshan Abhiyaan 2025 from Dhar, Madhya Pradesh, he said that ‘Healthy Women, Strong Families, and a Developed India’ are connected pillars of progress. She repeated that since 2018, Poshan Abhiyaan has become a people’s movement, thanks to millions of Anganwadi workers and field officials across India. This year’s 8th Poshan Maah focused on six key themes—Mindful Eating, Early Childhood Care and Education, Nutrition Behaviour for Infants and Young Children, Men’s Participation, Vocal for Local, and Convergence & Digitalization—raising public awareness and laying a visionary foundation for Suposhit Bharat by 2047.

announcements.title: Fit India will run cycling trips from Kashmir to Kanyakumari Oct 31
announcements.content: The Ministry of Youth Affairs & Sports and Labour & Employment, through its main program Fit India, will hold two nationwide bike trips called “Iron Wheels of Unity” from October 31, 2025, to mark the 150th birthday of Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel. The trips will cover the whole country, showing national unity and the idea of a fit and strong India. The Kashmir to Kanyakumari (K2K) bike trip will cover 4480 kilometres, starting in Srinagar, J&K on October 31 and going through Punjab, Delhi, Rajasthan, Gujarat, Maharashtra and Karnataka, ending in Kanyakumari, Tamil Nadu, on November 16, 2025. 150 riders will join this trip, a fitting tribute to the 150th birthday of Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel. Mountaineer Nisha Kumari, who climbed Mount Everest on May 17, 2023 and cycled from India to London to share the message of ‘Change before climate change’, will lead the K2K trip. Another trip, Pedal to Plant, will cover 4000 kilometres, starting from Pangsau in Arunachal Pradesh and going through Assam, West Bengal, Bihar, Uttar Pradesh and Madhya Pradesh, ending in Mundra, Gujarat, on December 31, 2025. Along the route, the cyclists will plant 100,000 saplings and run climate and fitness talks at schools and colleges. Union Minister of Youth Affairs & Sports and Labour & Employment, Dr. Mansukh Mandaviya said: “I would like to wish the cyclists who are part of the Fit India Iron Wheels of Unity campaign. This is a tribute to our great freedom fighter and statesman Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel. Our Prime Minister Narendra Modi wants us to be fitter and healthier. This program will help that goal and raise awareness about an active life. As I have said before, cycling is a great way to stay fit and reduce pollution. I encourage every Indian to take up cycling and spend at least 30 minutes to one hour on their own fitness.” The “Iron Wheels of Unity” program is an extension of the ‘Fit India Sundays on Cycle’ movement started by Dr. Mansukh Mandaviya, and aims to further promote healthy fitness and caring for the environment. The nationwide trips are expected to cut carbon emissions by more than 100,000 kilograms, showing Fit India’s promise to protect the environment and a healthier country. ***** Rini Choudhury/Anjelina Alexander

announcements.title: India re-elected COP10 Vice-Chair; reaffirms clean sport pledge
announcements.content: India took part in the 10th meeting of the Conference of Parties (COP10) to the International Convention against Doping in Sport, which was held from 20-22 October 2025 at UNESCO Headquarters in Paris. The meeting celebrated the 20th anniversary of the Convention, the only legal global rule that aims to promote fairness and stop doping in sports. The Indian team, led by Shri Hari Ranjan Rao, Secretary of Sports, and Shri Anant Kumar, Director General of the National Anti-Doping Agency (NADA), talked with delegates from more than 190 States Parties, plus representatives of the African Union, International Olympic Committee, World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA), and other groups. While meeting, India was chosen again as the Vice‑Chair of the Bureau for the Asia‑Pacific (Group IV) for the period 2025–2027. Azerbaijan became Chair of the COP10 Bureau. Brazil, Zambia, and Saudi Arabia were also chosen as Vice‑Chairs for their regions. India also gave in‑kind help by setting up Interactive Boards that show the history of the Anti‑Doping Convention. Over 500 representatives from governments, anti‑doping organisations, and UNESCO permanent delegations were at the meeting. Talks focused on making the Convention run better, funding the Fund for the Elimination of Doping in Sport, and dealing with new problems like gene editing, traditional medicines, and moral issues in sports. The report from the COP9 Bureau and Approval Committee mentioned the need for better coordination, good communication, and teamwork across sectors. India successfully suggested changes to help schools and communities use the Values Education through Sport (VETS) approach to spread sports values, ethics, and fairness to young people, clubs and society. The results of COP10 will help improve the Convention’s rules and effectiveness. The session ended with a renewed pledge from all Parties to promote fairness and integrity in sports.

announcements.title: Sri Lanka PM visits NITI Aayog
announcements.content: NITI Aayog welcomed Sri Lanka's Prime Minister Dr. Harini Nireka Amarasuriya in New Delhi on 16th October 2025. The visit aimed to strengthen cooperation between the two nations and share India’s progress in infrastructure, education, tourism, skills, and AI. In her opening speech, the Prime Minister praised NITI Aayog as a think‑tank and coordination hub, noting its special ability to link long‑term policy design with real‑world implementation. She showed interest in learning how NITI Aayog works with central ministries and states, bringing analysis, evidence‑based policy, and citizen feedback into good governance. She also mentioned Sri Lanka’s reform path and the need for institutions that support policy coherence, evidence‑based decisions, and continuity beyond politics. Discussions, led by Vice Chairman Suman K. Bery with senior members present, gave an overview of India’s current projects such as PM Gati Shakti for multi‑modal infrastructure planning, the National Education Policy 2020 for all‑inclusive learning, joint opportunities in tourism and cultural exchange, and new technologies including AI and digital governance. Presentations covered India‑Sri Lanka Bilateral Relations, trade, investment, and the Economic and Technology Cooperation Agreement (ETCA); PM Gati Shakti, showing how India’s logistics model could be used in Kandy City; Education Reforms under NEP 2020, focusing on inclusive, tech‑driven learning; Tourism and Cultural Exchange, highlighting partnership in heritage, eco, and wellness tourism; and Frontier Technologies and AI, exploring cooperation in digital innovation and governance. NITI Aayog staff from many areas joined the meeting, showing India’s dedication to sharing knowledge and working together. The visit highlighted the shared goal of India and Sri Lanka to deepen strategic ties, promote sustainable development, and use innovation and skills to tackle regional challenges. Both sides re‑affirmed their commitment to a knowledge‑based, tech‑driven, people‑centric partnership under the Neighbourhood First and MAHASAGAR frameworks.

NITI Aayog hosted Sri Lanka's Prime Minister in New Delhi on 16th October 2025 to talk about cooperation in infrastructure, education, tourism, skills, and AI.
Both leaders agreed to deepen ties, share knowledge, and build a people-centric partnership for sustainable development.

announcements.title: NITI Aayog and DP World launch 'We Rise' for women business owners
announcements.content: NITI Aayog’s Women Entrepreneurship Platform (WEP) and DP World announced a joint initiative called "We Rise - Women Entrepreneurs Reimagining Inclusive and Sustainable Enterprises". The program, part of WEP’s Award to Reward (ATR) initiative, aims to help women entrepreneurs in India grow their businesses worldwide by providing trade help, mentorship, and strategic partnerships. Ms. Anna Roy, Mission Director of WEP, signed the Statement of Intent with Shri B.V.R. Subrahmanyam, CEO of NITI Aayog. Through ATR, WEP will identify and mentor high‑potential women‑led Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) across India to expand globally. DP World will use its global logistics network and trade expertise to support 100 women entrepreneurs, helping them meet export requirements and build business capacity. The chosen entrepreneurs can also show their products at Bharat Mart in Dubai, a global B2B and B2C marketplace in Jebel Ali Free Zone (Jafza), giving Indian firms access to international buyers. WEP and DP World are working together to empower women entrepreneurs focused on products. With more than 90,000 women entrepreneurs already on the WEP platform, this partnership is a unique public‑private effort to open trade opportunities and help women businesses grow. It shows DP World’s commitment to inclusive trade and overall economic growth. Shri Subrahmanyam said the partnership supports India’s vision for women‑led economic growth. "With We Rise we want to create a supportive environment so women entrepreneurs can grow, scale, and reach global markets. By teaming up with DP World, a global leader in supply chain solutions, we are building a strong foundation for long‑term impact," he said. Ms. Roy added that achieving women‑led development through entrepreneurship requires targeted support, and organizations in the public and private sectors must collaborate. She praised DP World for its initiative that will boost women exporters. WEP started as a platform in 2018 and became a public‑private partnership in 2022. It serves as a national aggregator to strengthen India’s women entrepreneurship ecosystem and make women‑led development real. With 47 partners from the public and private sectors, WEP provides services such as finance access, market links, training and skills, mentorship and networking, compliance and legal help, and business development. Launched in 2023, the ATR initiative formalizes WEP’s partnership model, bringing together stakeholders to meet the specific needs of women entrepreneurs while celebrating their success stories. It offers a plug‑and‑play model that encourages scalable collaborations and measurable results.
announcements.original_title: NITI Aayog’s Women Entrepreneurship Platform and DP World launch ‘We Rise’ initiative to empower women entrepreneurs
announcements.summary:
NITI Aayog’s Women Entrepreneurship Platform (WEP) and DP World are partnering under "We Rise - Women Entrepreneurs Reimagining Inclusive and Sustainable Enterprises" to help 100 women entrepreneurs grow globally, offering trade help, mentorship, and a chance to showcase products at Bharat Mart in Dubai.
The initiative will use DP World’s global logistics network to meet export requirements, build business capacity, and connect these women-led MSMEs to international buyers.

announcements.title: Seventh regional meeting on easing R&D for state growth at IIT Guwahati
announcements.content: A two‑day Regional Consultative Meeting on “Ease of Doing Research & Development (R&D) for Accelerating Growth of States/UTs” was held by NITI Aayog at IIT Guwahati on October 15–16, 2025. The workshop brought Vice Chancellors, institutional leaders and officials from scientific ministries and departments in the Northeast to discuss ways to strengthen India’s R&D system. Prof. Devendra Jalihal, Director of IIT Guwahati, gave the welcome address and urged more collaboration between universities, industry and government to speed up India’s research and development goals. Prof. Vivek Kumar Singh, Programme Director of NITI Aayog, explained the theme of the workshop, noting that making research easier is only the first step; the real aim is to turn scientific results into real‑world applications. In their keynote talks, Dr. Sanghamitra Bandopadhyay, acting Director of ISI Kolkata, and Dr. Vinita Sahay, Director of IIM Bodh Gaya, stressed the need to rethink India’s research landscape, break apart institutional barriers and build industry links. They also highlighted the importance of creating a research‑friendly climate in schools. Dr. V. K. Saraswat, Member of NITI Aayog, shared his views on the future of Indian science and technology. He said states and union territories should identify their strengths and use a cluster approach to grow their R&D ecosystems. He mentioned using the Mohali model for the Northeast, with Guwahati as the main hub, to promote integrated research and innovation clusters. He also suggested launching mission‑mode R&D projects that address the specific challenges of the Northeast to foster inclusive and sustainable growth. In the technical sessions, participants discussed how to simplify processes to improve R&D efficiency and productivity, attract and keep skilled people for R&D, translate lab work into real products (Lab to Land), encourage collaboration and mobility, and measure the ease of doing R&D. Contributions came from top Vice Chancellors and Directors of universities, national laboratories and institutes. The meeting ended with a clear point: India’s scientific progress depends not only on how easy research can be carried out, but on how well it can be turned into real impact. Making research translation central to policy, funding and planning will turn India’s ideas into innovations that boost industry, support self‑reliance and help achieve Viksit Bharat 2047. *** MJPS/SR

NITI Aayog held a two‑day meeting in IIT Guwahati on 15–16 October 2025 to talk about making research easier and turning it into real‑world results for the Northeast states and union territories.
The meeting said India’s science progress needs easy research steps plus strong links with industry, schools and government so ideas become useful products and help build a better future.

announcements.title: NHRC acts on attacks against three journalists in Kerala, Manipur and Tripura
announcements.content:
The National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) of India has taken notice of media reports about attacks on three journalists. One attack happened in Kerala and Manipur on 30 August 2025. Another happened in Tripura on 21 September 2025. In each case, the Commission sent notices to the state police chiefs asking for detailed reports within two weeks.

In Tripura, a journalist was attacked by a group with sticks and knives while he was at a clothes distribution event organized by a political party in Hezamara, West Tripura. His motorcycle was also stolen.

In Manipur, a journalist was attacked while covering a flower festival in Laii Village, Senapathi District. He was hit twice by an air gun and suffered serious injuries.

In Kerala, a journalist was attacked by a group when he reached Mangattukavala near Thoudupuzha. He was returning from a wedding.

In all cases, the victims were taken to the hospital and the police registered the cases. ***** NSK

announcements.title: NHRC urges states and UTs to protect homeless from winter cold
announcements.content: The National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) in India, seeing the cold wave, has asked 19 state governments and 4 union territory administrations to take early action and give relief to protect vulnerable groups, especially newborns, children, infants, the poor, the elderly, homeless people, those in need, and beggars who risk exposure due to lack of shelter and resources. The Commission says that changing weather because of climate change affects human rights and reaffirms its pledge to defend those harmed by extreme weather, ensuring their dignity is respected. It highlighted a National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB) report titled ‘Accidental Deaths and Suicides in India’ that shows 3,639 people died from cold exposure between 2019 and 2023. In a letter to the states and union territory administrations, the Commission reminded them of National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA) guidelines to reduce cold wave impacts, including: The Commission urged officials to be aware and requested reports on actions taken to prevent incidents and safeguard vulnerable populations from cold wave harm. *** NSK

announcements.title: Professor Sood launches AI guides for farmers and SMEs to boost use
announcements.content:
Prof. Ajay Kumar Sood, the top scientific adviser to the Indian government, released three documents under the AI for India 2030 plan led by the Centre for the Fourth Industrial Revolution (C4IR) India and the World Economic Forum (WEF).

The launch was announced in front of Shri S. Krishnan, Secretary of the Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology (MeitY); Shri S.C.L. Das, Secretary of the Ministry of Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSME); Dr. Parvinder Maini, Scientific Secretary of the Office of the Principal Scientific Adviser (OPSA); and Mr. Anindya Banerjee, Advisor on Digital Infrastructure in the Ministry of Agriculture.

The three documents were released under the guidance of OPSA and MeitY, and by a multi-stakeholder Advisory Council. The AI for India 2030 project wants to create plans that matter strategically and globally, putting responsible, inclusive, and growth-focused AI at the core of India's digital economy.

India's AI progress is about change at the grassroots level. These playbooks come at the right time and give clear ways to make AI inclusive and useful, so new technology brings real help to farmers, business owners, and communities across the country. I ask everyone to work together to use these practical plans for India's growth. The coming together of many departments and programs shown in these reports should keep the momentum going and help AI be used more widely in society, said Prof. Sood.

The playbooks give clear steps to use AI in India's key sectors, based on many field talks, pilot projects, and feedback from government, industry, start-ups, universities, and farmer groups.

Each document shows a teamwork model that shows what the government, industry, start-ups, and local workers should do.

Mr. Purushottam Kaushik, Head of C4IR India, WEF, gave a short summary and explained the method used for the new documents.

Because these reports focus on real sectors, we have a very useful collection that came from many partners, showing a way forward. This playbook shows how AI can fit smoothly into this change, unlocking new efficiencies, better decisions, and more prosperity for every farmer, said Shri Krishnan.

The 'Future Farming in India' playbook shows a plan to use AI for millions of farmers, aiming to increase harvests, control risks, and help farmers reach markets. The key is the IMPACT AI framework, which guides teamwork: governments make policy, industry builds solutions in test labs (sandboxes), and local workers give tools to farmers. It uses trusted local networks and local languages to put AI guidance into everyday farming choices.

The 'Transforming Small Businesses' playbook gives a plan to help India's small firms tackle issues of productivity, getting credit, and finding markets by making AI accessible. The IMPACT AI framework again guides firms from learning about AI, to using experience centres and test labs, to taking action with an AI maturity index, marketplace, tools, and funding, and finally being recognized by honoring pioneers. This cluster approach seeks to spread real AI use across small businesses.

'Focusing on MSMEs is timely and smart. AI uses in these sectors are growing fast. After these documents, we look forward to working with industry partners and start-ups to turn these ideas into real projects that help our small businesses,' said Shri Das.

'OPSA's Science and Technology Clusters can help move the plan in these reports forward. Using their current network, the clusters can build skills and spread knowledge, especially at the start. Also, the International S&T Clusters Conference in December 2025, organized by OPSA, could focus on AI to boost collaboration,' said Dr. Maini.

'AI's power to change agriculture is widely recognized. We are looking at many AI uses in farming, such as digital crop surveys where images and data are combined with AI to improve accuracy and insight,' said Mr. Banerjee.

The AI Sandbox White Paper describes plans and operations to set up safe spaces for testing and expanding AI, making sure solutions are secure, dependable, and match India's priorities.

The next steps concentrate on joint action and clear results. State governments, industry groups, tech makers, and financiers will join to create implementation teams that turn playbook ideas into funded projects in farming and main SME groups.

A single monitoring system will watch progress using sector‑specific signs like how much AI is used, productivity increases, cost cuts, better credit access, and improved market reach.

Also, a special knowledge hub will record and share good examples and success stories, helping continuous learning and spreading good solutions across India's AI network.

**** MJPS/ST

announcements.title: GST boosts growth from cement to handloom in Chhattisgarh
announcements.content:
Key Takeaways
17 October, 2025

Introduction
Chhattisgarh is in central India and was formed in 2000 after separating from Madhya Pradesh. It is the country’s 9th largest state and has over 25 million people. The state has many forests and natural resources and is famous for its tribal culture, vibrant festivals, and growing industry. Its crafts – bell metal from Bastar, bamboo from Raigarh, and hand‑woven Kosa silk – show a strong tradition of skill and care for nature.

GST changes give new energy to the economy. Lowering tax on everyday goods and on traditional sectors cuts costs for producers, raises consumer buying, and makes local products stronger in India and abroad. A 5 % GST on handlooms, handicrafts, and dairy lightens the burden on small makers, encourages them to register, and supports the state’s goal of inclusive growth.

Cement Industry
Cement and building materials are major in Korba, Raigarh, Bilaspur, Raipur and Naya Raipur, where cities grow fast. The sector brings tax money and helps other businesses. It also employs many people. Cutting GST on cement from 28 % to 18 % lowers building costs, boosts home demand, and creates more jobs in infrastructure.

Handloom & Powerloom
Handlooms are a key cottage industry in Chhattisgarh and part of India’s big textile job market. The state’s MSME powerloom workers help supply the national industry.

Handloom fabrics are made in Janjgir‑Champa, Raigarh, Raipur, Mahasamund, Bastar and Sarguja. Products include terry towel cloth, cotton handlooms in Raipur, Durg and Bastar, and silk from Janjgir‑Champa and Raigarh. GST at 5 % makes sarees and silk cheaper and more competitive worldwide, boosting exports. It also supports weavers against cheap machine‑made cloth, especially for Kosa and Tussar silk.

Powerloom (mill‑based) weaving is semi‑organized and located in Raigarh, Bilaspur and Janjgir‑Champa, with hubs in Balodabazar, Mahasamund, Raipur, Bastar and Sarguja. Lowering GST from 12 %/18 % to 5 % helps the sector. India’s textile industry, the country’s second biggest employer, benefits from lower taxes, more jobs, better margins and higher export competitiveness. The reforms also ease the tax load on MSMEs, improve working capital and push formalization.

Handicrafts & Traditional Arts
Chhattisgarh’s art includes metal, clay and wood works. Dhokra metal casting, Bastar wood carvings and bell metal objects show strong craftsmanship. Jewelry, textiles and terracotta are also popular, mixing old styles with modern appeal.

Tribal & Forest Crafts
Bastar, Kondagaon and Jagdalpur are famous for tribal and forest arts. Artisans make wood items, Dhokra metalwork, wrought iron, bamboo, terracotta and bell metal crafts, reflecting local culture. Cutting GST from 12 %/18 % to 5 % raises demand by 10‑15 % and could add 5 000 jobs by 2026. It improves margins, sales and supports artisans in Self‑Help Groups. Lower tax on raw materials like tendu leaves also helps tribal communities.

Metal Handicrafts
Metal, bell metal, wrought iron and iron craft are common across Bastar, Raipur and other tribal areas. Bastar Iron Craft (Dhokra) has a Geographical Indication tag, showing its heritage. The sector supports many livelihoods and is promoted under the One District One Product initiative. GST cut from 12 % to 5 % reduces production cost, improves sales and helps exports. It gives financial relief to tribal artisans and keeps traditional skills alive.

Packaged Dairy
Dairy is vital in Raipur, Bilaspur, Durg/Bhilai and tribal cooperatives, especially for women. Chhattisgarh has more than 1 068 dairy cooperatives, many run by women. GST on paneer, curd, yogurt and buttermilk fell from 12 % to 5 %. This is expected to raise consumer demand and require better cold‑chain transport. The policy creates new business chances, supports organized dairy and strengthens women‑led farms.

Conclusion
The new GST rates on handlooms, handicrafts, metal and forest arts, dairy and cement lower costs, increase buying, and improve competitiveness. They empower women farms, sustain artisans, support industrial jobs, and boost exports. By strengthening livelihoods, preserving traditional skills and opening new business chances, GST reforms drive inclusive growth and help Chhattisgarh build a sustainable future.

announcements.title: GST rate cut boosts agriculture, tourism, industry in Uttarakhand
announcements.content:
Key Takeaways Introduction

Located in the Himalayas, Uttarakhand is a state where terraced farms meet spiritual tourism, and old crafts mix with new businesses. From the red rice fields of Purola to the busy homestays of Nainital and Mussoorie, the state’s economy shows a mix of nature, tradition, and business. The new GST rate change gives a timely boost to this hill economy, cutting taxes on agriculture, tourism, crafts, and manufacturing. By lowering rates on important items such as Pahari Toor Dal, Red Rice, Handicrafts, Woolen Clothes, and Hospitality, the reforms aim to make goods cheaper, help small farmers, and bring investment to the state’s green and high‑value sectors. The reform matches Uttarakhand’s goal of sustainable growth, helping people in the hills while strengthening new industrial hubs in the plains.

Agriculture & Local Produce

Pahari Toor Dal

Grown in Chamoli, Almora, Tehri, Nainital, and Pithoragarh, Pahari Toor Dal is grown by small rain‑fed farmers as part of the traditional Barahnaja mixed cropping system. It is known for being organic and locally respected, and it is a key ingredient in Uttarakhand’s traditional food. It is grown across 13 hill districts. With the GST rate lowered from 12% to 5%, prices are expected to become cheaper, making Pahari Toor Dal more competitive in organic and health food markets. This change is expected to encourage sustainable hill farming and improve income for small and marginal farmers.

Uttarakhand Red Rice

Cultivated in Purola and Mori, Uttarakhand Red Rice is known for its traditional value and contribution to hill biodiversity. With the GST rate lowered from 12% to 5%, prices are expected to become more competitive, especially in packaged and health food markets. The change supports nearly 4,000 people directly and indirectly who work in red rice farming, creating local jobs and promoting sustainable hill agriculture.

Almora Lakhori Mirchi

The GI‑tagged Lakhori Mirchi from Almora is known for its distinct aroma and flavour. With the GST rate lowered from 12% to 5%, prices are expected to become more competitive, benefiting nearly 5,000 people directly and indirectly involved in its cultivation. The move supports local farmers and strengthens the market presence of this traditional hill spice.

Tourism & Cottage Industries

Tourism & Homestays

Tourism, including hotels and restaurants, contributes 13.57% to Uttarakhand’s GSDP and employs nearly 80,000 people directly and indirectly. With the GST rate on hotel tariffs up to ₹7,500 lowered from 12% to 5%, the reform is expected to make travel cheaper and benefit small hotels, restaurants, and homestays across Nainital, Mussoorie, Auli, Chopta, Munsyari, Haridwar, and Rishikesh.

Aipan Art & Decorative Handicrafts

Practised across the Kumaon region, including Almora, Bageshwar, and Nainital, Aipan is a traditional wall and floor art that is now used on bags, wall hangings, and gifts. With the GST rate lowered from 12% to 5%, the reform is expected to benefit around 4,000 people, mainly women‑led businesses, while supporting GI‑tag promotion and expanding local handicraft markets.

Hand‑Knitted Woolen Garments

Across Uttarakhand’s hill districts, locally hand‑knitted sweaters, caps, and socks form an important seasonal cottage industry led by hill women. With the GST rate lowered from 12% to 5%, prices are expected to fall by 6–7%, supporting around 10,000 livelihoods and helping small producers earn better returns during the peak tourist season.

Ringal (Hill Bamboo) Craft

Produced mainly in Pithoragarh, Champawat, and Nainital, Ringal, a local dwarf bamboo, is used to make baskets, trays, and other useful items. With the GST rate lowered from 12% to 5%, the reform supports SC/ST communities working in Ringal‑based handicrafts. A study in the Garhwal Himalaya found that about 47.65% of hill families earn some income from Ringal or bamboo craft work, showing its role in sustaining rural livelihoods.

Traditional Woolen Products (Pankhi, Shawls, Stoles)

Handmade from local sheep wool in Chamoli, Uttarkashi, and Bageshwar, these traditional woolen items are part of Uttarakhand’s craft heritage and rural livelihoods. The GST reduction from 12% to 5% is expected to boost sales through local fairs and online platforms, helping preserve traditional crafts and support hill women artisans who depend on this seasonal cottage industry.

Industry & Manufacturing

Food Processing

Uttarakhand has 383 registered food processing units, mainly in Rudrapur, employing nearly 30,000 people. The GST rate reduction from 12% to 5% is expected to improve margins, encourage value addition, and promote investment in sectors such as fruit processing, herbal products, and organic foods, strengthening the state’s agro‑industrial base.

Automobile Sector

The automobile manufacturing belt across Pantnagar, Rudrapur, Haridwar, and Kashipur employs nearly 50,000 people directly and indirectly. With the GST rate reduced from 28% to 18% on vehicles up to 1200cc (petrol) and 1500cc (diesel), prices are expected to fall by about 8–10%. This will boost local demand, support manufacturers, and create more jobs across the automobile value chain.

Medical Device Park

Located in the State Infrastructure and Industrial Development Corporation of Uttarakhand Limited (SIDCUL) industrial area, the Medical Device Park employs about 4,000 people in manufacturing. The GST reduction from 12% to 5% on medical devices will lower production costs, boost competitiveness, and encourage investment in the healthcare manufacturing ecosystem, further strengthening Uttarakhand’s MedTech sector.

Conclusion

The GST reforms unlock wide‑range benefits across Uttarakhand’s economy, from small hill farmers growing traditional crops to women artisans keeping Aipan and Ringal crafts alive, and from homestay owners in Rishikesh to industrial workers in Rudrapur. By reducing tax burdens and improving competitiveness, the reforms will strengthen livelihood security, tourism, MSME growth, and green entrepreneurship. Together, these measures link the mountain to the market, advancing Uttarakhand’s vision of inclusive, sustainable, and self‑reliant development.

announcements.title: GST changes from pashmina to apricots to boost Ladakh economy
announcements.content:
Key Takeaways Introduction:
Ladakh’s economy depends on its special landscape, culture, and craft skills. Traditional jobs mix with new eco‑friendly businesses. Good Pashmina wool, apricot farms, Thangka paintings, and eco‑tourism all show the region’s talent and history. The new GST cut on many goods and services will help Ladakh’s economy, easing costs for artisans, farmers, and small businesses. These changes will help people earn a living, keep culture alive, and grow Ladakh’s economy sustainably.

Handlooms Pashmina Wool & Products:
Pashmina wool is a very valuable craft in Ladakh. It is made in the Changthang area of Leh and supports more than 10,000 nomadic herders. Pashmina is famous for being warm, soft, and fine, and it is used to make high‑quality shawls, stoles, and clothes. The GST reduction from 12% to 5% will make genuine Ladakhi Pashmina more competitive against imported or machine‑made items. It will also help herders and artisans keep a steady income and could boost export growth.

Handwoven Woolens & Namda Rugs:
Handwoven woolens and Namda rugs from Leh and Kargil show Ladakh’s rich wool craft tradition. They use yak and sheep wool to make dyed and distinct textiles. The GST reduction from 12% to 5% lowers production costs and encourages people to keep making traditional handicrafts. This benefits local artisans and cooperatives that work with wool and rugs.

Wool Felt Products & Woollen Accessories:
Wool felt items and woollen accessories from Leh and Changthang, such as felt boots, hats, and gloves, add to Ladakh’s craft culture. These items are used locally and are also popular with tourists. The GST reduction from 12% to 5% supports small‑scale, seasonal cottage industries that process wool and make products. It is expected to strengthen Ladakh’s economy by increasing incomes for artisans.

Traditional Ladakhi Carpentry:
Traditional carpentry from Leh and Kargil features intricately carved wooden altars, window frames, and furniture. The GST reduction from 12% to 5% is expected to make these handcrafted items more affordable and competitive in the market. This will support craftsmen, many of whom come from marginalized communities, and encourage the preservation of Ladakh’s cultural and artistic heritage.

Ladakhi Thangka Paintings:
Thangka paintings are traditional Buddhist scroll artworks made in monasteries in Leh, Alchi, and Hemis. They are used for meditation and decoration. The GST reduction from 12% to 5% makes these intricate paintings more affordable and economically viable, helping preserve a vital part of Ladakh’s cultural heritage.

Local Tourism & Homestays:
Local tourism and homestays across Leh, Nubra, Pangong, and Kargil support Ladakh’s service economy and directly employ over 25,000 people. The GST reduction from 12% to 5% on hotel tariffs up to ₹7,500 per night makes travel and accommodation more affordable, especially during the busy tourist season. This will support the growth of eco‑tourism and the local homestay economy.

Apricots & Apricot Products:
Ladakh is India’s largest apricot producer, with Kargil, Leh, and the Nubra Valley as its main production hubs. The GST reduction from 12% to 5% benefits more than 6,000 farming families that grow and process apricots. This is expected to improve the competitiveness of locally produced apricots and their value‑added products such as dried apricots, jams, and oils, making them more market‑viable. It will create better income opportunities and encourage growth in apricot production businesses.

Sea Buckthorn Products:
Sea buckthorn, grown across the Nubra Valley, Leh, and Changthang, is known for its medicinal and nutritional benefits. Women‑led Self‑Help Groups (SHGs) play a key role in harvesting and processing these berries. The GST reduction from 12% to 5% is expected to enhance the competitiveness of locally made sea buckthorn products, making them more affordable and market‑viable.

Yak Cheese & Milk Products:
Yak cheese and milk products from Changthang and Nubra are traditional dairy items produced by Ladakh’s nomadic communities. The GST reduction from 12% to 5% will support self‑sustainability in remote, high‑altitude areas and strengthen the local economy.

Leh Berry (Buckthorn Berry):
Leh berry, or buckthorn berry, from Leh and Nubra is used to make health drinks and supplements. The GST cut from 12% to 5% will encourage investment in local agro‑processing, lift small producers, and increase competitiveness.

Organic Farming Products:
In Sham Valley and Kargil, organic farming is gaining momentum, with farmers producing herbal teas, dried vegetables, etc. The GST reduction from 12% to 5% supports small‑scale eco‑farmers by lowering costs and improving profitability. This is expected to encourage wider adoption of sustainable farming practices while strengthening Ladakh’s organic farming economy.

Conclusion:
The recent GST reforms mark a transformative step for Ladakh’s economy by empowering traditional artisans and farmers. From Pashmina weavers and apricot growers to sea buckthorn processors and homestay owners, each sector stands to gain through reduced costs, improved competitiveness, and higher incomes. Together, these reforms will preserve Ladakh’s rich cultural heritage, strengthen its eco‑friendly industries, and make local products more affordable and marketable.

announcements.title: SOAR: Helping People Learn with AI
announcements.content:
Key Takeaways Introduction
The global workforce is changing a lot because of AI, machine learning, data science, and automation. As AI is used in many fields like health care, money, schools, factories, and public work, people need to learn basic AI skills and get special training. The Skilling for AI Readiness (SOAR) program in India is a project by the Ministry of Skill Development and Entrepreneurship (MSDE) that adds AI skills to India’s schools. It fits the government’s aim to lead in new technology. Launched in July 2025, the program comes at the 10‑year mark of the Skill India Mission, which has helped people since 2015, adding new areas like AI under PMKVY 4.0.

SOAR’s Mission: Empowering the Future
Artificial Intelligence: Changing India’s Schools
AI is changing India’s schools by encouraging new ideas, boosting digital learning, and readying students for a tech world. The National Education Policy (NEP) 2020 says schools should teach modern subjects like AI at the right ages to grow creativity and digital skills. CBSE already teaches AI in its schools. It started in Class IX in 2019‑2020 and moved to Class XI in 2020‑2021. It focuses on real uses such as skill growth and personalized learning. The Government of India is setting up a Centre for AI Excellence to push AI use in schools. The aim is to use AI for Indian languages, help students think critically, and shift from chalkboards to chipsets. This centre will help the nation build AI tools and people. AICTE‑approved schools are also encouraged to offer AI as a choice. IITs give advanced AI courses like Deep Learning, Machine Learning, and Predictive Data Analytics.

The Government is putting AI and digital lessons into the Skill India Mission (SIM) to make a future‑ready workforce. It works through PMKVY 4.0, NAPS, ITIs, NSTIs, and the Skill India Digital Hub (SIDH). PMKVY 4.0 started in 2015, focuses on short training, up‑skilling, and recognizing prior learning, with a focus on future skills like AI. NAPS started in 2016; NAPS‑2 is its second phase and helps apprenticeships.

SOAR: Relevance and Expected Outcomes
Strategic Alignment with Skill India Mission
SOAR backs the Skill India Mission by giving students special modules, giving young people the digital skills needed to get jobs and work better in AI fields. Contribution to Viksit Bharat Vision
The program pushes India’s plan to be a developed country by 2047, using AI for All projects. It creates a tech‑savvy workforce that uses AI to grow innovation and compete worldwide, as seen in national skill plans. Promotion of Digital Inclusion
SOAR helps close the city‑rural digital gap by putting AI lessons on open platforms like the Skill India Digital Hub. This gives equal digital skills to all schools, helping poor groups. AI‑Aware Students and Trained Teachers
SOAR wants students to understand AI and use it ethically, and to train teachers in government and private schools to improve teaching and make AI common in classrooms. Boosting AI Career Interest and Narrowing Skill Gaps
The SOAR program will raise young people’s interest in AI jobs through hands‑on training. It also reduces the city‑rural gap in digital skills by giving wide training and access to high‑demand tech skills.

Conclusion
The SOAR program is a major step to make India a global leader in AI‑based education and jobs. By putting AI learning in school and vocational courses, SOAR gives students and teachers new skills and builds a culture of new ideas and ethical tech use. With partners and places like the Skill India Digital Hub, the program keeps everyone, no matter their background, able to learn, giving India’s youth power to drive tech and economic growth. As a key part of the Viksit Bharat @ 2047 plan, SOAR builds a digitally fair, competitive, and self‑sufficient India ready to shape future global innovation. References:

announcements.title: Deendayal Antyodaya Yojana – National Rural Livelihoods Mission
announcements.content:
Takeaways: The Deendayal Antyodaya Yojana – National Rural Livelihood Mission (DAY‑NRLM) is a major program run by the Ministry of Rural Development, Government of India. It aims to reduce poverty by helping poor families find good self‑employment and skilled wage jobs, giving them lasting and varied income sources.
DAY‑NRLM gathers rural poor families into Self‑Help Groups (SHGs). It keeps supporting them in their business activities until they earn more and leave deep poverty.
DAY‑NRLM’s impact is clear in many rural stories. For example, in Meghalaya, Heinidamanki Kanai started as an entrepreneur after joining the Kyrshanlang Self‑Help Group (SHG) in January 2020. With help from her SHG and the National Rural Livelihoods Mission (NRLM), she began making handmade soaps (rose, aloe vera, orange, and lemongrass). Her hard work paid off in August 2023, just a few months after she began her shop in April. Recognizing her talent, she got a bank loan of Rs. 1.8 lakh through her SHG. She used the money to buy new machines, tools, and even ran lab tests to keep her soaps high quality. Her business grew steadily. Her yearly income surpassed Rs. 1 lakh, changing her life and giving her confidence to aim higher. She also taught soap making to other SHG members in her village, sharing knowledge and encouraging others to start their own businesses.
The National Rural Livelihood Mission (NRLM) began in 2010 after changing the old Swarnajayanti Grameen Swarojgar Yojana (SGSY). In 2016 it became Deendayal Antyodaya Yojana – National Rural Livelihood Mission (DAY‑NRLM). Both central and state governments fund it. It is one of the world's biggest programs to lift the poor out of poverty. The Mission reaches its goal by investing in four main areas. DAY‑NRLM builds strong groups like Self‑Help Groups (SHGs) for poor people, especially women. It helps these groups get many financial and livelihood services. The groups get long‑term help to diversify income, raise earnings, and improve life quality. Women in SHGs are trained as community resource persons (CRPs) – such as Krishi Sakhis (agriculture helpers), Pashu Sakhis (animal helpers), Bank Sakhis, Bima Sakhis, and Banking Correspondent Sakhis. The Mission also trains SHG women on topics like domestic violence, women’s education, gender issues, nutrition, sanitation, and health. The SHGs aim to help:
The mission’s main goal is to cut poverty by helping poor households, especially women, get financial services, diversify jobs, and live better.
Financially, the mission helps women by building community groups that offer finance, technical help, and marketing support.
DAY‑NRLM has given more than Rs. 11 lakh crores in credit to women SHGs through banks. Women trained as Bank Sakhis and Banking Correspondent Sakhis help SHGs connect with banks. The large credit package, with collateral‑free loans, interest help, and other support, has a very good repayment rate of over 98%, showing the program works well.
DAY‑NRLM helps with both farm and non‑farm jobs. It supports women farmers, called “Mahila Kisans,” by teaching eco‑friendly farming. It has reached 4.62 crore women. Trained helpers called KrishiSakhi and PashuSakhi work with them all year. The mission also supports small businesses in crafts and food processing through the Start‑up Village Entrepreneurship Program (SVEP), which has helped more than 3.74 lakh businesses. The Mission also trains SHG women on domestic violence, women’s education, gender issues, nutrition, sanitation, and health.
Krishi Sakhi is an Agriculture Helper (CASP) who gives local support where farm services are hard to get. She teaches sustainable farming and helps farmers sell produce. Bank Sakhi is a trained SHG member who works at a bank. She helps SHGs open savings accounts, do credit and debit transactions, and links them to loans and other banking services. Pashu Sakhi is an Animal‑Care Helper (CASP) who provides local animal services where vets are scarce. She teaches animal care, helps farmers market animal products, and boosts rural income.
DAY‑NRLM has brought 10.05 crore rural women’s families into more than 90.90 lakh SHGs in 28 states and 6 union territories. Other key achievements are:
High‑performing states in DAY‑NRLM: In FY 2024‑25 (as of 28 Feb 2025), several states performed well. For SHG capital support, Uttar Pradesh gave ₹1,23,326 lakh and Bihar gave ₹1,05,132 lakh, both above targets. Andhra Pradesh gave the most loan money to SHGs, ₹34,83,725 lakh. For eco‑friendly farming, Maharashtra helped the most “Mahila Kisans” (12,97,051 women), then Uttar Pradesh (11,37,950) and Andhra Pradesh (10,43,085). For non‑farm businesses, Assam supported 9,557 enterprises under SVEP, followed by Kerala (5,802) and West Bengal (4,933).
The Ministry runs two central schemes under DAY‑NRLM to give rural poor youth job skills and help lift them out of poverty. The programs are:
High‑performing states in DDU‑GKY (2014‑15 to June 2025): Uttar Pradesh trained 2,44,528 people, Odisha 2,15,409, and Andhra Pradesh 1,33,842. For job placements, Odisha placed 1,77,165 people, and Andhra Pradesh placed 1,17,881.
Top states in RSETI (2014‑15 to June 2025): Uttar Pradesh trained 7,55,966 people and helped 5,54,877 start businesses. Rajasthan trained 4,34,478 and settled 3,19,948. Madhya Pradesh trained 4,36,835 and settled 3,08,280. Karnataka trained 4,19,299 and settled 3,05,397.
The Government is giving advanced training and marketing skills to SHG women. Learn more at https://www.pib.gov.in/FeaturesDeatils.aspx?NoteId=155247&ModuleId=2. DAY‑NRLM is a key part of reducing rural poverty and empowering women in India.
It has made credit, skills, and markets more available, giving steady jobs and financial safety. By focusing on training, business, and linking with other government programs, NRLM has broadened incomes and strengthened the rural economy. Good tracking, strong SHG‑bank ties, and training make it transparent and accountable, driving inclusive growth and better lives in villages.

announcements.title: Tripura’s economy gets a boost from GST cuts
announcements.content: Key Takeaways Introduction Tripura is in northeast India. It is famous for its beautiful scenery, lively culture, and rich history. About 60% of its land is forest and 24% is farmland. The state is often called the Daughter of Mother Nature. Its economy still depends a lot on farming and related work. The climate and soil are good for many garden crops like pineapple, jackfruit, and other tropical fruits. Tripura is also known for tea and has good chances for silk farming because of its weather and old silk‑rearing traditions. Handloom weaving, handicrafts, and traditional arts are strong in Tripura. These sectors are getting new chances because GST has lower rates. Lower tax for handloom fabrics, stitched clothes, some teas, and silk products help local makers, weavers, and farmers reach more customers while keeping prices low. The GST changes make the rural economy stronger, create jobs, and keep Tripura’s role in northeast India. Handloom Textiles Handloom weaving is a well‑known industry in Tripura. The Risa and Tripura Pachra‑Rignai textiles have special Geographical Indication (GI) tags. More than 1.3 lakh households make handloom products. Tripura Risa Textile The Risa textile has a GI tag and comes from the Tripuri tribal people. Women in the Killa Mahila Cluster Level Federation in the Gomati district lead the weaving. The craft uses back‑strap looms. Risa cloth is a traditional wrap used as a head‑cloth, shawl, or upper garment for women. It is also given as a gift to respected guests. The Tripura Rural Livelihood Mission supports and promotes Risa textiles. They mainly sell in local markets. The new GST rate is about 5% for fabrics, and stitched clothes priced up to ₹2,500 are now taxed at 5% instead of 12%. This 7‑percentage‑point drop helps Tripura’s local women earn more and keeps the culture alive. Tripura Pachra‑Rignai Textile The Pachra‑Rignai textile also has a GI tag. Women weave it in Gomati, Unakoti, North, West, South, Sepahijala, Khowai, and Dhalai districts. The Rignai is a skirt; the Pachra is a wrap. They are worn daily and at ceremonies. Sales are mainly in the state and at craft fairs, with more online sales growing. GST changes keep the price low: unstitched fabric stays at 5% GST; stitched clothes up to ₹2,500 now have 5% GST instead of 12%. The 7‑percentage‑point cut makes them cheaper and easier to sell. Tea Tripura grows many kinds of tea: black CTC, green, and organic. It is grown in all districts. There are 54 tea estates and 2,755 small growers. The tea is sold through auctions in Guwahati and Kolkata. Some tea reaches northern and western India and local shops. Tripura also exports to Bangladesh, the Middle East, and Europe. GST lowered packaged tea tax from 18% to 5%. This helps lower cost and expands market. Sericulture Silk farming is important for many rural families. In many districts, small farmers grow mulberry and non‑mulberry for silk. About 15,550 farmers grow silk. They handle all steps: cocoons, silk production, and reeling. GST cut from 12% to 5% (a 6.25% benefit) makes silk products cheaper. This helps small producers reach markets and grow income. Food Processing Food processing is driven by small farmers. The main fruit is the GI‑tagged Tripura Queen Pineapple. Farmers also grow jackfruit. Micro and small units under PM‑FME help add value and create jobs. NABARD reports 2,848 units in Tripura. Between FY 2018–19 and FY 2024–25, 73 metric tons of pineapple went to Dubai, Oman, Qatar, Bangladesh, and 15,000 metric tons to other Indian states. GST lowered the tax on fruit and vegetable juices from 12% to 5%. This cuts cost and makes products more affordable. Conclusion Lower GST rates give new energy to Tripura’s traditional and farming sectors. Reducing tax from 12–18% to 5% in handloom, tea, silk, and food processing lowers cost, makes products cheaper, and lets more people buy them. The reforms support tribal women, artisans, and small farmers and help Tripura grow and export. GST is helping the rural economy and keeping Tripura as a key growth spot in northeast India. announcements.title: India’s 2047 aviation plan: soaring skies, growing economy
announcements.content:
Key Takeaways

Introduction

Connectivity is a bridge that turns places into chances. It is not just about today, but history shows that better links between regions helped those areas grow, trade increase, and the economy become fairer. Even now, connectivity matters for tourism, trade, emergencies, and less reliance on foreign markets.

One important driver of the growing domestic market is UDAN (Ude Desh ka Aam Nagrik), a regional travel plan that started on 21 October 2016. After nine years, UDAN has moved from a pilot to a national success. It connects distances and lets people across the country fly easily.

India’s Aviation: Soaring Towards Inclusive Growth

In the last decade, India’s skies have become busier than ever. India is now the world’s third‑largest domestic aviation market. The number of airports grew from 74 in 2014 to 163 in 2025. By 2047, when India celebrates 100 years of independence, the government plans to have 350‑400 airports.

The aviation sector is one of the fastest‑growing parts of India’s economy. It supports air transport services and indirectly helps tourism, trade, logistics, and manufacturing. According to the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), each rupee spent on aviation creates more than three times that value in economic activity and supports more than six times as many jobs in related industries.

Today, the sector directly creates 369,000 jobs and indirectly supports over 7.7 million jobs. The demand for skilled workers—pilots, engineers, ground staff, and logistics professionals—is expected to rise sharply.

With 116 bilateral Air Service Agreements, India is deepening global links as its carriers expand abroad, strengthening India’s role as an aviation hub in Asia.

Civil aviation also drives FDI inflows, technology transfer, and Make in India initiatives in aircraft manufacturing, ground handling, and Maintenance, Repair, and Operations (MRO) services.

Over the past decade, domestic air passenger traffic grew 10‑12% annually. By 2040, passenger traffic is expected to rise six‑fold to about 1.1 billion. India’s commercial airline fleet is projected to grow from 400 in 2014 to around 2,359 in March 2040. Total employment from aviation in 2040 is expected to reach about 25 million, making it a core engine of India’s journey toward a developed economy.

UDAN: Democratizing Air Travel for Every Citizen

From metro cities to mountain valleys, the Indian sky now maps new possibilities—connecting small towns, boosting tourism, and driving local economies. The heart of this change is the UDAN scheme under the Ministry of Civil Aviation (MoCA), which has made air travel accessible and reshaped regional connectivity.

According to NITI Aayog, domestic travellers accounted for over 83% of total tourism spending in 2019, a figure expected to rise to nearly 89% by 2028. This shift shows how UDAN and similar initiatives have bridged infrastructure gaps and made air travel affordable and reachable for millions.

This transformation has also changed India’s travel map. Once remote destinations—Kullu, Darbhanga, Hubballi, and Shillong—are now directly connected by air, boosting local economies and regional tourism.

The vision of UDAN highlighted the need to open air travel to all, a sentiment that sparked a more inclusive aviation sector. This commitment to the common man’s dreams led to the birth of UDAN.

UDAN Achievement: Looking Ahead – Vision For 2047

As India approaches its centenary of independence, the aviation sector aims for ambitious growth—from 163 airports in 2025 to over 350 by 2047, and passenger traffic expected to cross one billion.

These goals represent a shift toward cleaner fuels, digital airways, and inclusive mobility. With 25 million jobs projected by 2047 and expanding opportunities in MRO, drone manufacturing, and pilot training, aviation will become a vital pillar of India’s $10 trillion economy.

Following initiatives in the aviation sector are key to achieving India’s 2047 vision—connecting remote regions, supporting livelihoods, and advancing sustainable growth.

Krishi UDAN

Launched in September 2020, Krishi UDAN speeds up transport of agricultural produce and perishables, especially for tribal and northeastern states. In partnership with the Operation Greens Scheme, it offers 50% freight subsidy, multimodal transport options, and coverage of horticulture and allied produce.

Lifeline UDAN

This special initiative started in March 2020, during the COVID‑19 lockdown, to ensure uninterrupted medical and essential supply deliveries. Over 588 flights carried 1,000 tons of cargo across 5.45 lakh km, focusing on the North Eastern region, the Islands, and hilly terrains. Lifeline UDAN also helped set up COVID labs, transport medical teams, and respond to emergencies like the Vishakhapatnam gas leak.

Greenfield Airports Policy

The Greenfield Airports Policy creates a framework for building new airports on unused land through public‑private partnerships to expand India’s aviation infrastructure and relieve metro hubs.

Enhancing Travel Experience

To improve travel, reduce delays, and save time, the government launched several initiatives including Digi Yatra. From 2022 onwards, Digi Yatra enabled paperless, contactless processing of passengers using facial recognition technology. By March 2025, more than 52.2 million passengers used this service. The Digi Yatra App is available on Android and iOS platforms and has been downloaded by over 12.1 million users.

Flight Training and Pilot Development

To meet the projected demand of 30,000–34,000 pilots in the next 10–15 years, the government is expanding Flight Training Organizations (FTOs) and commercial pilot licensing. Promoting gender inclusion, with 13–18% women pilots, DGCA targets 25% female representation in all aviation roles by 2025.

Drone Rules 2021, Production‑Linked Incentive (PLI)

The Drone Rules, 2021, liberalized India’s drone sector by simplifying regulations and enabling wider commercial use. The Production‑Linked Incentive (PLI) scheme, with Rs 34.79 crore disbursed in FY 24–25, has encouraged domestic manufacturing and reduced reliance on imports, boosting India’s self‑reliant drone ecosystem.

Bharatiya Vayuyan Adhiniyam, 2024

This legislative reform modernises India’s aviation sector by re‑enacting the Aircraft Act, 1934, to fit current needs and global standards. The new law supports indigenous manufacturing under Make in India and Atmanirbhar Bharat, aligns with the Chicago Convention and ICAO, and streamlines regulatory processes such as license issuance. It removes redundancies and provides provisions for appeals.

Conclusion

India’s civil aviation sector has become one of the fastest‑growing parts of the economy, making the country the third‑largest domestic aviation market worldwide. As the country continues to record unprecedented rises in passenger traffic, expand regional connectivity, and modernise aviation frameworks, the ministry’s efforts improve travel experiences for millions and boost economic prosperity, national integration, and India’s confidence in reaching its goal of becoming a developed nation—Viksit Bharat @2047.
