announcements.title: National plan for blockchain technology
announcements.content:
Key Takeaways: Introduction

Blockchain began as a technology linked to cryptocurrencies, but it has now become one of the most important digital changes of the 21st century. Unlike Artificial Intelligence (AI), which depends on huge computing power, blockchain’s strength lies in its ability to prove trust without a middleman.

India’s current systems often use single, central databases that can have errors, fraud and low transparency. Blockchain solves these problems with a tamper‑resistant, distributed ledger. Records are kept safely on many computers (nodes). It is almost impossible to change them without notice, so data integrity and trust are much better.

Seeing its big potential, the Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology (MeitY) created the National Blockchain Framework (NBF). NBF gives a single structure for building blockchain projects across many sectors. It shows how to use blockchain in public services to make them clearer, more responsible and faster.

What is Blockchain?

Blockchain is a shared, clear, safe and unchangeable database that works like a ledger of records or transactions. It can’t be tampered with and anyone on the network can see it.

Types of Blockchain

The core strengths of blockchain – transparency, immutability, decentralization and trust – are the focus of the National Blockchain Framework. These features let us build secure and efficient digital systems. They are especially important for improving government, better citizen services and reducing bureaucracy.

National Blockchain Framework: India’s Indigenous Platform for Secure and Scalable Digital Governance

The National Blockchain Framework (NBF) started in March 2021 with a budget of ₹64.76 crore and was officially launched on 4 September 2024. It is designed to speed up the creation and use of permissioned blockchain applications. This is a key step toward a secure, open and scalable digital infrastructure for India.

Technology Stack – Vishvasya Blockchain Stack

At the heart of the NBF is the Vishvasya Blockchain Stack. It is a homegrown, modular platform that gives the technical base for building and running blockchain apps for government.

Key features of Vishvasya Blockchain Stack:

• NBFLite – A sandbox version of the stack for startups and academics. NBFLite lets entrepreneurs, research labs and students try out blockchain in a safe space without needing a full launch. It comes with smart‑contract templates for important government and industry areas such as Supply Chain and Digital Certificates, so users can create and test apps quickly.

• Praamaanik – A new blockchain tool that checks if a mobile app is real and where it came from. In today’s fast‑moving digital world, it is vital to stop harmful apps and fake support. When a user scans an app, Praamaanik compares its details with blockchain records. If it matches, the app is genuine, building trust in the mobile market.

National Blockchain Portal

The National Blockchain Portal shows India’s plan for using blockchain in government and business. The site helps people innovate, set standards and use blockchain across different industries. It builds confidence and shows India’s leadership in new technology.

India’s NBF is one of the few government projects worldwide that supports blockchain across many sectors.

Blockchain‑Enabled Chains

Transforming Governance, Supply Chains and Justice

India is moving toward a trusted digital economy with coordinated work by regulators and tech makers. NBF supplies the core tools for using blockchain in government, supply chains and enterprises.

Certificates and Document Chain

The current way of giving and using certificates has problems like fake papers and slow service. To fix this, the National Informatics Centre (NIC) uses blockchain to create a “Certificate Chain.” This chain securely stores and retrieves certificates.

One use is the academic papers of the Central Board of Secondary Education stored on the blockchain. The Document Chain is a single platform that gives issuing bodies and users a standard method for storing and getting any government‑issued document such as caste certificates, income certificates, ration cards, driving licences, birth and death certificates, etc.

More than 34 crore documents have been verified securely through India’s blockchain platform, including over 48 000 documents in the Document Chain, as of 21 October 2025.

Logistics Chain

The Logistics Chain gives a safe and clear way to track goods across many stakeholders. Using blockchain, every transaction in the supply chain is recorded on a tamper‑proof ledger, giving traceability and accountability at each step.

One example is the Online Supply Chain Management System for medicines (Aushada) in Karnataka. Aushada is linked to blockchain to record movements of drugs from manufacturers to hospitals, including quality checks. Patients can view the maker, expiry date and quality of medicine before buying. This traceability reduces the chance of fake drugs, improves accuracy and adds openness.

Judiciary Chain

The Judiciary Chain uses blockchain to make the justice system clearer, faster and more reliable. It gives a secure, unchangeable and time‑stamped record of court data and documents.

Blockchain helps send notices, summons and bail orders electronically, cutting delays and removing manual steps. As of 21 October 2025, 665 judicial documents have been verified on the blockchain platform.

Inter‑Operable Criminal Justice System

Building on the Judiciary Chain, the Inter‑Operable Criminal Justice System (ICJS) connects the whole criminal‑justice ecosystem. It gives a single digital platform for case records, evidence and court documents. Over 39 000 ICJS documents have been verified on the blockchain platform, as of 21 October 2025.

Property Chain

The blockchain‑powered Property Management System records every property transaction on the ledger. Even when land records are updated or transferred, all parties can see the full history before making decisions. This clarity helps buyers verify ownership, rights and liabilities, cutting lawsuits and speeding up dispute resolution.

As of 21 October 2025, more than 34 crore property documents are verified through the blockchain platform.

Strategic Roadmap and Regulatory Initiatives for Blockchain Adoption in India

MeitY’s National Strategy on Blockchain shows a plan for developing blockchain technology in India. It tackles challenges and sets short‑term and long‑term goals for using blockchain across different fields.

Centre of Excellence (CoE) in Blockchain Technology (BCT)

The National Informatics Centre (NIC) has set up a Centre of Excellence (CoE). It helps government departments with advice, training and support for pilot projects before full roll‑out. The CoE supplies blockchain services and ICT infrastructure that let departments connect their systems and use BCT effectively. It has worked with popular blockchain platforms such as Hyperledger Sawtooth, Hyperledger Fabric and Ethereum – open‑source systems used to build safe and open digital networks.

Role of Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (TRAI) in BCT

TRAI has put blockchain‑based Distributed Ledger Technology (DLT) into the telecom world. It requires all Principal Entities (PEs) and Telemarketers (TMs) to register their message transmission chains, letting people see every step of an SMS from the sender to the receiver. This big project, done with regulators and service providers, has made consumer protection stronger, cut spam and shown how blockchain can enforce rules and build trust. It covered over 1.13 lakh entities in partnership with RBI, SEBI, NIC and C‑DAC.

Role of Reserve Bank of India in BCT

The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) uses blockchain to upgrade India’s financial system through pilot projects such as the Digital Rupee (e₹). The retail pilot started in December 2022 with a small group of customers and merchants. It shows how blockchain makes payments instant, traceable and clear, while encouraging financial inclusion and new payment ideas.

NSDL’s Adoption of Blockchain for Debenture Covenant Monitoring

The National Securities Depository Limited (NSDL), India’s biggest depository, launched a DLT‑based blockchain platform for Debenture Covenant Monitoring. This big step modernises India’s capital markets. The platform lets issuers and trustees record asset charges, watch asset cover ratios and track covenants on a secure digital ledger. The ledger is tamper‑proof, cryptographically signed and time‑stamped, giving a clear audit trail and boosting investor confidence.

Capacity Building Initiatives in Blockchain Technology

To build a skilled workforce in emerging tech like blockchain, MeitY started several training programmes. These aim to make the workforce ready for the future.

Skill Development Programme

The Capacity Building Division of Digital India Corporation (MeitY) ran Skill Development Programmes for government officials, giving them tech knowledge across departments. More than 214 programmes trained over 21 000 officials in new fields like Blockchain. Supported by State e‑Mission Teams (SeMTs), these efforts are creating a government workforce ready to lead technology‑driven governance.

Post Graduate Diploma in FinTech & Blockchain Development (PG‑DFBD)

The rise of cryptocurrencies, NFTs (non‑fungible tokens) and other blockchain uses has increased demand for faster, cheaper and safer platforms, driving growth in the FinTech sector. To meet this need, the PG‑DFBD offers a 900‑hour curriculum that covers Blockchain, FinTech, AI/ML, cybersecurity, programming and regulatory frameworks.

BLEND: C‑DAC Online Course

The BLEND programme, offered by the Centre for Development of Advanced Computing (C‑DAC), is an online course for engineering students and early‑career workers to learn blockchain and its real‑world uses. The course gives a deep understanding of blockchain ideas, architecture and operations, and lets participants build real projects in many fields.

FutureSkills PRIME

FutureSkills PRIME (Programme for Re‑skilling/Up‑skilling of IT Manpower for Employability) is a industry‑focused initiative backed by MeitY. It equips India’s workforce with digital skills in ten new technologies, including blockchain, to improve employability and strengthen the country’s tech talent.

Way Forward: Future Blockchain Use Cases

Many blockchain use cases are being explored to improve efficiency and trust in public services. These show how blockchain can drive innovation in governance, ensuring accountability and cutting systemic problems. Key proof‑of‑concepts include:

• Land Records – secure ownership data
• Blood Bank – open donation tracking
• GST Chain – real‑time tax monitoring
• Public Distribution System (PDS) – secure supply chains

Conclusion

Aligned with Digital India and Aatmanirbhar Bharat, blockchain technology is changing how trust and openness are built into digital governance. Through the National Blockchain Framework, India is creating a connected and interoperable blockchain system that supports government‑to‑citizen (G2C) and government‑to‑business (G2B) services, driving innovation and self‑reliance in technology. With a steady focus on training and homegrown blockchain solutions, India is ready to become a global leader in using blockchain for inclusive growth.

References

- Rajya Sabha
- Ministry of Communications
- Ministry of Finance
- Digital India Corporation
- National Informatics Centre
- National Institute of Electronics & Information Technology
- Centre of Excellence in Blockchain Technology

announcements.title: GST simplification helps Karnataka grow from coffee farms to tech hubs
announcements.content:
Key Takeaways
Introduction
Karnataka is at the crossroads of tradition and technology. The smell of Coorg's coffee plantations mixes with the sound of machines in Peenya and Hosur. From the fisheries on the coast of Dakshina Kannada to the craft centers of Mysuru and Bidar, the state's economy shows India's variety, strength, and entrepreneurial spirit. The recent GST changes are a big step for Karnataka. They give relief in agriculture, manufacturing, and services. By lowering taxes on important goods like coffee, dairy, clothing, handicrafts, coir, and essential industrial supplies, the reforms will make things cheaper, boost local demand, and help small businesses and exporters compete. With the new tax structure, farmers, artisans, and business owners in Karnataka will pay less in paperwork, build better supply chains, and reach more markets. The changes match India's aim to simplify taxes and support Karnataka's goal of inclusive, innovation‑led, and sustainable growth.
Coffee
Karnataka is the heart of India's coffee industry, producing about 71% of the country's coffee. Its plantations are mainly in Kodagu, Chikkamagaluru, and Hassan. Most growers are small or marginal farmers. About 6.7 lakh people in India grow and process coffee, most of them in Karnataka's Malenadu region. The GST cut from 18% to 5% on coffee extracts, essences, and instant coffee gives a big tax relief. It is expected to lower retail prices by 11–12%. This will increase local demand, give better profits to small processors and cooperatives, and close the gap between India's coffee consumption and that of other countries. Karnataka's shade‑grown Arabica and Robusta varieties – Coorg Arabica, Chikmagalur Arabica, and Bababudangiris Arabica – all have GI tags. They are strongly demanded in Italy, Germany, and Switzerland. The tax cut makes Karnataka's coffee producers more competitive both at home and abroad.
Dairy
The Karnataka Milk Federation (KMF) leads the state's dairy sector, which is a key part of the rural economy. It supports more than 26 lakh milk producers, most of them small and marginal farmers. With over 15,000 primary dairy co‑ops across Karnataka, including big processing hubs in Bengaluru, Mysuru, Hassan, and Tumakuru, the sector gives jobs to about 22 lakh people in rural and semi‑urban areas. KMF's brand Nandini is a symbol of cooperative success, linking farmers to city shoppers. In FY24, Karnataka produced 13.46 million tonnes of milk, and KMF sold an average of 52.7 lakh litres per day, making it India's second‑largest dairy cooperative. The new GST cuts – from 5% to nil on UHT milk and paneer, and from 12% to 5% on ghee and butter – will lower retail prices by 5–7%, increase demand for value‑added products, and improve cooperative profits. This helps consumers and lets KMF give better, steadier prices to its farmer members, strengthening dairy as a source of rural income and women's empowerment.
Cashew
In Dakshina Kannada and Udupi, the coastal districts of Karnataka, cashew processing is a major industry. It is labor‑intensive and employs many women from rural and vulnerable communities. Dakshina Kannada alone has about 66 processing units. The GST cut from 12% to 5% on processed cashew nuts is expected to lower prices by 6–7%. This will give better profits to small processors and exporters. India is a big global player in the cashew trade, exporting kernels to the UAE, Japan, and the Netherlands. The tax change should increase local demand and help keep incomes steady for the coastal women who work in this sector.
Coir
The coir sector, found in Tumakuru, Hassan, Chikkamagaluru, and coastal Karnataka, is a traditional cottage industry that gives important non‑farm jobs, especially to women. It is supported by the Karnataka State Coir Development Corporation and the Central Coir Board. Nationally, about 5.5 lakh people work in coir. Karnataka, a big coconut producer, has great room for growth. India is the world's largest maker and exporter of coir products, mainly to the USA and China. The GST cut from 12% to 5% on coir mats, rugs, and geotextiles will make them 6–7% cheaper, improving competition with synthetic products. The reform promotes a green economy, encourages eco‑friendly coconut husk products, and helps MSMEs grow. It can create a lot more non‑farm jobs, especially for women, supporting national job creation programs like the PMEGP.
Fisheries
Karnataka has a 320 km long coast that includes Dakshina Kannada, Udupi, and Uttara Kannada. It supports many traditional fishing families and a strong seafood processing industry that creates many jobs, especially for women. The sector employs lakhs of fishermen and workers in processing plants, cold storage, and export houses. Karnataka is 5th in India's marine fish production. Most fish is eaten locally, but demand for processed seafood such as canned, frozen, and ready‑to‑eat products is growing in India and abroad. The GST cut from 12% to 5% on processed fish and marine products will reduce prices of items like canned tuna, frozen shrimp, and ready‑to‑eat fish curries by about 6–7%. This helps add value in the fisheries chain, encourages local processing, gives more stable jobs, and lessens reliance on changing export markets. By improving competitiveness for seafood MSMEs and cooperatives, the reform directly supports coastal livelihoods and lets fishing communities get more value from this important resource.
Agricultural Machinery
Lowering GST on tractors, farm machinery, and parts is a big move to boost rural productivity and industry in Karnataka. With more than 78 lakh farmers, most small and marginal, cutting GST from 12% to 5% on tractors and machinery and from 18% to 5% on parts will lower the cost of mechanisation. For example, a tractor costing ₹8 lakh now has GST of ₹40,000 instead of ₹96,000, saving about ₹56,000 for the farmer. This makes equipment easier to buy for farmers, Farmer Producer Organisations, and hiring centres, boosting productivity. Karnataka's industrial hubs in Hubli‑Dharwad, Belagavi, and the Bengaluru automotive corridor will also benefit, as the state has many MSMEs that make tractor parts and machinery. The auto component industry is strong, with companies like Toyota, TVS, Bosch, and others. Demand for farm machinery is likely to grow with the new GST, creating jobs for more than 55,000 workers and raising rural incomes. Linking cheaper machinery with a stronger manufacturing base creates a positive cycle of growth in both rural and industrial areas.
Textiles and Garments
The ready‑made garment (RMG) and textile sector is one of Karnataka's biggest job creators. Major centers are Bengaluru, Ballari, Hubli–Dharwad, and Mandya. Bengaluru is known as the "Garment Capital of India" and has more than 400 apparel units that supply global brands like Tommy Hilfiger, Nike, and Adidas. The sector employs about six lakh people, making it the second‑largest textile employer in India. Most workers are women, many from rural and low‑income families. Karnataka provides 20% of India's garment production and 11% of textile exports, worth about ₹4,000 crore, with the United States a top buyer. The new GST rules raise the threshold for the 5% rate from ₹1,000 to ₹2,500 per item, giving big relief to MSME apparel units. The reform reduces tax on more products, makes prices more competitive, and gives manufacturers more working capital. It should strengthen Karnataka's export‑focused garment clusters, boost women's jobs, and drive demand along the whole textile chain, from spinning in Davangere and Belagavi to production in Bengaluru and Ballari.
Granite
Karnataka is a major hub for India's granite industry, with quarrying and processing centers in Ramanagara, Chamarajanagar, Ballari, Koppal, and Raichur. The sector gives many jobs to quarry workers, machine operators, and logistics staff, most of whom come from marginalized and tribal groups. Karnataka accounts for about 32% of India's total granite exports, making it a key player worldwide. India mainly exports granite to China as raw blocks. The GST cut from 12% to 5% on granite blocks will reduce processing costs by 6–7%, improving profits for small and medium enterprises. This advantage should make Indian granite more competitive against global producers like Brazil and Norway and encourage more investment in modern machinery, safety, and environmental standards in Karnataka's quarrying areas.
Cement
Karnataka's cement industry, mainly in Kalaburagi and Ballari, is vital for industrial growth in North Karnataka. It takes advantage of rich limestone deposits and employs many skilled and semi‑skilled workers such as engineers, technicians, and logistics staff, and supports many related services. Major companies like Ultratech Cement and ACC make Karnataka an important supplier to construction and infrastructure projects across South India. The GST cut from 28% to 18% on cement is a major policy change that will lower retail prices by 7–8%. This cost saving will reduce expenses for housing, real estate, and public projects and increase demand for building materials. The growth in construction will create jobs for both skilled and unskilled workers and boost industrial and economic growth throughout Karnataka's industry and construction sectors.
Sandalwood and Soaps
Karnataka's connection to sandalwood is famous, especially through Mysore Sandal Soap made by Karnataka Soaps and Detergents Limited (KSDL) in Bengaluru. The soap uses sandalwood oil from across the state, where KSDL has long been the main supplier. The brand is a symbol of Karnataka's skill and heritage. Mysore Sandal Soap has a GI tag and accounts for about 75% of KSDL's revenue. The GST cut from 18% to 5% will lower retail prices by 11–12%, making the soap more competitive against big FMCG companies. The change will boost sales, improve profits, and help modernise and diversify products, keeping the brand a global symbol of Karnataka.
Drones
Bengaluru is the hub of India's drone industry, with big aerospace companies and many tech startups. The sector employs engineers, software developers, and technicians, driving high‑value innovation and industry diversification. Karnataka was the first state to introduce an aerospace policy, seeing the sector's huge investment potential. Key institutions like Hindustan Aeronautics Limited (HAL) and ISRO have built a strong technical base for drone work. The GST cut on unmanned aircraft (drones) from 18/28% to 5% gives a big tax break, reducing the cost of locally made drones by 11–20%. This helps drones compete against imports and speeds up use in areas such as agriculture, logistics, infrastructure monitoring, and defence. The reform strengthens Karnataka's leading role in drone manufacturing, creating jobs, advancing technology, and supporting the "Make in India" goal.
Ilkal & Udupi Handloom Sarees
Karnataka's weaving tradition is best seen in Ilkal (Bagalkot) and Udupi, where handloom weaving has been done for many years. The sector supports about 55,000 weaver families, many working from home or in cooperatives. They face problems like changing yarn prices and competition from power looms. Both Ilkal and Udupi sarees have GI tags. Ilkal sarees are famous for the Tope Teni technique that joins the body and pallu warp, and their red silk pallus. Udupi sarees are known for fine cotton and traditional designs. The GST cut from 12% to 5% on handloom sarees will lower prices by 6–7%, making them more competitive against mass‑produced alternatives. The reform should boost sales through cooperatives, government shops, private retailers, and online platforms, improving weaver incomes and keeping Karnataka's handloom tradition alive.
Bidriware
Bidriware comes only from Bidar and is one of India's finest metal crafts. It features silver wire set into a blackened zinc‑copper alloy using special soil from Bidar Fort. Bidriware has a GI tag and shows the skill passed down through many artisan families. The craft gives skilled jobs in the Bidar area, but low pay and competition from machine‑made items hurt workers. The GST cut from 12% to 5% gives a 6–7% price edge, making the handmade items cheaper and more competitive in domestic and tourist export markets. Bidriware is exported to more than 90 countries, so the reform should help artisans earn better, revive interest in the craft, and sustain livelihoods while preserving Karnataka's metal artistry.
Mysore Rosewood Inlay
This craft is done by skilled family teams near Mysuru. It is a key part of Karnataka's royal heritage and was supported by the Wodeyar dynasty and Tipu Sultan. The art uses coloured woods, mother‑of‑pearl, and other eco‑friendly materials to decorate rosewood furniture. Ivory used in the past is now replaced by sustainable options. The craft has a GI tag since 2005. Sales come from Cauvery Handicrafts shops, private galleries, and niche exports to the US and UK, with growing online demand. The GST cut from 12% to 5% will lower prices by 6–7%, improving affordability and competitiveness. For example, a rosewood dining set at $4,000 could save more than $250. This tax relief will boost profits for small family businesses, strengthening Mysuru's place in the global market for custom, high‑value wooden art.
Conclusion
The GST reforms give wide benefits to Karnataka's economy, from farmers growing coffee, dairy, and cashew to artisans making handlooms and crafts, and entrepreneurs leading industry and technology. Lower taxes cut costs, make products more competitive, and help add value in key sectors, giving more income to people in rural and urban areas. By linking traditional work with modern industry, the changes promote inclusive, job‑focused, and sustainable growth. The reforms are expected to raise productivity, increase local demand, and keep Karnataka as one of India's most dynamic, innovation‑driven state economies.

announcements.title: PM ABHIM program
announcements.content:
Key Takeaways
Introduction
During COVID‑19, services such as testing, case detection, surveillance, outbreak management, and critical care were in high demand. The pandemic showed that India must strengthen its health system at all levels—primary, secondary, and tertiary—to respond effectively to future outbreaks, emergencies, and changing health needs.

Pandemic Agreement of the World Health Organisation
In May 2025, WHO member states adopted the world’s first Pandemic Agreement after three years of negotiations about COVID‑19. The agreement aims to make pandemic responses fairer and to strengthen global coordination for prevention, preparedness, and response. It will help people obtain vaccines, diagnostics, and therapeutics fairly. The resolution outlines steps toward implementation, such as drafting an annex to create a Pathogen Access and Benefit‑Sharing (PABS) system through an Intergovernmental Working Group (IGWG). Once the World Health Assembly adopts it and 60 countries ratify it, the Agreement will enter into force. Member States also directed the IGWG to set up a Coordinating Financial Mechanism for pandemic prevention, preparedness, and response, and the Global Supply Chain and Logistics Network (GSCL) to ensure timely and affordable access to health products during pandemics. The Agreement complements the International Health Regulations, amended last year to improve global outbreak detection and response.

Launched on October 25, 2021, the Pradhan Mantri Ayushman Bharat Health Infrastructure Mission (PM‑ABHIM) focuses on health, research, and surveillance infrastructure. Over 2021‑26, the government is investing Rs. 64,180 crore to expand and strengthen primary healthcare institutions, enhance disease surveillance systems, support health research, and build pandemic preparedness. It also helps India achieve universal health coverage by constructing Ayushman Arogya Mandirs, public health labs, and critical care facilities.

Policy Framework
PM‑ABHIM strengthens India’s health system by building on the National Health Policy 2017 and linking with the National Health Mission and the Ayushman Bharat scheme. These are major health initiatives of the Government of India. While each program is distinct, they share similar goals and complement one another.

Policy Foundation: National Health Policy 2017
The National Health Policy 2017 stresses the importance of community health systems, with trained first responders working with local governments and community groups. These are crucial for disaster preparedness and public health emergencies. The National Health Mission, launched in 2005, creates community‑owned, decentralized health systems that provide affordable, quality care. It has made significant progress in maternal and child health, disease elimination, and health infrastructure. Its work has been key to India’s health improvements, especially during COVID‑19, and has helped bring better, more accessible care across the country. The 2017 policy reinforced these priorities and set the stage for further enhancement through the Ayushman Bharat scheme, which PM‑ABHIM now builds upon.

Ayushman Bharat Scheme
Launched in 2018, the Ayushman Bharat scheme builds on the National Health Mission to strengthen primary care through four main pillars. It makes quality healthcare available at all three levels—primary, secondary, and tertiary.

PM‑ABHIM: Key Objectives and Components
Launched in 2021, PM‑ABHIM is one of India’s largest national programmes. It aims to build a strong, accessible, and self‑reliant public health system. The mission works from the grassroots to the district level by building and upgrading Ayushman Arogya Mandirs (AAMs), Block Public Health Units, Integrated District Public Health Labs, and Critical Care Hospital Blocks in each district. These facilities will close gaps in service and provide comprehensive primary, secondary, and critical care close to people. PM‑ABHIM also focuses on pandemic and disaster readiness by expanding an IT‑enabled, real‑time disease‑watch network that links laboratories at block, district, regional, and national levels to detect, investigate, and stop outbreaks quickly. It encourages health research and innovation, especially on COVID‑19 and other infections, by using the One Health approach, which sees human, animal, and environmental health as connected. The mission also tries to fill gaps in cities and villages by creating Urban Health and Wellness Centres (AAM) in slums and turning Sub‑Centres into AAMs. Together, PM‑ABHIM aims to create a strong health system that can handle future emergencies and give fair, good care to all.

India wants to stop the spread of communicable diseases by 2030, achieve universal health coverage, and give everyone safe, affordable medicines and vaccines. These are part of Sustainable Development Goal – 3. The government backs the SDGs.

PM‑ABHIM: Key Initiatives
Under its Centrally Sponsored Scheme (CSS), PM‑ABHIM has made significant progress from FY 2021‑22 to FY 2025‑26. According to recent data, 17,788 Sub‑Health Centres with no buildings are approved to become Ayushman Arogya Mandirs (AAMs). 11,024 Urban AAMs (U‑AAMs) are being set up to bring primary care to slums and underserved city areas. 3,382 Block Public Health Units (BPHUs) are being created to strengthen block‑level health work. In every district, 730 Integrated Public Health Laboratories (IPHLs) are being built to improve testing and surveillance. For top‑level care, 602 Critical Care Hospital Blocks (CCBs) are being set up in districts with more than five lakh people. In total, the government has approved ₹32,928.82 crore for these projects, covering 9,519 AAMs, 5,456 U‑AAMs, 2,151 BPHUs, 744 IPHLs, and 621 CCBs. These moves help create a strong, local, and accessible health network that can give fast, good care to everyone.

Allocation of Resources
The money split by year for PM‑ABHIM is shown below. (Numbers are in crore rupees.)
2021‑22: 9155.97
2022‑23: 10465.09
2023‑24: 11015.80
2024‑25: 13551.30
2025‑26: 19356.40
Total for all years: 63544.56
Plus 1% for M&E and PMC: 64180

Conclusion
Four years after it started, PM‑ABHIM has transformed India’s health system by spending Rs. 64,180 crore to boost pandemic readiness and emergency help. It upgraded care from village clinics to large hospitals and improved disease‑watch systems, making the health system stronger. As India works toward Universal Health Coverage and SDG‑3, PM‑ABHIM’s focus on communities, working with Ayushman Bharat and global health plans, keeps the country ready to keep people healthy during emergencies.

References
Press Information Bureau: Ministry of Health and Family Welfare. Others: Click here to see PDF SK/RK.

announcements.title: INS Vikrant: India’s first home‑made aircraft carrier, a naval milestone
announcements.content:
Key Takeaways Introduction:
INS Vikrant, India's first indigenous aircraft carrier (IAC 1), shows India's ambition and self‑reliance.
It was designed by the Indian Navy’s Warship Design Bureau and built by Cochin Shipyard Limited (CSL).
It is the biggest warship ever made in India.
It joined the Indian Navy when the Prime Minister commissioned it on 2 September 2022.
INS Vikrant is a symbol of India’s local talent, resources and skills.
Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi celebrated Diwali 2025 on the ship, honoring the hard work and bravery of naval sailors and armed forces.
This visit continued his practice of celebrating Diwali with troops in forward and strategic locations, showing support for those who protect the country in all types of war.
The ship hosted the Prime Minister for an overnight sea trip from 19 to 20 October 2025.
The following activities were carried out during the trip:

History and Development:
INS Vikrant is named after India's first aircraft carrier, INS Vikrant (R11), which was retired in 1997.
The older INS Vikrant was key in the 1961 Goa Liberation Operation and the 1971 Indo‑Pak War, and it remains a source of pride in India's naval history.
The new INS Vikrant, India's first indigenous aircraft carrier (IAC 1), continues this legacy and marks an important step in the country's naval independence and shipbuilding ability.
A symbol of defence self‑reliance, INS Vikrant is more than a warship.
It shows India's hard work, skill, influence and commitment in the 21st century.

Capabilities and Specifications:
INS Vikrant’s technical and operational strengths are reflected in the following features:

Achievements:
Since it joined the Navy, INS Vikrant has become a key part of the nation's maritime power.
Its achievements show the carrier’s advanced abilities and strengthen India’s dedication to the SAGAR (Security and Growth for All in the Region) vision, promoting peace, stability and cooperation in the Indo‑Pacific.

• PM Day at Sea (October 2025):
The ship hosted the Prime Minister for an overnight sea trip from 19 to 20 October 2025 for Diwali.

INS Vikrant: A Pillar of Humanitarian Assistance and Disaster Relief (HADR):
Beyond its military role, Vikrant is a powerful tool for Humanitarian Assistance and Disaster Relief (HADR).
It has advanced technology and a strong design that makes it flexible for many tasks.
The ship uses a lot of automation for its engines, navigation and safety, which helps it work well during emergencies.
One key feature is its powerful generator, which can supply electricity equal to that needed for 5,000 homes, allowing it to keep working in far‑away or disaster areas.
The ship’s large aviation facilities let it act as a mobile command center, hospital and supply hub when needed.
INS Vikrant’s HADR role fits with India’s wider maritime plan, especially the 'SAGAR' (Security and Growth for All in the Region) program.
The Indian Navy has led many relief efforts during disasters and emergencies, boosting India’s reputation as the 'Preferred Security Partner' and 'First Responder' in the Indian Ocean Region.
When the Panama‑flagged MV Heilan Star sent a distress call about 230 nautical miles west of Goa, a Sea King helicopter from INS Vikrant carried three injured crew members to INS Hansa for medical care.
This mission showed the Indian Navy’s strong commitment to HADR beyond Indian waters.

A Milestone in India's Maritime Self‑Reliance:
Since 2014, Indian shipyards have delivered more than 40 local warships and submarines to the Navy, adding a new platform every 40 days on average.
This shows India’s enthusiasm for building stronger maritime security.
The creation and use of INS Vikrant is a major step in the Navy’s move toward self‑reliance.

Indigenous Design and Construction:
INS Vikrant was designed by the Indian Navy’s Warship Design Bureau (WDB) and built at Cochin Shipyard Limited (CSL).
The ship uses many local pieces of equipment and machinery, with major Indian companies such as BEL, BHEL, GRSE, Keltron, Kirloskar, Larsen & Toubro, Wartsila India, and more than 100 MSMEs involved.
Local warship‑grade steel for the ship was made through a partnership between the Navy, DRDO and Steel Authority of India (SAIL), allowing India to be self‑sufficient in warship steel.

Enhancing Maritime Capabilities:
In June 2023, the Indian Navy showed its strong maritime power by conducting a multi‑carrier operation with INS Vikrant, INS Vikramaditya, and a varied fleet of ships, submarines and aircraft.
This displayed India’s technology skills in the sea.

Strategic Procurement: Rafale‑Marine Jets:
In April 2025, India signed a ₹63,000 crore contract with France to buy 26 Rafale‑Marine fighter jets that can fly from aircraft carriers.
The deal covers pilot training, flight simulators, weapons and long‑term maintenance, and it includes technology transfer to strengthen Indian defence manufacturing.
The Rafale‑Marine jets will improve the air forces of both INS Vikrant and INS Vikramaditya, giving them top combat readiness.

Commitment to Indigenous Shipbuilding:
The Indian Navy aims to have a second local aircraft carrier and plans to base INS Vikrant in Visakhapatnam to boost the Eastern Naval Command.
This shows its pledge to self‑reliance and regional safety.
By December 2024, more than 133 ships and submarines had been built and commissioned in India.
The Navy remains a major supporter of the Indian shipbuilding industry.
By December 2024, 63 of the 64 warships planned for the Navy were being built in India, including the impressive INS Vikrant and nuclear submarines like INS Arihant and INS Arighaat.

Conclusion:
INS Vikrant is a lasting symbol of India’s maritime revival.
The locally built carrier moves across the sea and shows the country’s military strength.
It not only boosts the Navy’s role in regional security but also motivates future generations to achieve full defence self‑sufficiency.
As India grows its role in the Indo‑Pacific, the carrier also shows the country’s aim to be one of the world’s leading defence exporters.
INS Vikrant has brought new confidence to the nation and created a fresh sense of pride.

announcements.title: India’s growing green footprint
announcements.content:
Key Highlights

Introduction:
India has moved up to 9th place in the world for total forest area, according to FAO's Global Forest Resources Assessment 2025, released on 22 October 2025. In the previous assessment, India was 10th. India also remains 3rd worldwide for annual net gain of forest area. FAO is a UN agency that works to reduce hunger and manage natural resources like forests sustainably. The GFRA is a regular assessment of the world’s forests, giving detailed data on area, changes, management, and use.

GFRA 2025: India in a Global Context
Countries mentioned: Brazil, Canada, United States, and China.

The Global Forest Resources Assessment is the only worldwide review based on official national data. It classifies forests into two main types: naturally regenerating and planted. Naturally regenerating forests include primary forests, which have only native species. Planted forests include plantation forests (e.g., rubber) and other planted forests that are not plantations.

India has helped increase planted forests, adding to a global total of 10.9 million hectares.

Agroforestry in India

Deforestation and Net Changes
"Wood removals" refer to the amount of wood cut and taken from forests for purposes like roundwood or fuelwood production.

Forest emissions and removal trends 1990–2025 (FAO analytical brief)

Global scenario, India's achievements, and forest status changes

Key initiatives by the Government of India to boost forest cover:
1. Budget allocations
2. National Mission for a Green India (GIM)
3. National Afforestation Programme

Forest cover data shows that the world is making progress: some countries are cutting deforestation, while others are expanding forest area. India’s move to 9th place globally for total forest area, and staying 3rd for net annual gain, shows what strong national commitment can achieve. India’s ongoing work to expand forest cover, promote sustainable forestry, and implement missions like GIM highlights its commitment to protecting the environment and addressing climate change.

announcements.title: President of India will visit Kerala from Oct 21 to 24
announcements.content:
The President of India, Smt Droupadi Murmu, will visit Kerala from October 21 to 24, 2025.
The President will arrive in Thiruvananthapuram on the evening of October 21.
On October 22, the President will do Darshan and Aarti at the Sabarimala Temple.
On October 23, the President will reveal the bust of former President of India, Shri K.R. Narayanan at Raj Bhavan, Thiruvananthapuram.
Later, she will open the celebration of the Mahasamadhi Centenary of Sree Narayana Guru at Sivagiri Mutt, Varkala.
She will also attend the final ceremony of the Platinum Jubilee celebrations of St. Thomas College, Palai.
On October 24, the President will attend the centenary celebrations of St. Teresa’s College, Ernakulam.

announcements.title: President shows statue of former President K. Narayanan at Raj Bhavan, Thiruvananthapuram
announcements.content: President Smt Droupadi Murmu unveiled a bust of former President Shri KR Narayanan at Raj Bhavan, Thiruvananthapuram on October 23, 2025. Former President Shri Ram Nath Kovind, Kerala Governor Shri Rajendra Vishwanath Arlekar, Bihar Governor Shri Arif Mohammed Khan, Kerala Chief Minister Shri Pinarayi Vijayan and other important guests were present. She said Shri Narayanan’s life showed courage, perseverance and self‑belief. He reached the top office of our country through hard work and education. His excellent studies proved what can be achieved with determination and opportunity. Before politics he had a distinguished career in the Indian Foreign Service. He always promoted India’s values of peace, justice and cooperation. He was firm on fairness and inclusion. The President highlighted that Shri Narayanan always stayed connected to Kerala, his home state. He was inspired by its social progress and focus on education and inclusion. Even as president, he kept his ties to Kerala. He always said education should help all people, not just a few. He believed that human values are key to building a good society. The President said Shri Narayanan left a legacy of honesty, compassion and democracy. We can learn from his life and build a fair, caring India. She believes his memory will encourage people to follow his values of equality, honesty and serving the public. Click here to see the President's Speech- *** MJPS/SR
announcements.original_title: PRESIDENT OF INDIA UNVEILS BUST OF FORMER PRESIDENT OF INDIA, SHRI KR NARAYANAN AT RAJ BHAVAN, THIRUVANANTHAPURAM
announcements.summary:
President Droupadi Murmu unveiled a bust of former President Narayanan at Raj Bhavan, Thiruvananthapuram on October 23, 2025.
She praised his courage, perseverance, love of education and commitment to fairness.

announcements.title: President of India attends St. Thomas College graduation ceremony in Palai
announcements.content: The President of India, Smt Droupadi Murmu, attended the closing ceremony of the Platinum Jubilee celebrations of St. Thomas College at Palai, Kerala today (October 23, 2025). She said that education is the key to finding chances for growth and development. She noted that St. Thomas College was started to give education mainly to students from rural areas. She was pleased to see the college achieving this aim for 75 years. She said that schools like St. Thomas College are places where futures are made. She expressed joy about its focus on holistic learning and social justice, and that the college promotes values of sustainability and inclusivity. She also mentioned that the college encourages learning with a moral compass. She said that the 21st century is the ‘knowledge century’. Knowledge that drives innovation moves society forward and makes it self‑reliant. The power of literacy, education and knowledge has helped Kerala be a leading state on many human development measures. Speaking about Kottayam, she said the city has seen great social and educational changes. The famous movement against untouchability, known as ‘Vaikom Satyagrah’, happened a hundred years ago. It is called ‘Akshara‑nagari’ because it has been a fountain‑head of literacy and education. The ‘Sakshara Keralam’ movement was strengthened by the active role of people from this area. Shri P.N. Panicker’s great initiative to promote learning through the library movement was inspired by the simple but powerful message ‘Vayichu Valaruga’, meaning ‘Read and Grow’. She highlighted that the light of education shows the way to individual and collective progress. She praised the efforts of St. Thomas College in spreading the light of education. She is confident that St. Thomas College will continue to provide quality education and help build a more equal society and Viksit Bharat by 2047. Please click here to see the President's Speech- *** MJPS/SR
announcements.original_title: PRESIDENT OF INDIA GRACES VALEDICTORY FUNCTION OF THE PLATINUM JUBILEE CELEBRATIONS OF ST. THOMAS COLLEGE AT PALAI
announcements.summary:
The President of India, Smt Droupadi Murmu, attended the closing ceremony of St. Thomas College's Platinum Jubilee in Palai, Kerala on October 23, 2025.
She praised the college for 75 years of giving rural students quality, inclusive education and said it shows how learning builds a better future for all.

announcements.title: President of India attends St. Teresa’s College 100th anniversary
announcements.content: The President of India, Smt Droupadi Murmu attended the 100th anniversary celebrations of St. Teresa’s College in Ernakulam, Kerala, today (October 24, 2025). Speaking at the event, she said the college has been dedicated to women’s education in India while staying true to spiritual values. This is a great contribution to social change and nation-building. We should deeply honor the vision and legacy of the people who founded and guided this college for a hundred years. The President noted that women from Kerala have led the nation. Fifteen outstanding women of the Constituent Assembly added valuable ideas in making India’s Constitution. Of those, three were from Kerala: Ammu Swaminathan, Annie Mascarene and Dakshayani Velayudan. They influenced discussions on basic rights, social justice and gender equality, as well as other important areas. The first woman to become a High Court Judge in India was Justice Anna Chandy, who in 1956 became a judge in the High Court of Kerala. Justice M. Fathima Beevi made history when she became the first woman judge in the Supreme Court of India in 1989. The President said that the bright women students of St. Teresa’s College represent a young, thriving and vibrant India. She highlighted that women’s active role is essential for the country to use its demographic advantage. She pointed out that the Gender Budget allocation has risen four and a half times in the last decade. Women‑led MSMEs almost doubled between 2011 and 2024. A key goal for achieving a developed India by 2045 is 70% women workforce participation. Women from all parts of society drive India’s progress. She was pleased to note that alumni of this college are contributing positively to the country’s growth. She said higher education institutions like St. Teresa’s College will help India become a knowledge superpower. Please click here to see the President's Speech - *** MJPS/SR

announcements.title: PM's words at Rozgar Mela held online
announcements.content: Friends, this time the festival of lights, Diwali, has brought new light into your lives. During the celebrations, getting an appointment letter for a permanent job means double joy: the joy of the festivals and success. Today, this joy has reached more than 51 हजार young people in the country. I can feel how much happiness will be in all of your families. I offer my heartfelt congratulations to you and your family members. I wish you all the best for this new beginning in life. Friends, your enthusiasm, your ability to work hard, and the confidence that comes from seeing your dreams become real – when this is combined with a passion to serve the nation, this success will not be just personal. It will become the nation's success. Today, you have not only received a government appointment but also a chance to make an active contribution to national service. I am confident that you will work with this spirit, honesty, and integrity, and you will play a role in building better systems for future India. And you know, for us 'Nagarik Devo Bhava' is the mantra. With a spirit of service and dedication, we must never forget how to be useful in the life of every citizen. Friends, for the past 11 years, the country has been moving forward with a pledge to build Developed India. The biggest role belongs to our youth, all of you. Therefore, youth empowerment is the priority of the BJP-NDA government. Today, employment fairs have become a means to fulfill the dreams of young people. Through these employment fairs alone, in a short time, more than 11 लाख appointment letters have been issued. Moreover, this effort is not limited to government jobs. We have also launched the 'PM Vikas Bharat Employment Scheme' in the country. The goal under this scheme is to provide jobs to 3.5 करोड़ young people. Friends, today through campaigns like Skill India Mission, youth receive skill training, while initiatives such as the National Career Service Platform connect them with new opportunities. I have been informed that up to now, more than 7 करोड़ vacancies have been communicated to young people through this. These 7 करोड़ vacant positions are not a small figure. Friends, another major step for youth is the 'Pratibha Setu Portal'! Candidates who reach the final UPSC list but are not selected will no longer have their effort wasted. Hence, private and public institutions can invite those youth through this portal, conduct interviews, and provide opportunities. Using youth talent in this way will showcase India's youthful potential to the world. Friends, during this festive season, the GST savings celebration has added new colors. You all know how big the reform in GST rates was in the country. Its impact is not limited to people's savings; the Next Generation GST reforms are also expanding employment opportunities. When everyday items become cheaper, demand also rises. When demand rises, production and the supply chain pick up speed. And when factories produce more, new jobs are created. Therefore, the GST savings celebration is turning into a job celebration. We have just seen how record sales occurred on Dhanteras and Diwali, breaking old records and setting new ones, showing how GST reform has given new momentum to the economy. The MSME sector and retail trade are also witnessing a positive impact of this reform. Hence, many new job opportunities are emerging in manufacturing, logistics, packaging, and distribution. Friends, today India is the youngest country in the world. We regard India's youthful potential as the nation's great strength. We are moving forward in every field with the same mindset and confidence. Even our foreign policy works with the interests of Indian youth in mind. Our diplomatic talks and global MoUs now include training, upskilling, and employment generation for youth. Recently, the Prime Minister of Britain visited India. During this visit, India and Britain agreed to increase investment in sectors such as AI, fintech, and clean energy. A free trade agreement reached a few months ago between India and Britain will also create new opportunities. Similarly, investment partnerships have been formed with many European countries. These could create thousands of new jobs. Agreements with countries such as Brazil, Singapore, Korea, Canada, and others will increase investment, support start-ups and MSMEs, boost exports, and give youth new opportunities to work on global projects, opening many possibilities. Friends, the successes and vision of our country that we discuss today will also have a major role for you in the future. We must continuously work towards the goal of 'Vikas Bharat' (Developed India). Young work‑doers like you will carry this pledge to fruition. During this journey, you can get great help from the iGot Karmayogi Bharat platform. About 1.5 करोड़ employees are learning and upgrading skills through this platform. If you join them, you will develop a new work culture and a sense of good governance. Your efforts will shape India's future, and the dreams of citizens will come true. I once again wish you all success. Thank you very much. *** MJPS/ST/RK
announcements.original_title: Text of PM’s remarks during Rozgar Mela via Video Conferencing
announcements.summary:
During Diwali, the government gave appointment letters to more than 51 हजार young people and will create jobs for 3.5 करोड़ more through the PM Vikas Bharat Scheme.
It also launched the Pratibha Setu Portal and Skill India Mission to help youth find work and build a better future.

announcements.title: PM Modi speaks at Rozgar Mela
announcements.content: Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi spoke at the Rozgar Mela using video call today. He said that this year’s Diwali has added new light to everyone’s life. During the celebrations, getting permanent job offer letters brings double joy – festival cheer and job success. Shri Modi said that more than 51,000 young people across the country felt this happiness today. He congratulated the recipients and their families and wished them all the best for this new start. Shri Modi noted that the new hires are enthusiastic, hardworking and self‑confident. When they also want to serve the country, their success becomes a win for India. He said the new jobs are not just government roles, but chances to help build the country. He is confident the new hires will work honestly and help build a better India for the future. He asked the new hires to remember ‘Nagarik Devo Bhava’ and to work with service and dedication. He said that for 11 years India has been working hard to become developed, and the youth are key. Youth empowerment is a top priority. He said Rozgar Melas help young Indians get jobs, with more than 11 lakh appointment letters given through these Melas recently. He added that these efforts also aim beyond government jobs. The government started the ‘PM Viksit Bharat Rozgar Yojana’ to give jobs to 3.5 crore youth. The Skill India Mission gives training, and the National Career Service links young people to new jobs. The platform has shared info on over 7 crore vacancies with young people. The Prime Minister launched the ‘Pratibha Setu Portal’, giving chances to UPSC finalists who were not chosen. He said their work will not be wasted, as both private and public sectors are hiring them through the portal. He said using youth talent well will show India’s potential worldwide. He noted that the GST Bachat Utsav has improved the festive season, with big cuts in GST rates nationwide. He said these reforms do more than save consumers; new GST changes also create more jobs. When goods cost less, people buy more, factories make more, and more jobs are created. So the GST Bachat Utsav also becomes an Employment Festival. He said sales during Dhanteras and Diwali broke records, showing GST reforms boost the economy. He said the reforms help MSMEs and retail trade, creating jobs in making, logistics, packaging and delivery. He said India is the world’s youngest country and its youth are a great strength. This belief helps India progress in all areas, even foreign policy, which now considers young people’s interests. He said India’s foreign deals and agreements now include training, upskilling and jobs for young people. He said that when the UK Prime Minister visited, both countries agreed to increase investment in AI, fintech and clean energy. He added the free trade deal with the UK will create more opportunities. Investment deals with European nations are expected to create many new jobs. He said deals with Brazil, Singapore, Korea and Canada will bring investment, help startups and MSMEs, grow exports and give young people chances to work on international projects. He said the new youth will help achieve these goals, and that young workers will lead the way to a developed India. He said the ‘i-Got Karmayogi Bharat Platform’ is useful, and about 1.5 crore government staff already use it. He urged the new hires to join the platform, which will teach them good work habits and governance. He said India’s future and its people’s dreams depend on their work. He wished all appointees again. Speaking to the Rozgar Mela. Congratulating the new hires. https://t.co/ZqoiS3FDJ0 *** MJPS/SR

announcements.summary:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi spoke at Rozgar Mela about how Diwali brings new light and new jobs to 51,000+ young people, making them happy.
He congratulated the new hires and urged them to work hard for a better India.

announcements.title: English version of PM’s comments at Rozgar Mela online
announcements.content:
Friends, this Diwali, the festival of lights, has added new joy to everyone’s lives. More than 51 000 young people have received permanent job offer letters during the celebrations, bringing double happiness to families. I feel how much joy will fill your homes. I congratulate you and your families and wish you a bright new beginning. When enthusiasm, hard work, confidence from realised dreams, and passion to serve the country combine, success becomes personal and also a national success. Today, you have not only a government job but also a chance to help the nation. I trust you will work honestly and help build better systems for future India. Our mantra is ‘नागरिक देवो भव:’. With service and dedication, we must always remember how we can help every citizen.

For 11 years the country has been working to build a developed India. Youth are key to this goal, so the BJP‑NDA government prioritises their empowerment. Employment fairs now give 11 lakh job letters and are not limited to government jobs. We also launched the PM Viksit Bharat Rojgar Yojana to provide jobs to 3.5 crore young people.

Youth now gain skills through campaigns like the Skill India Mission and find opportunities via the National Career Service Platform, which shares information on over 7 crore vacancies. This large number shows how many jobs can be created.

Another big step is the Pratibha Setu Portal. Candidates who reached the UPSC final list but were not selected can now use the portal for interviews and jobs from private and public institutions.

The GST Savings Festival has added new colours this year. Reducing GST rates has helped people save, and also created more jobs through the Next Generation GST Reforms. Cheaper everyday goods raise demand, which boosts production, supply chains, and new jobs. This GST reform is turning into an employment festival. Record sales on Dhanteras and Diwali show the positive impact on the economy, especially for MSMEs and retail trade. New jobs arise in manufacturing, logistics, packaging, and distribution.

India has the largest youth population worldwide. Youth power is our biggest strength, and we move forward with confidence in all fields. Even foreign policy considers youth interests. Our talks, MoUs, training, up‑skilling, and job creation are included. Recently, the British Prime Minister visited India. India and Britain agreed to increase investment in AI, fintech, and clean energy. The free trade agreement signed a few months ago will create new opportunities. Similar partnerships with several European countries, and agreements with Brazil, Singapore, Korea, Canada, and others, will boost investment, support start‑ups and MSMEs, increase exports, and give young people chances to work on global projects.

Today, we talk about the country’s successes and vision, and you will play a big role. Young Karmayogis like you will bring the goal of ‘Developed India’ to reality. The iGot Karmayogi Bharat platform can help you; about 1.5 crore employees use it to learn and upgrade skills. If you join, you will develop a new work culture and sense of good governance. Your efforts will shape India’s future and fulfil the countrymen’s dreams. I once again send my best wishes. Thank you very much. *** MJPS/VJ/SS
announcements.original_title: English rendering of PM’s remarks during Rozgar Mela via Video Conferencing
announcements.summary:
During Diwali, 51 000 young people received permanent job offers, bringing happiness to families.
The government also launched programmes like PM Viksit Bharat Rojgar Yojana, Skill India Mission, and portals such as Pratibha Setu and iGot Karmayogi Bharat to give more jobs and skill training.

announcements.title: Vice President says hello to the country before Deepawali
announcements.content: Vice-President C.P. Radhakrishnan greeted people on Deepawali. He said the festival shows good beating bad and knowledge beating ignorance. At the meeting, the Vice‑President was briefed on the ministries' main projects that aim to boost science research and innovation, develop and sell technology, improve biotech, quantum computing, and cyber‑security, and support weather services, climate and ocean studies, and disaster protection. He praised the ministries for building India’s innovation‑driven science system and advancing cutting‑edge research. He noted India’s jump from 81st place in 2015 to 38th in the Global Innovation Index 2025, and the rise in patents, scientific papers, and tech‑driven growth. He commended India’s vaccine breakthroughs, the BharatGenAI large language model, and advances in quantum computing. He also stressed the need for ethical biotech research, encouraging young people to pursue science careers, and stronger industry ties. He highlighted faster weather forecasting and the great potential of India’s blue economy, and urged more global partnerships to keep India a leader in science. P. Radhakrishnan, at Parliament House today. They explained the key projects, achievements, and future plans of the Ministries of Electronics & IT and Information & Broadcasting to boost India’s digital growth and improve the country’s information and communication system. He stressed the need to focus on Tier‑2 and Tier‑3 cities as new software and innovation centres. He also highlighted the importance of using social media responsibly and encouraging new digital content.
